To others who have a modicum of intelligence, an appreciation for good filmmaking and an understanding of the subject matter, this will be an absolutely outstanding gem with a strong resonating beat that cuts straight to the heart of you. Such is the utter emotional devastation this movie fills you with at the end, to watch it again would be painful. Hopkins deserves his Oscar for this without doubt.

A deliberately confusing movie depicting the confusion dementia causes, brilliantly told and directed, and above all absolutely astonishing acting from Anthony Hoping. After watching this you will definitely be worried about growing old.
Exquisite, unique, so painfully that I started to cry... Full of emotions and feelings... Anthony Hopkins must win this academy award. Bravo! 👏 👏 👏

I watched this movie as soon as I heard it received Oscar. The movie is really good. It makes us realize how old people suffers but we even don't realize. We try to get rid of them though we know, we are hurting their feeling. So cruel! It is even more difficult for a person having demensia. Anthony Hopkins did a amazing job and it is as good as'' The silence of the lambs''.Anyone may finds this movie a bit boring as it is kind of realistic movie about elderly aged person situations, feelings. But,for acting heads down, can't compliant.

We in the family think my Mother is showing signs of some sort of Dementia? After seeing this film I broke down as the sign are similar although very early stages. A Beautiful Filn about the end of life of a sick loved one. Some thing we all have to face one day.

The good thing - Sir Anthony Hopkins, after a long expectation, refuge in easy formulas and what can be defined as cliches/ manneririsms, gives a magnificent acting. For me, The Father is a sort of return to past, reminding the bad condition of one of loved ones. But, maybe, the realism is one of its basic fundamental virtues. The provocative perspective, the fall of a world / order and the need, high need to understand as a need of breathing. An admirable work and splendid job of Olivia Colman.

reviews.review_title: God forbid this happens to anyone
reviews.content: WARNING: *MILD SPOILERS*It's amazing what Anthony Hopkins can do despite being in his 80s. His work in The Silence of the Lambs is iconic but I think his performance in this film can rival that.The Father follows Anthony, an ageing man who refuses assistance from his daughter Anne. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, he begins to doubt his loved ones, his mind and even reality.This is genuinely one of the saddest and most painful films I've had to sit through. Based off his own play, Florian Zeller gives us a devastating film about dementia and one that I feel will connect with many people. I don't know anyone with this illness but I cannot imagine how difficult it must be for the person and the people around them to deal with this problem. There is a great amount of confidence displayed by Zeller in portraying this. The film does such a phenomenal job of putting us into the same perspective as Hopkins. Yorgos Lamprinos' editing is fantastic as the structure becomes more confusing. Locations and actors would change wth time going forwards and backwards. It was a great visual choice to have different actors play the same character as it captured the memory loss and confused state Hopkins was in. All of these elements combined gave so much more clarity to how it would feel having dementia. The script by Florian Zeller and Christopher Hampton is very well written. Every single piece of dialogue sounds incredibly natural making all of the characters feel like real people and that added to the emotional value of the story.The performances in conjunction with the dialogues make this film as emotional as can be. Anthony Hopkins delivers an astounding performance that feels all too real and depicts dementia to the best of his ability. There are some great subtleties in the way he delivers dialogues and even changes moods in a smooth manner. His acting in the ending alone where he breaks down after being unable to understand the world is enough to make anyone cry which is a further testament as to how great he is here. Olivia Colman is also excellent. She puts forth an incredible performance that showcases the pain and distress a daughter feels seeing her father in this state gracefully.The Father might just be my favourite film of 2020. It does such an amazing job putting the audience into the shoes of Hopkins' character and helping us get a better understanding of this illness. It's very depressing and I don't know if I want to go through this experience again. All I know is that Florian Zeller is a master storyteller and Hopkins deserves to win an Oscar.

reviews.review_title: Dementia from the perspective of the sufferer! [+82%]
reviews.content: What makes The Father a brilliant film is its unwavering depiction of an elderly man with dementia. The said man (oddly enough, named Anthony) is played by Sir Anthony Hopkins (who's picking up his second Academy Award win in his 80s), with fragmented episodes playing out to audiences exactly the way they would in front of his eyes. The deliberately disjointed narrative is the outcome of a masterfully penned screenplay by Florian Zeller (whose play "Le Père", the film is based on) and Christopher Hampton - the information presented to us in tidbits keeps us wildly guessing all through.Performances complement the writing in uplifting the film. Apart from Hopkins, the most notable show is from Olivia Colman who plays Anne (Anthony's daughter). It also includes neat work from Imogen Poots, Olivia Williams, Rufus Sewell, and a few others. Editor Yorgos Lamprinos marvellously (dis)connects Anthony's fading memories and present events - faces, personas, settings, and situations changing within seconds of each other. Hopkins gracefully transitions between distressed, anxious, sad, and elated in a manner that, by all means, gives dementia a multi-layered perspective.The Father startled me in ways conventional psychological horror-thrillers wouldn't, with its overall disorientation. When I heard Anthony say "..I feel as if I'm losing all my leaves", it left me both restless and helpless. Restless, because I wanted Anthony to feel wholesome once again even for a few seconds, but that wasn't going to be the case. Helpless, because it could be you or me in the same situation later in life. When a film leaves that sort of aftertaste, it's either exceptionally good or downright horrible. In this case, it's the former.

My short review will reflect the title of my short review: I didn't get the chance to see it in the cinema, but I watched it TWICE on a 10 hour flight from Heathrow to Dallas. This film hit me hard. Both in that I do have relatives who are suffering from dementia and Alzheimer's: please bare in mind that the condition Anthony has is never specified. But both of those conditions is known for confusing things for the sufferer, and the film is presented that way. It will mess with your mind but come together at the end. So sad, brilliantly written, beautiful film making.

reviews.review_title: Most scary film I have seen, as so real.
reviews.content: Not sure how too sum it up. Stunning performances. Both my parents suffered from dementia, this film hit so many of the experiences we went through in trying to care for them.We were in tears during the film and after, I think we relived our experiences. Masterpiece of cinema.

reviews.review_title: Sensitively told with a magnificent Anthony Hopkins
reviews.content: Many films have been made about the last stages of life, but, it's hard to recall one which so doggedly adheres to capturing those last glimpses of a rational mind as does Florian Zeller's THE FATHER from the main character's own viewpoint. Adapted from his own play (with critical input from acclaimed screenwriter Christopher Hampton), Zeller focuses his entire attention on his title character, Anthony, magnificently performed by Oscar nominated Anthony Hopkins.The viewer is presented with Anthony as a widower and former engineer who is cared for by his loving daughter Annie (Olivia Coleman; also justly nominated) and a parade of day-care workers, including, most prominently, Laura (Imogen Poots). We also see Anthony in both his own flat and in that of Annie. The complex screenplay is never played strictly chronological, and there are other phantoms and figures lurking in the reaches of Anthony's mind. Scenes and dialogue are repeated, sometimes exactly, and other times with a twist. Events may be taking place over five years as easily as in one. The theme that every day is a "new" day for one with dementia is eloquently depicted. It's a difficult task for the actors as well, and they have to play everything straight or the movie would collapse. Hopkins, Coleman, Poots and the rest of the cast are all equal to the challenge and go beyond. Of particular note is Olivia Williams as another caregiver. Her screen-time is rather brief, but no less effective. Peter Francis' Production Design subtly but effectively portrays the confusion in Anthony's mind. Yorgos Lamprinos' editing is precise and there is a grace to Ben Smithard's cinematography and Ludovico Einaldi's score (abetted by some choice classical music).THE FATHER isn't a technical achievement (as well as it produced). It is a heartbreaking personal one. Zeller is the conductor here, but it is Hopkins who must play the notes. This is a case where one's familiarity with the actor and his long worthy career could have been a burden, but Hopkins easily allays any doubts, and, even when we recognize a bit or two from his acting repertoire, it only adds to the poignancy of the screenplay. As Hopkins descends deeper into the void, it comes not just with sadness, but, with sweet mercy for his soul.

A journey through the mind of a demented gentleman. I can't even begin to explain how brilliantly the script was written, making us feel what he feels and see what he sees. Go through confusion, doubt and paranoid thoughts. Sir Anthony Hopkins' performance was really unmatched. A wonderful, painful movie especially if you live with someone with dementia.

The way this film examines what it may be like for somebody suffering from dementia is devastating. It's difficult to imagine how it would be to watch anyone who is going through this in real life; or indeed has a loved one with dementia. One of the things best aspects of this film is how, for the most part, we are watching the story from Anthony's perspective. We see him becoming confused and forgetful. With that comes a repetitiveness, often combined with confusion. As an audience we see events happen in different ways. We're not always sure about when things are happening, what time of day it is or how much time has passed. We see parts of the room change from scene to scene. Some of the actors and actresses change, signifying Anthony's inability to remember who people are. Sir Anthony Hopkins was magnificent in the role. Totally believable. Prior to watching this film, i always thought Chadwick Boseman deserved an Oscar for his performance, but now having seen this film, I have to rethink that idea as Sir Anthony Hopkins truly deserved his Best Actor Oscar. The supporting cast were also great. Technically, the production design and editing were brilliant. The way the sets and characters change from scene to scene means that we experience some of the confusion that he goes through was creative. The score was good too. Overall, a fantastically written, well acted and directed film. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: You obviously have not been through this
reviews.content: This is nothing like real life. I love Anthony Hopkins but this is a terrible portrayal of what living with someone with dementia is like. So disappointing.

The Father is a thoroughly realistic and powerful depiction of dementia. Not only are the performances of Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman masterful, but the featured perspective is an unforgettable gem. This film is definitely an important must watch for teens and adults, and accurately earns it's truthful rewards.So not only is The Father a masterpiece; it's a total experience. What the film does is it grabs and places you in the perspective of a sufferer, meaning that the devastating story indeed relies on the realistic acting. This compelling tale is structured and gets very personal at times, but still manages to be a moving drama to be added to the must-watch list.So what else can you say? The Father is a wounding, heartbreaking and jaw-dropping masterpiece in which Anthony Hopkins delivers a breath-snatching performance. Now go ahead and experience this cleverly-made Alzheimer's drama.If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.

This falls under the category of "exceptional movies I never want to watch again". A painfully accurate depiction of a man suffering from the progression of dementia and the effect on those around him. Hopkins is phenomenal. One of his greatest performances. And one of the best movies I have seen in a long time.
Anthony Hopkins with his very subtle skills shows how dementia really feels like..pure class acting.

The Father is a tough, emotional, and draining film, but it is an absolute must watch for so many reasons.Anthony Hopkins gives a flawless, stunning and gut wrenching performance. One of the finest displays of acting I've ever seen. I felt so drawn in and emotionally involved in his character, unable to take my eyes off of his mesmerising performance. Truly astounding.Olivia Coleman was incredible too. So much emotion and it was heartbreaking experiencing the relationship and the dynamic between the two. They had such a believable father daughter relationship which was so powerful and poignant.The screenplay is superb. Every word, every story beat, every pause and glance are filled with drama, emotion and suspense. It is masterful stuff.Florian Zeller's direction is also incredible. You can tell it was adapted from the stage as it has that authenticity and closeness to it. The way that he puts us in the mind of Anthony is just phenomenal. At times this film almost feels like a horror or suspense thriller as we try to figure out what is real and what isn't. Just marvellous.I can't sing this The Father's praises enough. A masterclass in both film making and acting.

reviews.review_title: Depressing subject matter elevated by good filmmaking
reviews.content: I had a great deal of COVID anticipation for this film having missed the brief theatrical run and seeing Sir Anthony Hopkins being awarded at the Academy Awards 2021 as Best Actor for his performance as the lead also called Anthony (which I found an annoyance at first strangely enough).The technical abilities on display including set design and cinematography in a single location (Anthony's flat) is second to none.Hopkins does indeed deliver an Oscar worthy performance as the supporting cast including Olivia Colman should also receive praise in bringing an all to common problem that afflicts many families unfortunately, dementia/Alzheimers Disease to a film.Without revealing plot the director plays mind games with the viewer. Okay maybe one then. Look at the furniture and decoration! I am sure that was the intention. It sure did confuse me!However other films deal with the harrowing subject matter in a more satisfying way and I was left underwhelmed with this film compared to other Academy Award fare in 2021.

reviews.review_title: Anthony Hopkins delivers a magnificent performance
reviews.content: This is the kind of movie which needs to be seen at least twice. Once in a lifetime one gets to see a performance so perfect. Anthony Hopkins plays a 84 year old man ( his real age) battling dementia , senility and a fading memory where he keeps forgetting names, faces, events and even timelines. His is a performance full of nuances, subtle, refined and memorable. When told by daughter Anne that she is leaving for Paris, Anthony ( also his name in the film) is bitter and says that rats are abandoning ship. He also keeps talking about his late younger daughter as if she was still alive. The film should relate to everyone since we have all seen old relatives with similar ailments.Director Florian Zeller skillfully uses different actors for same characters within the confines of the claustrophobic London flat. The director brings out the angst, distress, confusion and frustration of Anthony so effectively as he weaves the riveting narrative. It is a treat to watch Anthony as he cajoles his carer and does some tap dancing for her.The location of this film is the flat, and for immensely talented Anthony this is his stage where he delivers his lines with mastery. ( Luckily for audience the verbal communication of Anthony is perfect ). The most touching moment is towards the end when Anthony breaks down in a sort of catharsis as the carer comforts him. " I am losing all my leaves " he says sadly.The camera and characters do not move out of the flat. Only once the camera moves to the window to look outside and see a little boy playing and Anthony smiles. The film has excellent cinematography , editing and sound.

In daily life, there are a lot of things that change very fast. We can't stop time, everything is changing around us. Sometimes a healthy mind might have be missed the changes or might refuse them. In this script, we see this changes through the eyes of an old man. The old man that can't adapt the changes as fast as the speed of change. There is no one reality for this man. He just splashes in the timeline and find out the thinks just he can remember. With magnificent acting of Antony Hopkins, we watch the old man's despair.
This movie shows us the world from point of view of the old man. It makes us realized how fast the world changes and how fast we are adapt the changes.

reviews.review_title: A perfect symphony where every player is at the top of their game, and not a beat is missed
reviews.content: Anthony Hopkins was already considered one of the all time greats, but he easily delivers the performance of his career, injecting a humanity to the character while slowly unravelling towards a show stopping breakdown. Olivia Colman is no slouch backing him up either.The screenplay takes an inventive, non linear approach to the narrative, spiralling through loops that painstakingly fit together like puzzle pieces. It doesn't simply describe how the character is feeling, but brings the viewer into his world and makes you feel the frustrating confusion of his declining state.The film takes place almost exclusively in a small apartment, so one wouldn't imagine the cinematography and set design would be much to bark at, but on the contrary, it becomes a storytelling device unto itself. It's just loaded with intricate details, and the tiny changes and parallels in the surroundings further draw us in to the character's condition.It is an absolutely heartbreaking film, both for how you sympathize with the onscreen drama, and how painfully realistic it all is. A devastating reminder of the deterioration that comes with aging that's either gonna bum you out, or inspire you to live your life while you still can.

reviews.review_title: Another striking piece of experiential cinema
reviews.content: This film does a really good job of placing the viewer into the shoes of a dementia patient. Everything from a technical point of view-the writing, directing, art direction and especially the editing-carries off the central conceit very well. The viewer ends up being a wash in time and reality as Anthony is. Moreover, the film does not (just) treat Anthony as an object of pity-he is also a figure of conflict and causes pain for his love ones. The film has a messy reality to it that I rather like. Hopkins-in a good way-is a hot mess in this film and it is amazing how *much* of the gamut of humanity he goes through here.I am afraid however the film has no repeat viewing value. The more clearly you can put the narrative together the less you feel like Anthony-which defeats the point of the film. Everyone should see this film-it is a great one off experience-but it lacks the true depth Great Films have. It is something of a parlor trick.

reviews.review_title: It's a Psychological Horror, More Than a Tragedy
reviews.content: Brilliantly crafted story, have never seen anything quite like it.

Many films have depicted this disease, but few have dared to do it from the perspective of the person who suffers from it. It is appreciated that the scriptwriter is a pioneer in this regard. In addition, creative decisions are correct regarding the message. The best thing about the movie is Anthony Hopkins, who deserves much more than an Oscar for this performance. The only flaw is that, on very few occasions, the tape feels tedious and perhaps it could have been even shorter. If not for that (like one or two scenes), I would give it 10/10.

reviews.review_title: A painful depiction of senile dementia. Hopkins delivered a master performance.
reviews.content: "The Father" is not an easy movie to go through. It shows what it means to slowly but inevitably lose the grasp of reality, from the point of view of a person affected by advanced senile dementia. I felt constantly confused, there are a lot of sequences where I did not understand what was happening at all, but hopefully everything is clarified by the end of the film. Anthony Hopkins delivers a wonderful performance, its interpretation is spotless. You can see the pain in his expressions, the confusion in his eyes and gestures. It is a punch of reality, directly on your face. The director managed to depict the sickness in a meaningful and truthful way: Anthony has its good moments where he laughs and he is full of life, but then, the more we go on, the more we see his condition getting worse and worse: he loses track of time and space, he swap events and people in his life, he is not able to think logically. The ending is heartbreaking, I was in tears.It is scary to see what aging can do to some people. This movie is like a lucid nightmare. It is slow paced, and lets the audience sink deeper and deeper into a malfunctioning brain. I am speechless, Florian Zeller partially restored my hope in modern cinema. I am happy to see that the mainstream market is still able to deliver good stories. The cast is small, and every single actor plays a specific role that fits in the plot. Everyone had the perfect amount of screen time. If I have to find one weakness, it would be some dialogues lines in a couple of dialogues with professional carers, that are not very believable. May this film be a lesson for all production companies: stop paying your attention exclusively to franchises and release more meaningful movies like "The Father". I am craving for them.

This film does an amazing job of giving an insight into the confusing world that a dementia sufferer inhabits. Memories of people, events and places lost or distorted and sometimes imagined; faces and names changing, time shifting.Hopkins plays Anthony, a man struggling to make sense of what is happening to him. Visited by Anne (his daughter) who is trying to care for her father while holding her life together the story centres around their exchanges, difficult, scary, sometimes humourous, and for the greater part bewildering, we are given Anthony's version of reality to decipher.What the film does so well is to bring some of that disorientation to the viewer, without becoming inaccessible. Hopkins does an astonishing job - but credit has to go to everyone involved, the entire cast, the direction, the writing, the music, and everything in-between.The film's stage roots are evident in the simplicity of its location, set almost entirely in an apartment, and this is crucial in creating a feeling of claustrophobic, but also in letting us experience the life of the characters.Never slipping into sentimentality, we are nevertheless taken on a bruising emotional journey, never 100% sure of what is real (which of course is the point) somehow I left the cinema feeling that I understood a whole lot more about the reality, and surrealities of life for a sufferer, which is an incredible achievement.

Anthony Hopkins was amazing! He's in his 80s and is still such a wonderful actor. Olivia Colman can do no wrong in my eyes, and she's put in a great performance in this movie as always.This movie was depressing but so well done. I was just as confused as Anthony was, which is the point. Seeing this from his point of view was very refreshing and well done.
Absolutely amazing and unbelievable performance by Antony Hopkins!

reviews.review_title: Wasn't expecting that. And I liked it - a whole lot!
reviews.content: No Oscar is worthy of Anthony Hopkins performance here. One of the World's best actors of all time just raised the bar to a height that I can't see being bettered anytime soon. Olivia Colman's performance is utterly superb. This is not the type of film I would watch. My wife suggested we give it a try. At the end, we were both speechless and in awe of the best film we have seen in many, many years. I felt is if I was living in the story, as if I were there, in his shoes, in their shoes. I highly recommend this film. The story may not be for everyone, but the acting by Hopkins & Colman is as convincing and real as it can ever get.

Most of us have had a loved one who has or is suffering from dementia. It's a horrible disease that's both frustrating for the sufferer and the carer.This is an absolutely brilliant portrayal of an old man who refuses all assistance from his daughter as he ages. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, and how he begins to doubt his loved ones, his own mind .The way this film is made is so clever .The story is told as if the viewer is seeing what the sufferer is experiencing .We are never quite clear what is real or what is In Anthony's head .As the film goes on and the dementia gets worse his confusion comes to the boil and it's heartbreaking.Anthony Hopkins should win the best actor Oscar for his performance but he won't .That will go posthumously to Chadwick Boseman but any previous year , before the Academy's agenda changed , he would have done and it's a shame that political correctness now wins over what is actually the most deserving .If The Father doesn't finish in my top 3 films of 2021 , I'll be surprised. I gave it four and a half stars but it very nearly got the full five .Absolutely fantastic film .

The movie absolutely thrilling and so perfectly twisted that you cannot keep your mind focused like in the SUPER HERO MOVIES .. NOW THIS IS A 🍿🎥 NO STERIOD JUNKIES JUMPING AROUND WITH ROPES AND UNDERWEARS .. THE PERFECTION OF EDITING IS ONE OF KIND.. THIS MOVIE DESERVES AN OSCAR.. omg the HOPKINS ACTING IS SO GOOD I GOT GOOSEBUMPS..had a good time watching this movie.. it was like watching Interstellar ...perfect 10/10 movie.. loved it to the core.

This is a slow and sad film . A lot of it takes place in an apartment. It is based on a play . Anthony Hopkins puts in a brilliant performance as the elderly man Antony suffering dementia . Olivia Coleman puts in a good performance as his daughter .
Wow. What a terrifying movie. Give that Oscar to Anthony Hopkins already. We shouldn't even compare.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant, if you understand what's going on!
reviews.content: Luckily my wife has worked with people with dementia and she could explain what was really going on. It's a brilliant portrayal of what is like for a person suffering from the disease.I can't put a spoiler in this but just so hope you get it!!!

The story is confusing but then you start to realise it's completely from the dementia sufferers perspective.You never quite know if Olivia Coleman is going to Paris, then she isn't.There is a scene where his daughter is played by another actress.Which adds to the confusion.There are scenes that repeat themselves straight away.You always think he is in his flat and then you realise he isn't.You start checking yourself if he is wearing a watch because you know what's coming if he isn't.Olivia Coleman also does a great job as the long suffering carer/ daughter.Hopkins goes from charming to angry to confused very quickly.

reviews.review_title: As good as film making gets
reviews.content: Extraordinary film. Excellent performances all round and just brilliant made. Not exactly light subject matter but this film certainly takes you on a journey.
This is a first movie...I'm just blown awayAmazing job from all the actors too and clearly a modern cinematic masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: A tough subject and a very difficult watch
reviews.content: Usually watching a film is a bit of escapism and entertainment but sometimes it's hard hitting and close to home. This film is undoubtedly the latter.Both Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman play their roles really well and convey the toughness of the situation.My only issue was, I understood what they were trying to do with the film, but there were parts of the plot that were hard to understand but maybe that was the point.

reviews.review_title: This movie touched me so much
reviews.content: I think that this is one of the best movie of the last 20 years. You can really explore the dementia sufferer's mind: it's possible to watch the world from his perspective.Anthony Hopkins had one of his best performance ever and Olivia Colman supports him magnificently.The emotions that made me feel are such that I can't not give a 9.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful piece of work, this one.
reviews.content:
A very compassionate and empathic movie told from inside the head of a man moving into dementia. It always struck how that centuries old term, that was considered an insult some decades ago, is now a blithe part of forensic terminology.Hopkins, whose name is Anthony in this movie, a detail to ponder, it increases the sense of intimacy we have with the actor and suggests his own commitment to the role, and sense of his mortality., runs away with this performance, perhaps one of his best, and in his case that's surely saying something.His confusion becomes our confusion, his hallucinations and delusions become ours, and only the final ten minutes appear to sort out things in
a way that ties the suggestions together.It probably deserves a second viewing, unless you can try to stop second guessing things and let the movie lead you, let yourself enter Anthony's head, and just go where it takes you. Trust the composition, your clouds will clear anyway, if not his, but then you have likely seen it already if you happen to be reading this.He's constantly fighting in this movie, for his own sanity in effect, though it always seems that the world around him is tricking him.The movie wraps with his degeneration to infantilism, and you might sense that the only light that filters in comes with this hyper-vulnerable senile nascence, that fuses with his sense of impending death, and terrible yearning to go home.It's a brilliant portrait, in a career marked by brilliance, and a movie of substance and value and amazing accuracy; one medical and emotional bullseye after another; a great flick.

It's one of the most impressive movies I've seen. Fading out from life could not be better described. Also, words are not enough to describe Anthony Hopkins' outstanding performance. This movie can also be played as a theater, its single place form and character transitions are very suitable for this.

reviews.review_title: A unique and original film that is masterfully crafted
reviews.content: Sometimes an idea for a film comes along that is so good you can't help but wonder how it hasn't been done before. 'The Father' was very much a case of that for me. I couldn't get over what a brilliant concept for a film it was. Dementia is a truly heart-breaking condition and to be put in the shoes of the character who has is not only fascinating, it is also important I think. It's great that people can understand what others are going through and relate to their struggles. The way they did that here was masterful.Anthony Hopkins in the lead role is truly incredible. He has been nominated for Best Actor at the Academy Awards and he thoroughly deserves it. Most years with a performance this good he would've been a lock to win it as well. This is one of those performances where he is so good that you actually have to keep constantly reminding yourself that he doesn't actually have this condition. Olivia Colman has also been nominated for Best Supporting Actress. She is also really good in this film. Her role isn't quite as easy to shine in, but nonetheless she finds a way. Her heart-break over the situation becomes our heart-break as an audience.The way this film is structured is nearing perfection. It's so clever and every time you think you have it figured out it hits you from a different angle you hadn't seen coming. The final scene in this movie is one of the most devastating scenes I've ever seen in a movie. This is an incredible film that isn't just a must-see, it's mandatory viewing in my opinion. A truly great film.

reviews.review_title: Don't lie to me that you are mad when that man slap Anthony.
reviews.content: Easy to say this is Hopkins' best performance.It is so easy for him to be natural yet delivers heart wrenching performance.How did u react when he was slapped by that man??I was mad like hell. Like someone slapped my own parent. That how great his performance was. This movie will haunt you for years.Great movie. Great movie indeed.

What a performance..
Great movie with a hard-to-forget kind of message.The actors did a great job but Hopkins really steals the show once again.One of the best films in recent years, trully remarkable work.

I understand Anthony Hopkins is in the movie, but how does that automatically make it a 10? Yes, his performance was fantastic, yes, the supporting characters also did very well. In my opinion, there wasn't any climax to the movie, not really a whole ton of excitement, just a very steady rhythm of confusion (intended) and uncertainty. Yes I get it, there's meant to be confusion because it's really supposed to emphasize how an individual with dementia and/or Alzheimer's would feel. I think they did an excellent job highlighting the fear that comes with this type of condition, and the family challenges that may develop. I'd consider it more of an educational movie with plain avenues of entertainment versus a jaw-dropping, box office breaking film. I'll more than likely get a lot of criticism for this, but everyone's entitled to their opinion.
Great acting! Indeed an Oscar winner! He was so into the character.

The Good: I went into this one expecting Oscar Bait, a film that's *fine* but nothing ground breaking or particularly memorable, ala...Nomadland or Green Book. But, no, The Father is the real deal. An actual masterpiece that - despite the difficult subject matter - I can't wait to watch again.The non-linear storytelling this film employs is truly incredible. The movie manages to be confusing and disorienting, yet understandable at the same time. We follow Anthony (Hopkins) as he struggles to make sense of the events in front of him; time jumps and skips, characters swap faces, things happen and then don't. It's an incredible experience, rooted entirely in empathy. God forbid any of us go through this when we age, but it's at least a window. The Father represents the ultimate purpose for tragic art itself: to understand, contextualize, empathize...to prepare ourselves.The performances in this film are next level. Anthony Hopkins absolutely deserved his Oscar for this; the way he stares off into space or how his mood changes and the audience doesn't need dialog to see this is remarkable. He's not a likeable character; one thing I really appreciated about this film is how it doesn't sugarcoat or glorify the mentally ill. He's a jerk, difficult to live with or appreciate, save for those moments where the memory of the man he was shines through. That feels distressingly real to me. Hopkins imbues this character with such humanity, I feel like he's a real person. I honestly forgot at times this was a performance. Olivia Coleman is also wonderful, as she is in basically everything.I also thought this was a wonderfully written and edited film. It is paced so well and never feels dull or slow. It's moving constantly and the audience is just as confused as Anthony is by the passage of time. Making this film truly one that grabs and holds your attention from the get go. If you were getting sick of me heaping praise on this one, I also really liked the set design. It feels like an expertly put together stage play at times and the subtle distinctions in the set is such a wonderful and creative touch.GAH. I love this movie so much.The Bad: Honestly, I'd be nitpicking at this point. I did think Imogen Poots' performance is maybe the weakest here and I kind wished we saw more of her. But, that's really all I can think of.The Ugly: The Father is a tough watch, especially for those with elderly parents or grandparents who've gone through this debilitating ailment. For that reason alone, I'd say it's not for everyone. Yet, I think it's necessary for everyone to experience difficult subject matter and honestly, I felt more hopeful by the end of this film than anything.The Father might be the most life affirming film I've seen in ages; the ultimate message being that decline and death is inevitable. All we know for certain is the time we have right now. Spend time with your loved ones, take chances, live your life. Because we will all hit a point where we can't anymore. I think that's beautiful.

Dementia is distressing
The Script is cleverly woven to show us what its like to live through dementia from the view of the victim. Anthony Hopkins does a wonderful job of portraying the victim. The change of principle characters is confusing but imagine how upsetting it is for someone actually living through it.The sound is ok
The Photography is ok
The Acting is GoodIts worth a watch 👍

An incredible interesting and haunting look into the horror of a fading mind and how it takes no prisoners leave no winners. The hardship of the suffer The burden of the carers. Acted incredibly by Hopkins hard to imagine who could have done a finer performance. A amazing movie I would recommend heartbreaking uncomfortable to the point I couldn't watch it again.

A confusing film about a confusing subject matter layered over a father-daughter relationship with son-in-law issues. Bringing a parent to live in a child's marriage is difficult on its own. Add a debilitating memory-loss disease to the equation and you cannot even begin to explain or describe the chaos. Now imagine you can see it from the perspective of the confused sufferer of this unnamed burden. Only then will you be in the same space this director marvellously created. Wouldn't have worked as a film under any other circumstance that brought this creative team together: from lighting to the casting of this stellar group of thespians! Heartbreaking, thought-provoking and raw!Anthony Hopkins' best so far! Really resonated here as no strangers to dementia and/or alzheimer's disease. Getting it (BluRay) for Father's Day the same month as your 50th: priceless!

Anthony Hopkins....a truly unbelievable performance - I believe, one of the best performances of all time. The final scene absolutely devastated me and I'll probably be thinking about it for weeks.The structure of the film is also incredibly clever and added to the unbearable tragedy and terrifying nature of this subject matter.

Those who have or have had close experiences with relatives who suffer from senile dementia or Alzheimer's will find in this film a very moving story. For those who do not, they could also fall into the sensitivity presented by the masterful role of Anthony Hopkins.However, when the story is already set, it could be a little bit slow and predictable.Nominated for 6 Oscars, including Best Actor and Best Picture, "The Father" bears some resemblance to another great film, "Still Alice" (2014) starring the great and only Julianne Moore, who actually won the Oscar that year for best actress.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Understanding Alzheimers from the Patient's Perspective.
reviews.content: A movie shot from the perspective of an elderly gentleman experiencing Alzheimers.I enjoyed this movie more than I thought I would. I found it sad at times (especially the ending), but it plays out more like a mystery - keeping me intrigued the whole time.I think this is an excellent movie for anyone wanting to understand Alzherimers from the perspective of someone suffering with it. This film does well at demonstrating how a person experiencing this ailment is rationally behaving and trying to understand the world around them.

reviews.review_title: A movie which deserves all awards
reviews.content: This movie is amazing from the very beginning till the very end. The subject is so important nowadays and you cannot choose any better way to show the relationships between an old and ill man and his daughter who has to both take care of her dad and continue living her life. All scenes are so true and actors' performance is just astonishing. I wish there were more movies like that.

reviews.review_title: Won't be Dry Eyes for Long
reviews.content: Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) has Dementia and cannot understand why things are not the same and becomes confused all the time. He gets rid of Caretakers because he doesn't like them. His daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) takes care of him, but needs to have him put into a home where she can live her life and he will be, hopefully, happy there.In the beginning we believe everything we see and hear according to Anthony's way of seeing things. Takes a few minutes for us to realize there are things we cannot really see or hear. Because Mr. Hopkins is what he is even when in Anthony's character, who has Dementia, the way he sees and says things we believe him. After a while we realize our mistake and we have to keep fighting this belief.Notables: Rufus Sewell as Paul, Anne's former husband who Anthony sees as real and, who tells Paul that Anne will move to Paris to be with another man and Paul tells Anthony that he, knows nothing about Paris and that Anthony is living in Paul's flat, but Anthony still believes he is in his own flat; Mark Gatiss as Bill, Anne's current husband, who asks Anthony how long will he (Anthony) live off Anne; and later Bill tells Anne that Anthony should be in a home for others to care for him; Imogene Poots as Laura, the only Caretaker Anthony likes and misses when she is no longer there and Anthony sees another woman who calls herself that Laura; Olivia Williams as Catherine, as the Nurse at the Nursing Home, who simulates Anthony's mother in the way she soothes Anthony, And there is a scene where Olivia Williams plays Anthony's daughter Anne, and Anthony does not recognize the difference. See? Will you notice?Some of the scenes are confusing, but all will straighten out in time. I am still not sure if Anne is actually married to Bill or not. I do kind of wish Mr. Hopkin's character was not named Anthony for obvious reasons.This is very sad, tragic, heart wrenching and we are at a loss like Anthony because no matter what Caretakers do, it's really not enough. As we watch this, we not only see a confused Anthony and his daughter Anne who fights back tears all the time, we think of the many families out there who have the same or similar problems with a loved family member and feel helpless.Anthony Hopkins received the Oscar for Best Actor Award for this story. For a while I thought that almost any actor could perform the job as good as anyone else, but I was wrong. This time Anthony Hopkins brought something else to the story - a kind of new dimension - and I felt as though he was my family member and I was as helpless as we saw Anne helplessly deal with everything.This was probably the best performance ever by Mr. Anthony Hopkins. Multiple Kudos. (10/10)Violence: No.Sex: No.Nudity: No.Humor: Kinda. There are some good lines by Mr. Hopkins as Anthony.Language: Yes, but only 2-times.Rating: A.

Anthony, 80 years old, rejects all the caregivers his daughter, Anne, hires to help him, leading her to exhaustion.There are films that are good, others that are really good, and then there is a very restricted selection where The Father is in.Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are two colossus, of those who do not need awards to be recognized.The aspect of continuity in this film is at a level that I don't remember seeing in a long time, being almost perfect from start to finish.The cinematography is really smart, confusing everything and everyone, with transitions between scenarios and characters that leave the viewer with doubt and not knowing what to believe.It's real, emotional, rational, in the midst of the irrationality of dementia, it's a desolate chaos that plants doubt and suspicion, and exposes the vulnerability and the absence, while present, of a person who is lost between memories and suffering.

reviews.review_title: Important issue but upper class view of solutions
reviews.content: Great acting and engaging story but an absolutely class-based depiction of dementia as a challenge for individuals, families and health systems. This is a highly sanitised upper class private health care view of dementia care. Having lived through my grandfather and father-in-law dying of dementia and working as a GP in Australia in a disadvantaged community I can tell you the choices and options facing most families are much more acute and problematic than this. This is a well acted sanitised upper class view of dementia as a community anc health system problem.

reviews.review_title: Original take on a daunting topic
reviews.content: This was the last movie I saw from the main Oscar categories and I was very surprised, I knew what the movie would be about but I wasn't expecting how the director would tackle it.It's a story about how dementia affects a relationship between a father and his daughter, but what makes it original is how we are presented the story, we see the movie as if we were in the mind of Anthony Hopkins and how scary the distortion of reality can be when you suffer from such an awful disease.It's both scary and fantastic in terms of how we the spectator have the chance to experience the downward journey of someone who starts to lose sense of what's around him.It has brilliant performances as you would expect and indeed I haven't seen Hopkins do such an amazing job for a long time, it was for sure one of the best performances of the Oscars this year, I would put it side to side with Boseman's but its definitely a class act!

reviews.review_title: Now we have the real thing
reviews.content: Hopkins is a brilliant actor. His performance might have worked very well for a stage performance. Here it comes across as overacting.And let's face it, while it might have seemed like a good idea in 2020 to make a movie about a confused old man, now we have Biden on TV each day.Give the Ocsar to Sir Anthony, but not one for the movie.

reviews.review_title: A confusing but ultimately enlightening look into Alzheimer's.
reviews.content: The failing mental health of an elderly parent is a perennial topic for critically-acclaimed movies. Most of the time, the focus is on how their supportive family watches them steadily deteriorate until they can do nothing else. The Father (2020) is one such film, but with a unique twist that makes it hit a lot harder than the standard Alzheimers fare. While attempting to present this disease from the aging parent's perspective is a bold choice, The Father leans into some radically artistic choices that might leave some viewers more confused than enlightened. I'm trying to avoid discussing the avant-garde method The Father uses to induce the kind of confusion that comes with Alzheimer's, mostly because I don't want to spoil the effect for anyone who hasn't seen this film yet. Needless to say, things make sense...eventually. The point isn't to understand it; it's to empathize with the main character. Of course, with the current era being what it is, even this fails to break through the dislike of the entitled, old white guy who ends up making things difficult for everyone around him. Anthony Hopkins certainly nails this role (especially at the end), and all the supporting characters are equally as strong in their performances. It's just that the role of an elderly white man is played almost too well. The stubbornness that Hopkins' character exudes is so frustrating as to make him entirely unsympathetic. If anything, I almost relate more to Paul (Rufus Sewell), who sees the detrimental effect Anthony is having on his daughter, Anne (Olivia Colman). I can only hope that I don't suffer from the same stubbornness when I get to the age where my mind is failing because it is not a good look on anyone. A confusing but ultimately enlightening look into Alzheimer's, I give The Father 3.5 stars out of 5.

Move over "Suspiria," "The Conjuring" and "Hereditary" - there's a new film that has claimed the title as the scariest movie of the past decade. It's not demons, witches or serial killers that make this new movie scary; it's something that has affected our loved ones and may affect us in the future: dementia."The Father" is a triumphant directorial debut by Florian Zeller, who puts us within the deteriorating mental state of our main character, Anthony. We experience his confusion as if it were our own. The film also takes on the perspective of the caretakers who are left helpless as they try to aid Anthony in making sense of a world he cannot recognize anymore.Zeller's play "The Father" debuted in Paris in 2012 to rapturous reviews. Its success spurred an acclaimed Broadway run with Frank Langella winning a Tony award for his performance. Now Zeller, with the help of esteemed screenwriter Christopher Hampton, has taken his stage play to the screen.At the center of the film playing the character of Anthony is veteran actor Anthony Hopkins (Zeller was so adamant about getting Hopkins for the role that he renamed the character specifically for him).With a nearly 60-year career in the rearview, including notable roles as Hannibal Lecter in "The Silence of the Lambs" and Richard Nixon in Oliver Stone's aptly named "Nixon," Hopkins' performance here may be his very best. He is charismatic, fierce and vulnerable, sometimes all at the same time.If not for Chadwick Boseman's untimely death and larger-than-life performance in "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," Hopkins would be the undisputed favorite to win his second Oscar this year.The world we see is through Anthony's eyes. Initially, his world is quiet and still, often filled with days listening to classical music in his luxurious London flat and taking walks in the nearby park. After a while, however, things slowly start to come apart. He's displacing items more regularly, days are getting harder to separate and conversational details are getting lost in the shuffle.One day, his daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) tells him she's leaving London to go live in Paris with her new significant other. Feeling he's being abandoned, Anthony is hurt by his daughter's decision. The next morning, however, Anthony is still in his flat and has no recollection of Paris.Maybe that conversation happened a long time ago or never happened at all. Maybe this isn't Anthony's flat - maybe it's Anne's and she's taken him in to stay with her. Maybe she has a husband here named James (or is it Paul?) and she's now being played by a different actress than before.Like a Charlie Kaufman or Christopher Nolan film, Zeller plays with time and setting to tell his story. Conversations are repeated several times over from different perspectives, adding another level to the complex task of discerning what is fact and what is fiction.Anthony's physical surroundings seem to be rearranging at impossible speeds and the chronology of events is becoming increasingly muddled. Production designer Peter Francis and editor Yorgos Lamprinos deserve immense credit for their work here as their craftsmanship helps tell a complicated story.The confusion and frustration that Anthony feels are equally placed onto us as we are never sure what is happening and what order it is happening in. It's like watching a balloon being inflated and waiting for it to pop, yet it never does as your anxiety keeps building.It's a terrifying and heartbreaking process to watch as Anthony's mood begins to darken. He never knows what is going to come next and what has just happened. He's left in a perpetual state of fright and feels that everyone is out to get him.Those around him are equally as confused and scared as he is. Anne doesn't know what to do with her father and is fighting a losing battle of keeping an optimistic look at things. Colman, a recent Oscar winner for her role in "The Favourite," acts somewhat as our guide through this mess. Imogen Poots, Olivia Williams, Mark Gatiss and Rufus Sewell all play well-cast supporting roles.Like "Schindler's List" and "Requiem for a Dream," "The Father" is a superb film that you will only want to watch once. Its subject matter may hit too close to home for some viewers or be an introduction for others. No matter your familiarity, the film's take on dementia and the toll it places on everyone involved is so incredibly well done that it demands to be seen.

reviews.review_title: With better direction it would have been more effective
reviews.content: If you are scared of dying or growing old you're going to be very moved by this. If you're very empathetic toward others you're also going to be very moved. If like me, you're a perhaps little more emotionally cold, and watch drama with a sense of detachment, then you're not going to be moved but you will see some very good acting from Anthony Hopkins.This should work for me. Hopkins has always reminded me of my father and my father faced some mental decline toward the end. Parts of it are quite good but what lets it down for me is the script. I know it's an award winning play but so many of the characters around 'The Father' talk to him in unrealistic ways. What they say is not totally unbelievable, but it's not natural either. Even though he's been in decline for a while they all seem surprised every time he forgets something. If you've dealt with this sort of thing, even once, you roll with it. You explain what you need to explain, what you think will get through, and you move on. You don't act all surprised that a man who's losing his memory has forgotten something again.It's somewhat off-putting and serves to remind you that the playwright is making a point rather than an observation.I get that it's mostly from his point of view, but with better direction the actors could have played it with a more realistic world-weariness that comes from dealing with this stuff every day, without seeming like they were trying to explain and reveal things to the audience.It's still a good film and should hold most people's attention to the end. Those who get caught up in the story may miss the obvious clues on the 'twists', but it's not a film where the plot really matters. It's more about creating a sense of empathy. And based on that, and the fact that that aspect of the film failed for me, I can only rate it 5. Which is not to say it's good or bad. It's a solid film. It just didn't personally connect with me.

I saw "The Father", starring Anthony Hopkins-Thor:Ragnarok, The Wolfman_2010; Olivia Colman-The Crown_tv, Hot Fuzz; Rufus Sewell-The Man in the High Castle_tv, Abraham Lincoln:Vampire Hunter and Imogen Poots-Popstar:Never Stop Never Stopping, Need For Speed.
This is an interesting story about a man that is getting older and how he sees things. It's based on a play by Florian Zeller, who also directs this movie. Anthony plays the old man that is living with his daughter, Olivia. Anthony keeps getting things wrong or seeing different versions of what he thinks things should be. For instance, one moment he will see Olivia and then he will turn around for a minute, and then he sees a different girl standing there, claiming to be Olivia. Rufus plays Olivia's husband and Imogen is a caretaker hired to take care of Anthony. Anthony starts believing that Olivia & Rufus are trying to take advantage of him by making him think he is crazy and have him institutionalized-so that they can take his apartment. Anthony's performance is riveting and you feel as if you really don't know what is going on-are they taking advantage of Anthony or does he have Alzheimer's? All is revealed in the end and either way, it is a riveting study of Alzheimer's.
It's rated "PG-13" for language and has a running time of 1 hour & 37 minutes.
It's not one that I would buy on DVD-great performance and all but once was enough-but it would be a good rental.

The Father. An old man with dementia and we learned about his life through his perspective.First of all, the movie was extremely disorienting and confusing. The first half was especially hecka confusing, and the second half filled in some of the pieces.This disorienting and nonlinear story telling was meant to make us see what Anthony Hopkins's character saw, and the director was really good at that aspect. This showed the biggest theme of the movie, which was how sad and anxious life could be for people with dementia. With how sad the story turned out, the story helped me to have a glimpse at the life of many elder people with dementia.And of course the story wouldn't be convincing and powerful without Anthony Hopkins's phenomenal performance as the father. I definitely saw an old man with dementia who tried to maintain his sanity, but slowly lost it. As creepy as Hopkins was in Science of the Lambs, here he was very sad and made us felt for him.Another good performance was from Olivia Colman, who played the daughter. We saw the pain that she went through dealing with the situation, and I again felt bad for her character. This shows another important theme about the effect of the condition on the loved ones around the patient.Overall, a purposefully disorganized plot that showed the negative effect of dementia. 8/10.

reviews.review_title: The Father is now easily in my top three films of the year.
reviews.content: This film is a special reminder of how grand and extraordinary Anthony Hopkins is as an actor.I've seen many films that examines from different angles the subject of mental deterioration such as alzheimer's, but I think that this film portrays with harsh realism the essence of dementia, and how it can damage, hurt and torture a person on a daily basis. And how it can impact his surrounding. Florian Zeller combined his directorial skills and artistic vision with Ben Smithard' steady work of cinematography to bring the senses of confusion and ignorance to the viewer, so that we would feel gradually a pure and sincere connection with the main character. Putting Anthony Hopkins' performance aside, the whole cast from Olivia Colman to Rufus Sewell did a brilliant job.A truly fantastic work that deserves all its awards and nominations this year.

I usually won't watch films about this subject, due to real life. Our family has had to deal with a lot of dementia, genetically, and early onset. So I have avoided the subject for 60yrs.But quality films like this one are extremely difficult to find these days, and I figured Anthony Hopkins would be good for it (didn't know he won an Oscar for it, as I don't keep up with the mostly corrupt awards industry), so I had to give it a go. I was on the edge of my seat from the beginning, and stayed there until the very end. It is the most realistic portrayal of dementia I have ever seen. My dad is stuck on me being 35 (I am 68), so he's in a time machine not in his control. This film brought it very close, and helped me understand my dad's mind.I rarely give a film 10*, but this one is close to being perfect in every way.My favorite Hopkins film/performance is Remains of the Day. But this may be a new one, although much more difficult to re-watch. Hopkins is masterful here, as ever, but he's calling on all of his acting experience to deliver an effortless (seemingly!) performance. Nothing over the top, no melodrama, just one of the best crafted characters I've seen. He has help from a great script, direction, editing, sets, and co-stars, but the focus is Anthony. His character is as broad as it is deep, but so skilled is Hopkins that it seems effortless. I'm very grateful that Hopkins agreed to do this very difficult role, at his age. He could just sit on his laurels now.My age and health, as well as family members, begs many questions about aging and quality of life, which this film inherently, but without stating, highlights. I hope we can find ways for the mind to keep up with the longevity of our bodies, or provide for an acceptable alternative to warehousing our endless last days of confusion.

reviews.review_title: Hopkins' masterclass performances makes it easy to forget some screenplay flaws here and there
reviews.content: "The Father" is a new movie, well from 2020, and a co-production between the United Kingdom and France. The movie runs for under 100 minutes, so not a particularly long film by any means. And yet this was one of the biggest players from the previous awards season. The director is Florian Zeller and his career path can really be described as unusual. He launched his career through stage plays and mostly focused on these as well in recent years, even if here and there he also moved on to movies. So the smallest surprise here is probably that he wrote the screenplay himself. The bigger surprise is that he directed. And he did not have a co-director despite not being experienced at all in this department, but a co-writer. That would be Christopher Hampton and he has been in the industry for a long time and even won an oscar decades ago. Well, he won his second now. This is how successful this film turned out in the end and how audiences, critics and awards bodies loved it. Huge international breakthrough for Zeller too of course and we will see what will be next for him in the future. Certainly promising projects coming up. But as much as Zeller may have achieved behind the camera and with the pen in his hand (metaphorically), the heart and soul of this film was British actor Anthony Hopkins. You see him on the right of the imdb poster of course. He won his second Oscar for his portrayal here and even if he did not go into Oscar night as the frontrunner, not too many neutral observers were unhappy with Hopkins being announced as the winner at the very end, even after the Best Picture winner was announced this time. Hopkins was not there in America, maybe partially because of the pandemic and partially because of his age and the distance, but he recorded a little thank you message the following day if I remember correctly in which he also made a short reference to the late Chadwick Boseman that most people were expecting to win. More on Hopkins later.The woman you see on the left is Olivia Colman of course, already an Oscar winner herself and her win for The Favorite as an against-the-odds upset as well, so kinda fitting. I think she played her part well as she always does, but I don't see huge versatility in her somehow and it feels a bit exaggerated how much awards bodies have loved her in the past. Still she contributed in a way where the film does not get worse when she is on screen and here and there she also has a memorable moment, like the one in the elevator for example with her bright smile after she gets a compliment from her father. That was one of not too many moments where we really saw how much he meant to her and how much she wanted to be loved by him. Despite the violent fantasy. Nice connection to how she in reality(?) takes really good care of him when he is in bed. Another example would be the table argument of course. But as a whole the fact how much she cares for him is also shown to us by all the time where we see them both on the screen, even if they are separated in the end and even if we can never really be sure what is reality and what happens only in Hopkins's character's mind. This is pretty much the key aspect to the script here. I cannot write the mindf... word from beginning to end, but it's all about that. Zeller's main intention here was definitely to make us see things the way they are seen from the perspective of an old man whose memory and sanity are fading quickly. We also see all the emotions he goes through in the process. Be it him joking around before becoming very serious seconds alter (the tap dance scene), be it him saying he is an intelligent man and how he does not want to be treated like a fool. The nun reference there also felt a bit random. But also those moments in which he is as vulnerable as it gets. When he is physically attacked, slapped, though (probably) only in his imagination, or when he, near the very end, compares himself to a tree basically and realizes how he is fading basically. These are all moments in which Hopkins truly shines.As for all the inclusions that do so much with your mind, I will also mention a few examples: Of course, the recurring watch references come to mind. But also the painting from the wall. All the references to his other daughter and how he sees her a bit in a new applicant. Or actually sees her a lot and how confused he is when he sees the other woman near the end. Then there is this loop scene which I also found fairly haunting to be honest when we have his daughter and her man talk about him and how he enters the room when they do. Would they really talk that loudly and even scream immediately afterwards with him not too far away? Anyway, this scene closes with him not taking his seat the way he did before, but going back to his room. By the way, in the trailer this film seemed to be much more about the apartment, but it turned out completely differently. The only thing related to reality clashing with an old mind was maybe when we saw the other daughter (let's call her that) briefly on one occasion. There are many more moments really I could list here, but I don't want to take it away from you if you have not seen the film yet. Or also not take it away from you to draw your own conclusions. I must say that in the second half, I felt it became a bit too much honestly with how everything gets blurry and not too close to reality anymore. For example the scene towards the end (but still a bit earlier and away fro the closing credits) when we see Hopkins' character alone all on his own at an utterly cold and sterile retirement home. This of course gave us in the audience immediately the idea that this is where he was all along, that maybe Colman's character never really existed, but then things take another turn and twist. One after the other. I don't know, maybe I like it more if I watch it again, but I thought that perhaps Zeller wanted a bit too much here. Had almost Nolan proportions with stuff like Inception, only as a full-on family drama.Aside from that, I think this is a pretty interesting project also as a stage play and I would not be surprised if we see it one day at non-movie theaters. Surely a challenge with some characters, even if it's not that many, and also the changing locations of course. I see that Zeller turned this into a film already in France years ago. Interesting. This seems almost lost though judging from the amiunt of votes here on imdb. But back to this one here: By the way, when Colman's character leaves in the end it felt like closure and a framework compared to how she entered the movie. But the film ends with Hopkins' character of course and a beautiful shot of the nature outside his new home. Fitting really. This seems like a film really close to his heart. The birthday his character states is his own in fact and he may be healthier in terms of his mental state, but also his character's name is Anthony. A bit of an irony if we take a look at another Oscar-winning movie, namely Nomadland, and how there everybody has their real name except the protagonist, even if it is not too different either. Let's sta with this one here for now though. What else can you say? Oh yes, Imogen poots is always a nice inclusion, not just for a hetero male like myself, but also acting-wise. Very nice. This also applies to the rest of the cast, especially Sewell and Gatiss who held their own next to Hopkins (and Colman) and this is a really huge achievement I'd say. No matter if it was two scenes or ten.All in all, this movie gets a thumbs-up with no hesitation, even if I somehow feel that I did not like the outcome overall as much as I would have liked and some of the awards recognition is also too much, especially for the screenplay. I felt that it even took away a bit from the emotional component because the fictitious aspects (and how we cannot be sure what's happening at all the longer the movie goes) made it a bit less depressing. For me at least. Difficult to really put a finger on it. I wonder how I will think about that on rewatch, but I have no intention really to go for a rewatch anytime soon. Who knows, maybe once it is on television. This is not a visual masterpiece, so it's not much of a worse watch on the small screen than at a movie theater where I saw it today I believe. The music I did not like too much, but that is of course entirely subjective. High-pitched opera is smply not my thing. But of course it makes sense that the character likes it with his age. They could not have gone for modern pop music or something and it also fits from the cultivated perspective if we look at his really fancy apartment and fairly exquisite alcoholic beverages you see here and there. What will always stay the most with this one here though is how Hopkins turned solid scenes into something exquisite at times. Great props to him and it will take quite some time to find a better performance by somebody in his 80s. May he lives for many more years to come and maybe also give us a few more nice films hopefully. Or just enjoy retirement. Whatever floats his boat the most. Thank you, Mr Hopkins!

reviews.review_title: Sir Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are Sublime
reviews.content: Sir Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are sublime in "The Father," co-written and directed by Florian Zeller based on his Play. The moments of quiet in this film, particularly at the end, are as powerful and significant to the story as the heart-wrenching, emotionally effective performances from the cast.

Anthony Hopkins... what an actor my goodness!! He's...I can't even explain how great an actor he is. And Olivia was flawless. The entire movie, the sequence, the presentation just amazing!Couldn't be better!He deserved the Oscar.Best performance of him after The Silence of the lambs which also is my absolute favourite!

Having lost my mother after a long illness, and her father before her to Alzheimer's, I knew this movie would be emotional for me. Even though he has been my all-time favorite actor, Sir Anthony Hopkins surprised me. I cried twice during the film. If ever there was an Oscar-worthy performance, this was it. I'll never forget it as long as I live. Unless, perhaps, I get dementia someday. I've worried about that ever since my grandfather died. 10/10.

I've never left a review on IMDb and may never do so again, but felt compelled to do so for this film.Sir Antony Hopkins delivers a performance of such power and subtelty that it is hard to bring to mind anything better. reviews.review_title: A beautiful representation of love and loss through the devastation of progressive dementia
reviews.content: I am both a nurse and the daughter of someone with dementia and the portrayal by the central characters resonated with me; the frustration, the fear and the anger experienced when facing the impact of this illness is something which is not fictional but factual for so many people. Watching someone,s personality, intelligence and memories fade is horrific to witness and if you are part of those fading memories, the pain and hurt of Olivia Colmans performance is real. Hopkins acts the ever changing mood and behaviours which not only is terrifying for those with dementia but for those who try to hold on to the love they have for the person they used to be. The decision to hand over the care of that person as they are now to complete strangers and an unfamiliar environment if far from easy but is often necessary as the conflict between loving and loyalty gives way to accepting that without doing so, risks sacrificing what time and happiness you have.This is a film, alongside Amour should be part of any curriculum for those studying for a career in caring, whether that be medicine, nursing or social care. A beautiful and emotionally charged film for all the right reasons leaving you with the permission to weep for the past, present and future.

First off - it's the best acted film I've ever seen. Across the board. Just sensational. And yes, it's Hopkins' greatest ever screen performance by some distance - and with his stellar body of work - that's some statement, and subsequently some performance. Holy Cow. Delighted for him and his win, the most deserving of my lifetime I think.Beyond the acting, though - we have one of the most powerful and important films ever made. It's the best debut I've ever seen. It's the saddest film I've ever seen, but I've seen it 3 times. I can't stop thinking about it.As with every awards season, I check out all the major contenders. This should have won everything. Nothing was better, and it was a pretty bloody strong year.For me? This could be the best film of the century so far.

It has been a long time since I have seen a movie with this caliber. The acting is truly superb with each of the actors and actresses. The way "reality" is depicted for a person descending into the depths of dementia is frighteningly accurate. Everything was executed beautifully. I believe that it is extremely important for everyone in the healthcare industry, for family, friends, church, and community members to see this. As one who is assisting in the care of a loved one with dementia, it is so very important to be patient and also to not show a surprised expression to common odd behaviors or comments, which can alarm and shame the one who is ill. The acting is exceptional, the subject matter is important but also heartbreaking.The film is shot basically from the POV of Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) a dementia sufferer who struggles to decipher what is happening. This is a clever way of directing the film and certainly helps the watcher to understand more of what it is like to suffer like this. Anthony Hopkins is brilliant in the role and really hammers home the emotional impact (the ending is truly heart breaking).Ultimately the fact that the film is all seen from Anthony's point of view, is also the reason my review is so low, i found it confusing to follow and although you can piece together the real truth by the end it just wasn't to my taste.(Please don't think the score is a judgement on how well made the film is)
As a 77 year-old man, I found this film to be the most depressing, scariest film I've ever seen; rivals 1951's The Thing From Another world, when I ran out of the theatre.

reviews.review_title: Anthony Hopkins is devastating in Florian Zeller's exploration of dementia
reviews.content: Dementia is an awful disorder, and it's every child's nightmare to have to watch their parent deteriorate and disappear right before their eyes. Florian Zeller manages to capture this experience magnificently here in this film adaptation of the play Le Père which he co-wrote with fellow playwright Christopher Hampton.Anthony Hopkins is everything in this film - funny, charming and also utterly heart-breaking - he completely deserves his Oscar win after putting in what will surely be remembered as one of his all time great performances. The way we enter his seemingly coherent mind and reality only to watch it gradually unravel until he is left as a broken man unsure of his own existence is stunning. Praise also has to be reserved for Olivia Colman who has to portray the daughter having to watch her father go through this nightmare. Some of her best work is done when she is not speaking, but instead letting her face do the talking. She could have easily won a second Oscar for her role here.The original score from Ludovico Einaudi is also great (but I love everything that man does) and I liked the use of the set design to illustrate the subtle differences in the constantly shifting and changing reality we inhabit for those 97 minutes.The entire screening was completely stunned into silence as the credits started rolling, as everyone was trying to come to terms with what we had just seen. This may prove to be one of the finest film experiences I'll have this year.
