reviews.review_title: This is a worst-case scenario - it's possible to live well with dementia for years
reviews.content: As good as this was, what was missing for me was an acknowledgement that what we're seeing is advanced dementia, and particularly severe at that - someone who is not just frightened, confused and forgetful, but paranoid, aggressive and suspicious. The film perfectly captures what the final 6 weeks with my dad were like before he went into care, and how he often continued to behave while in care. It also conveys how frightening a large aggressive man with dementia can be to those trying to care for him, as well as the terror of alienation when a loved one with dementia turns against you. As a couple of other reviewers have commented, most of the characters don't handle the man's condition well and act in ways that make him more agitated - the fact that even experienced care professionals are shown repeatedly asking him "What do you mean?" and "Do you remember?", and being surprised that he forgets things even when his condition is clearly severe, simply isn't realistic and is used to artificially drive the point home. There's no sense that his family and carers have acclimatised to the situation and learned to modify their behavior, when in fact that's one of the first things that happens when you have a loved one with dementia.Because the film is designed as an immersive experience from the perspective of someone highly agitated with severe dementia, what's missing are all the moments of joy and love in between. There's no recognition in the film that many people have much gentler manifestations of dementia, and can live for years with dementia with a good quality of life. This film will terrify people and generate huge fear around dementia, and I really want to emphasise that although many psychological and behavioral aspects ring true, it represents an extreme scenario (one more reminiscent of Lewy Body dementia than Alzheimer's) and that having dementia doesn't have to be like this. I know people with dementia who still actively pursue and enjoy their hobbies and who have put all kinds of practical coping strategies in place (either independently or with their family's support) to ensure they can carry out their daily activities safely. I know people who have had dementia for many years, whose short-term memory is completely shot and who are reliant on others for help with certain tasks, but who can still cook, garden, read, do puzzles, follow politics and current affairs, engage with friends and family, and generally take an interest in the world - and who enjoy their day almost every day. That's what dementia can be too, and what it is for many, not just an unremitting horror show. Please don't think it has to be this bad, at least not all the time.

reviews.review_title: A Disjointed Delve into the Demons of Dementia
reviews.content: Imagine Memento with the power of Anthony Hopkins as the lead. Now swap the rare condition in Memento, amnesia, with a disease that will affect 1 in 6 people over the age of 80. The result is The Father, a film as entertaining as Memento, but one that really hits home.The Father is a whirlwind thriller that brings attention to dementia in a whole new way. This mental head-spinner is one of the best films I can remember!

My mother suffered from dementia for her final years. The outsider looking into her life, her behaviour, would have seen something like what this movie portrays. What sets this film apart, of course, is that we never -- not ever -- could know what was going on inside my mother's head, while the film imagines it brilliantly.At first, it seemed as if this would be *just another* cinematic effort to deal with this awful illness, and there have been so many. But I don't remember any one of them triggering such empathy. Wow. And full marks too, to all carers, whether within the family or professionals. Really a very, very moving film experience.

The film shows the pure confusion and helplessness that must be felt by those with dementia. The way the set changes and then the faces and people change leaves you questioning which bit is real and which a dilusion.It's difficult to find fault is the way this film is set up and Anthony Hopkins acting, it really is a masterclass. Just at the end when everything falls into focus the pure vulnerability of his character is shown and the despair. The cynical way he is treated by his daughters husband shows the lack of time and patiance we tend to have and the kindness shown by the nurse at the end also highlights the patience and skill needed to truly look after those with dementia.From what I know of dementia I'd say this was the most accurate portrayal I have ever seen and he certainly deserved his Oscar.

BEST BEST BEST. Made me cry so hard! Anthony Hopkins is the Best actor of all time.

reviews.review_title: It's a tough watch, for sure.
reviews.content: Hopkins is an extraordinary talent. It's great to see him in this complex character. Undoubtedly, this movie is unforgettable for me.

It makes audience understand about dementia from this movie. I get confuse in the beginning and turn into sad and attached mode while watching. It's how people suffer dementia. The acting is top notch and Oscar of leading role should go Anthony.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant film with an amazing performance
reviews.content: On the one hand I feel like I want to list The Father as one of the rare movies that I respect greatly but never want to watch again. However, the style of the storytelling is so inventive and different that I find myself thinking about it a lot and wondering if I should take a chance watching it again, so I can explore how they pulled it off. It's truly astounding how this movie allows the viewer to feel a bit like a person who is actually suffering from dementia. I watched for several years as my own grandfather suffered through this condition, and the movie perfectly nailed the way he could swing from totally lucid to utterly confused in a matter of moments. I always imagined it all made sense in his head, even though it was often nonsense to us. Anthony Hopkins deserves all the awards for this performance because he goes through so much emotionally in this movie and all of it felt right.If I were to complain about anything when it comes to The Father (aside from the fact that it is about a subject which is hard to watch) it would be that sometimes the way the story is told feels too smart for its own good. Getting things that happened in the past confused with the present is realistic for the main character, but when he starts mixing things he wouldn't experience until the future into his present circumstances that didn't make sense. However, it still worked for me because it muddled things enough for the audience so we were in the shoes of the protagonist. I genuinely found myself afraid when he was left alone because I knew that another disorienting change could hit him in a matter of moments. The Father is a great film that is only hard to recommend because not everyone can emotionally handle this kind of story, since it feels so authentic.

reviews.review_title: Moving, intense and deeply authentic drama
reviews.content: Clearly, the portrayal is an economically privileged former white-collar professional. Nevertheless, this film delivers in terms of emotional depth and intensity. What makes The Father different from other films that deal with the diseases like dementia is that it doesn't just focus on the experience of family members. It is centred on the sufferer of dementia, which is very believable and at no point feel forced or saccharine. The emotions within the film are wideranging. There are some warm-hearted, even funny parts to Anthony's character, punctuated by the sadness in learning that he is unable to control the ability to discern the real from the figments created by his disease. While the film deals with a very uncomfortable topic it is worth every bit of viewing time and reminds us that we need to treat people who suffer from this terrible disease humanely.

My Rating : 8/10Well, I really loved this film. The way the story is told is refreshing and keeps the viewer guessing - you will know when you watch it!I'm sure this will touch many hearts, it's a drama which really gives you something to feel.Go ahead, seek it out!

This really surprised me. Rather more than just about a family trying to care for the needs of a loved one with dementia, it really goes some way to offer some idea about what that could be like for some people. It's actually quite a difficult movie to watch, remarkably draining, in it's approach. I don't want to say too much more, would only serve to spoil it, though the trailer gives some idea about it's approach in this regard.It would be interesting to watch again, in that I'll know what I'm in for, but going in somewhat blind, as I did the first time, I found it strangely unsettling! Nothing horrible in it, there's just something about it...I would be surprised if it doesn't do very well at the Oscars, in one way or another.

reviews.review_title: A person's point of view struggling with Dementia
reviews.content:
I got emotional throughout the movie, I've seen my grandfather at the same situation and I honestly can understand how these people's families may feel while taking care of their father or mother that are losing their mind, it's potentially sad and horrifying to see that your dad or mom no longer recognizes you and does strange things and suddenly starts to talk about something from their deep mind and their past that you have no clue what they're saying; but the fact is that none of us have ever realized what life would be like from the point of view of the person struggling with memory loss; and here in "The Father" movie you can completely relate to this...Sir "Anthony Hopkins" acting in this role is fantastic, he really deserves his Oscar for his performance!The confusion of time, recognition of family and other people and at the same time understanding the fact that something is not right here and every now and then realizing that nothing is at it's right place as you have thought that it should be, while you understand your environment and you may feel healthy but your mind is going off, makes this illness thousand times more horrific and sad...I remember once I heard a quote saying: "When human being gets old, they become a kid again..."
and you can see that in Anthony's(the character) behaviors...
The film confuses you till near end in all the scenes, because that's how mind loss and Alzheimer is like if you put yourself inside the person struggling with it...It was a really great and stunning movie and personally I loved it so much and got emotional and tearful at the most of it...Cycle of life is really wild and sad when it gets to one's near end...
I hope scientists find a cure for all sorts of Dementia, Specially Alzheimer and memory loss and no human being experience them any more...

Having had a Mum battle Alzheimer's for 9 years and nursed my Dad in covid times I can hand on heart say how utterly close to reality this film is .Especially the turmoil for the Daughter .The end scene for reminded me of my Dad's last weeks, and I imagine many others will relate to this while in tears watching it.The changes of people , plans , recalling memories took some getting used to but sum up life with old age and Alzheimer's.Brilliant.

Really - unbelievable. Beautiful. Compelling. Within a few minutes I could already see why he won the Oscar (last night!). It does all become clear in the end, I think, although I might just watch it again to be sure. Olivia Colman is lovely, as always, so emotive... Really, a terrific film - just phenomenal, particularly because of Mr. Hopkins.
This will stay with me for a long time. My mum had dementia and Anthony Hopkins absolutely got it. May be his strongest performance ever. Totally mesmerising.

A film where you never really feel settled, but that's the point of you're going to be transported into the perspective of a dementia patient. Dementia is a cruel illness and the film deals well with the issues many families face whilst trying to support loved ones. The director does an excellent job balancing the perspectivesThe wider cast are very good but the performance they take the lead from is Anthony Hopkins. I've enjoyed Hopkins career, he's an actor capable of so much depth & subtlety. In this role every ounce of Hopkins talent fills the screen. It's such a powerful performance it stands out as one his finest. There's a scene early in the film where Hopkins character meets a prospective carer, I was nailed to the edge of my seat. It's a heavy film but a must watch.

reviews.review_title: Saw this movie weeks ago with relatives. Remembered it again and decided to finally write a review.
reviews.content: "The Father" is nothing short of a heartbreaking film, about an elderly man suffering from dementia. Throughout the film, you are shown the perspective of Anthony, the dementia patient with characters appearing and disappearing (e.g. His son-in-law) not to mention dialogue that contradicts what was said before (e.g. His daughter denying that she was going to move to Paris despite her saying that she would earlier in the film). This creates confusion in the audience, which is the intended effect. I think this movie is a great way of showing people what dementia is like and just how horrible it can be.As for negatives, I honestly can't think of any. The performances were all brilliant (especially Anthony Hopkins'), the cinematography, editing, music etc. All fit together really nicely to create an immersive, unforgettable, and saddening experience.So, to conclude, watch this movie if you're fine with watching an extremely well-made yet depressing movie that you won't forget any time soon.

Anthony is an intelligent man in his early 80s, who is slowly descending into the twilight world of dementia. We see events from his perspective, which means a Kafkaesque, nightmarish world in which people switch identity, and even his own flat alters its appearance. The only downside of this approach is that we are never sure whether the conversations he experiences have ever happened, or may be memories of past events, or with other people. Anthony Hopkins is an excellent actor, who conveys the part with great depth and conviction. Don't expect a happy ending, though.

Fantastic movie.According to my girlfriend who works for so many years with people with dementia, this is as close as it can get...
Beautiful! Worth 2 Oscars.

Anthony Hopkins, take a bow! This is the best hes been in years. The film is beautifully shot, it really conveys a sense of place and the direction keeps everything ticking along nicely.You can't help but become invested in the father character and try to unravel events as they happen. The movie is paced well and never drags. The score is on point, and the films climax brings a lot of emotion - its a truly thoughtful and relatable piece of cinema that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

reviews.review_title: The first (new) film in quite a while to make me tear up
reviews.content: We don't just lose our memories when our brains deteriorate. Sometimes memories are corrupted; misplaced. Sometimes they appear to get repeated. In any case, we lose our ability to perceive the world - and our very lives - as we once did.We can discuss the existential implication of the way our minds operate another time (I have a friend who believes the human brain could be rewired to perceive time nonlinearly but still be considered functional, though I would have some questions on logistics and semantics there). I'm only here to tell you about The Father, one of the best films of this year's #KeepingUpWithTheOscars marathon and one of the most moving portrayals of dementia since Haneke's Amour (2012). Notably, this one lets us see things from the dementia patient's point of view.This is the first film Florian Zeller has directed, although it is based on a similarly named stage play of his. Sometimes (as with Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, another multi-category Oscar nominee, from the same playwright as 2016's Fences), this can be almost too obvious; the scenery rarely changes and not much "happens", per se.But The Father has nightmarish sequences worthy of Kaufman's I'm Thinking of Ending Things. I don't know how some of these scenes must have looked on a live stage, but they might've made me forget I was watching real people perform with little-to-no magic involved. It's hard for any of us to remember going to live shows in general, but you know what I mean.Anthony Hopkins gives what's possibly his finest performance since Hannibal Lecter, in the role of a British geezer named Anthony (perhaps indicating that Hopkins himself is beginning to muse on these things). But instead of a menacing force of evil, this is a character we all recognize too well from real life; a stubborn old goat who's certain he doesn't need any help, even as he begins to lose track of his recent memories, and soon also distant ones.Time is played around with in other ways throughout the film, but I dare not reveal too much. I can tell you that Anthony's daughter, played by the always-phenomenal Olivia Colman, begins to appear to him with different faces, different life plans, and even different husbands. Sometimes he doesn't remember the faces he's shown; sometimes he remembers them from the wrong places. The plot makes us wonder if someone is messing with him; gaslighting him until he must be dumped in a nursing home to live out his deterioration in solitude.People often wonder, what's even the point of a film like The Father? These days especially, surely escapist entertainment or something hopeful is what we need? This, to me, indicates a narrow understanding of film, presuming that filmmakers must never make films for themselves; that their duty is always to entertain, instead of translating their thoughts and worries into an artistic expression.Films like that aren't always fun, I agree. But The Father is legitimately powerful and clever in its presentation - and for some of us (especially if we're currently going through something eerily similar to what's being explored), watching a movie like it is a reminder that there are people out there who understand. It's not an Avengers sequel, but I assure you those are still around.

As someone who has a relative that is suffering with this horrendous illness, and a relative that succumbed to it many years ago, this hit really close to home.It's heartbreaking and so realistic. It was such a hard watch. But an utter masterpiece!

Florian Zeller's first job as director manages to move by capturing the story of Anthony, an old man being little by little consumed by dementia accompanied by the help of his daughter who does what she can in this vulnerable situation for both of them.First of all, the choice of how we see the film from Anthony's perspective makes it confusing at first for the viewer since it is not possible to differentiate the plane from reality, but when you realize that it is intentional it is a tool that you achieve. Empathize much more with the character and the pain is shared. It is a script that, as I said at the beginning, confuses but achieves emotions with the situation and with the main character, for my taste I prefer something more linear but I admit that it convinces and captivates.The color palette is magnificent, everything accompanies the scenes and vibes of the characters.Anthony Hopkins is not surprising, he is simply the acting beast that we are used to. Every time it generates more pain to see him and his face of not understanding and not knowing why, the final scene of him asking for his mother destroys you, 10 points.However, on the side of Olivia Colman I left much to be desired, I do not know if it was the expectations for what was said or that but her character did not reach me, I feel that I achieve emotions but not to the maximum, each scene that appeared a break for know more about her character, it was cut. I did not finish meeting that daughter with so much pain, I do not know if it was the script that failed to highlight her character or the linear interpretation of Colman that left me nothing but a neat performance.

reviews.review_title: Sir Anthony Hopkins will get the Oscar or no one will
reviews.content: This movie needs to win "Best Picture" and "Best Actors" this Sunday at the Oscars.The script, the actors, the simplicity of the settings, the directing...everything is on point.The quality of the film is so rare, it just has to be showered in awards.Not to give anything away: Sir Anthony Hopkins is already one of the best actors alive, and this is one of his beyond fantastic performances.

reviews.review_title: What an insight into what dementia is like
reviews.content: 2 of the best actors of our time portray a very emotional and powerful story about not only dealing with a family member with the illness but how the man with the illness perceives reality himself. Heart wrenching and a must see.

reviews.review_title: We all should know how serious it is.
reviews.content: Except I don't appreciate the music being too heavy, it definitely worths your watching. You'll have the idea of what dementia is and how you probably should do to deal with it or to face it yourself.

Normally I'm wary of the films that attract Oscar nominations or wins as they're normally arty films aimed at Hollywood big wigs who aren't in touch with the real world.Thank god I decided to go against that and watch this film. It is wonderful, heart warming and gripping. Acted superbly by all especially Hopkins and Colman.You have to watch this film but make sure you have your tissues ready as you'll be in floods for the last half hour.
I've never given a 10 rating. What else is there to say except.... what are you doing in my flat?
Movie is good, but not great, but his acting... Anthony Masterpiece Hopkins! Oscar award apsolutely deserved!

reviews.review_title: You Should See It Twice, and That's The Problem
reviews.content: This movie confuses the heck out of you and you can't really figure out what it's supposed to be about until it's almost over. So in theory you should watch it once to get an idea of what it's about then watch it again to appreciate the fine acting. The only problem is that it's not interesting enough to watch twice. Sure, there may be some great acting performances but great acting does not a great movie make. Somebody could play the perfect performance as Hamlet, for instance, but if he's playing to an audience that doesn't like Shakespeare nobody is going to care how great his performance is. And that's the problem with The Father. A lot of people will go to see it just based on the name of the stars but most of them won't want to stick around to figure out what it was supposed to be about. My wife's mother had Dementia and her brother cared for her by himself and eventually with a carer for years before she died, so they might empathize with it. People who haven't experienced that will just see a confusing mess.

What I appreciate most about The Father is the choice of narrator - who is telling the story? This leads to the questions: How sane are they? How confident are they in this? And how confident should we be that this is true?The film progresses with a sense of temporal dysphoria. People come and go, disappear, change names, change faces, change attitudes, and sometimes, events completely contradict one another. However, our character remains confident in his sanity, and instead reacts to this seemingly changing world with hostility, some of which falls on his own daughter.This is a powerful example of how changing the reference frame from which a story is told can paint a clearer picture. Often, we watch mentally unstable characters through the eyes of others, and in our minds, create the association that that character is very odd, in comparison with our narrator, the other person. If we instead tell the story from the point of view of that so-called mentally unstable person, then they are completely sane, yet almost the entire world around them is incomprehensibly peculiar. Which of the two stories do you think emphasises the extent of the psychological disorder? In the case of The Father, it is by far the latter.The movie ends with a touching soliloquy, which probably secured Hopkins his Oscar for the performance. "I feel as if I'm losing my leaves" he cries, as he begs for his mother - as a man in his 80s. In the end, our character finally admitted that he was ill, and for a brief moment before the end, things seemed normal. We can hope that he came to terms with himself, and found some sense of peace, in the days he had left on this Earth.

What a unique film. Told out of a unique perspective with a unique direction and way of storytelling. It is confusing but that is exactly the state of mind of the main character. We see the entire film out of his perspective. Just like him we are lost in the twilight zone between reality, memories, misinterpretation and fantasy. There is no straight line in this film and this is exactly how a person suffering from dementia must experience the world around him. In this way the film is perfect and it is something we never saw before. Another aspect which makes the film perfect are the performances. First of all you have heavy weight actor Anthony Hopkins playing the role of the protagonist. It is amazing how Hopkins portrays this role. The switch between all kind of different emotions that all feel so real and natural. He perfectly let me enter the mind of his character and you felt with him. It was like watching a real person. Hopkins is fantastic. Many say its his best since "The Silence of the Lambs". I am saying it is his best performance. Period.Olivia Colman was also wonderful, Not sure if she is supporting, its definitely borderline. But nevertheless its a very heartbreaking performance of a daughter who looks for the right solution and who is caring but that care is not recognized nor is it appreciated nor is it understood. Its a helpless situation her character finds herself in and Colman wonderfully brought that helplessness on screen in just the same believable way. Watching both brilliant actors shooting their acting weapons at each other is just a phenomenon of itself.The whole ensemble is fantastic. Notable mentions especially to Oliver Williams who is very underrated for her role but especially in the last third she really captures the screen with her tenderness. Great job. The direction is perfect. The way the film is set up is not an easy task to portray such a realistic confusion and transmit it to the audience surely isn't either. Great screenplay, editing and soundtrack. A very intimate movie that is important to be seen.

reviews.review_title: A Tour de Force in Acting!
reviews.content: What a beautiful evocative film.The writers took a very difficult subject matter and produced a very sensitive story that so many of us have/ will experience in one way or another .Personally my father also suffered from dementia and it is a heart wrenching disease for both the person suffering and the family and the writers managed to convey this so well in a limited amount of time.The choice of cast was superb Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman were both outstanding and delivered a masterclass performance .The film took me back to the days when I cared for my father I watched with tears in my eyes.

If I'm honest I didn't want to watch this movie. I'm an action fan, people blowing stuff up car chases loud noises that kinda thing. This was my wife's choice and as I'm a good husband I dutifully went along. And I'm so glad I did. All of the performances were spot on. Olivia Colman never lets me down in anything she's done and her performance as Anne is fantastic. But the real star and rightly so is Sir Anthony Hopkins. His performance as the titular Father is just magnificent. The film itself is at times so moving and at others so hard but it kept me guessing right up to the end. It's a must watch movie, maybe not a big screen movie but a must watch all the same. 9 out of ten.

Technically, The Father is well made, with good quality direction, cinematography, editing and sets. But the script, acting and general atmosphere left me cold. Already too long at 1 hour 37 minutes, this movie is the cinematic equivalent of falling into depression over several hours (it actually feels like centuries). One of the UK's most over-rated actors, Anthony Hopkins, executes his lines with his usual hallmark 'character' and aplomb, but was operating in an empathy-free zone and I felt strangely unmoved by his plight. The other actors take a workaday approach to the job, but all those middle-class English accents prattling on froze my brain, and I missed a lot of their lines because I was yawning (my jaw still aches). This movie is unattractive, uninspiring, tedious, annoying, and life-draining.But it did make me feel something: it made me feel depressed about the prospect of getting old, and the growing probability we all have of getting dementia. Having relatives with dementia is bad enough, but watching someone's mind dissolve in front of your eyes for entertainment must be appealing only to people with a sick sense of humour or disturbed morality. Hope I die before I get old. Or at least before I ever have to watch this movie again.

"The Alzheimer's symptom initiates with slight memory loss and confusion, but then the symptom ultimately leads to severe and irreversible mental impairment". This is what is written in Wikipedia, and this is what the movie is very well displaying, to let us realize the extreme difficulties of a man (Anthony) approaching the illness, and stimulate our sadness for this fellow old guy. It is very difficult to represent as real as possible the struggle within the mental difficulties, but the movie passes the exam through one of the best performance ever by a unique actor, who has the capability to drive us between the emotions and the compassion, to abruptly but also gently let us feel to be side by side with him, to embrace his confusion, then ending the effort with his last delicate monologue at the end, when the actor goes from serioussness to soft angry, from a bitter smile to a genuine final cry (his tears come from real), he gives up asking for his mom to protect and to fetch him, resigning to his destiny. Excellent Mr. Hopkins.My compliments also to the Director. The watch is the metaphore of the concept of memory, at the beginning Anthony always worried not to find it, then passing time and fading away from his wrist, eventually losing it at the end. We can notice the movie is shot entirely in internal ambients, to stress and underline the closure of the mind, then the last scene ends looking outside the window, the camera even fades through the glass, to breathe the air and feel the green of the trees, in the search for the peace and the hope to be far from the illness, for our friend Anthony, and for ourselves.

reviews.review_title: Masterpiece of acting by Anthony Hopkins
reviews.content: Absolute incredible movie and, mainly, an marvelous acting by Anthony Hopkins. A truly Oscar winning performance.

reviews.review_title: Solid drama with a master class in acting from the leads
reviews.content: The Good: Firstly, the actors. Of course, Anthony Hopkins shows us a master class in acting - but that wouldn't be enough if everyone around him faltered. Thankfully, they don't - with the entire (small) cast performing astonishingly well with gripping, believable and nuanced performances. The directing is also tight and assured (in a directorial debut no less) - in keeping the setting small, the first-time director can play to his strengths - using the same amount of space he would have in a stage play. Using the unreliable narrator trope is also a clever move - as it keeps the story engaging and interesting when there's actually not much going on in the 'timeline'.The Bad: There isn't much to complain about really. It's a small script that doesn't really go anywhere outside the main characters - this is not a criticism, but don't expect a grand tale with sweeping cinematic gestures - this is firmly about a father, daughter and those in close proximity.Should you watch it: This is an intense film with a gripping final scene. If you are OK with the subject matter (my mum can't watch this as my grandfather went through this), then the film will leave you with a lasting impression. Highly recommended.

Directed by Florian Zeller An old man named Anthony(Anthony Hopkins) suffers from an extreme case of Alzheimer's but refuses help from anyone and lives at home with his daughter Ann (Olivia Coleman) who does all she can to try to help him. However it's emotional struggle as her fathers health continues to deteriorate over the year and doesn't know what's left to do. Touching and heartwarming but rather depressing film. This this is a film that touches on a rather common real world issue that affects so many families it's a story that everyone can get behind even f you don't know anybody personally however it does has a certain impact on those who know somebody or themselves have succumb to Alzheimer. The movie deliverance shows how much of a struggle it is to dealing with, however not just from Ann's perspective but also from Anthony Hopkins whodelivers one of the best performances in his career. Hand down me of his most Memorable rolls fitting to go along side Hannibal Lecter & Pope Benedict It's not a straightforward story the film is all over the place multiple interpretations and different perspectives it does a great job keeping you off track and unaware what's fully going on. Someone's would probably say that that's a problem and it causes the point to where they're confused about what's going on. That's the point You can see that they tried to make you feel more what would be like to be in his position. Where everything is not as clear or an order now things to be misinterpreted or confused. It has more immerse immersion to the audience on that note. There's One scene the movie where Ann returns home but it's indicated to the point that he doesn't even fully recognize his own daughter and she literally looks like an entirely different person to him. Constantly their points were scenes play out but they play out varied. Olivia Colman does a marvelous job you feel her struggle, you want her to do her to try to do wants best what is the course not as simple as one wish it was. They're both in a helpless state each with in a struggle. The Father manages to captivated audience emotionally and keep you invested It was a magnificent performance highly warranted of its acclaim.

See it.Brilliant acting
Hopkins at the top of his game
Brilliant script
Genius director.

reviews.review_title: Anthony Hopkins's performance 🎭 deserved his Best Actor Oscar.
reviews.content: Sir Anthony Hopkins deserves all the accolades he gets for this most deeply personal performance in, The Father. This is one of those first movies that delves into what is involved in dementia/Alzheimers patients. Sir Hopkins takes us on this journey that involves confusion, memory loss and burden. We are taking his footsteps, on his way, into this confusion world he's been sent to live, much without his knowledge or consent.I had to pause the movie to contain myself 😢 because Anthony's performance was on par with genius. His very moving journey into the road of dementia/Alzheimer leads us to a road of Netherland, and then to pick up the pieces afterwards.You may not be able to switch off after the movie ends, but Anthony's performance 🎭 will thankfully stay on for others to watch in awe.
Brilliant. Sad. True. Human. It is ruthless, as it should be. It is uncomfortably familiar. Brilliant.

I'm not usually a big fan of movies adapted from stage plays, because the very nature of writing for the theatre places the audience's focus on dialogue, structure and performance, and I'm more of a visuals and music guy when it comes to movies. I can appreciate sharp writing but I need the extra zest of overall fine filmmaking to bring an adaptation above and beyond the theatre. I tend to be more forgiving if a beautiful looking and great sounding movie is relatively lacking in plot or dialogue, versus the opposite (a movie with great writing, but technically bland).I'm a big fan of Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, but the potentially sensitive subject of dementia, and the fact that this was adapted from a play by a director who was making his screen directorial debut, had me worried. Would it be as stodgy or emotionally manipulative as it could have been? The material might have worked well on stage but would it as cinema?In that regard I was pleasantly surprised. Clearly this was a play, because it is indeed driven by the dialogue and character interactions, and almost entirely set indoors. But Florian Zeller provides some nice cinematic touches that help to raise the experience, mainly in three ways. One, his use of music. The few classical pieces here come in at just the right moments and are extremely effective whenever they do. I suspect that the music was also part of the stage production, because it's important to the protagonist's characterization; listening to music is Anthony's favored escape from reality. But here, the soundtrack fits the movie like a glove and gives it more dynamism. Two, Zeller's cinematographer, Ben Smithard, a veteran of numerous films and shows, vividly captures both the indoor and outdoor environments, most notably the main flat that contains most of the "action." The apartment complex becomes its own character, in a way, as the viewer gets to know its geography and objects. Credit must also go to the production and set designers, of course. Three, and probably most importantly, you have the excellent work by Greek film editor Yorgos Lamprinos. I haven't seen anything else he has done, but his editing here is a huge part of what makes this material translate so well as a movie. He was deservedly nominated for an Oscar.But those are all factors that personally made this such an excellent film for ME. Of course, the main draws here for most people will be Anthony Hopkins and the writing, by an award-winning playwright. And those things are as strong as you've heard. The writing is witty, unpredictable and, by the end, poignant, as you enter the frayed mind of Anthony while he deals with encroaching dementia. Zeller's treatment of such a sensitive subject is refreshingly free of sentimentality or emotional manipulation. This is pitched almost as much like a Hitchcockian mystery as it is a drama of old age and family, and the pacing is fantastic; at a tight 97 minutes, it never overstays its welcome or drags. As is typical of great writing, the script drops only as much detail as it needs to throughout, while leaving just enough lingering questions in the viewers' minds. And beware, not all of those questions will be answered. Even after the end credits begin rolling, you will need to interpret certain plot points in your own way, and there is a lot of fodder for discussion and debate here. My partner and I couldn't agree on what really transpired in the family's past. It frustrated her, but I loved the ambiguity.Hopkins is simply amazing here. He brings humor, anger, sadness, irascibility, strength and fragility in one fully formed and complex package of a character. He's such a natural in the role that I assumed he originated the part on stage. So It was to my surprise that I found out that not only was this film Hopkins's first time playing "Anthony," but the play was originally in French and therefore began life with a French lead in the role. Christopher Hampton, the translator, rightly receives a co-writing credit because he is a large part of why the English dialogue still crackled so well. Anybody would think it was the original language. The immensely talented Olivia Colman holds her own as the titular character's loving yet conflicted daughter, but this is mainly Hopkins's show and he is absolutely engrossing every second he's on the screen. And it's not just his facial expressions and line delivery either; it's a surprisingly physical performance; the viewer can easily gleam Anthony's varying moods and emotions merely from his body language (and he shows off some dance moves too). I haven't yet seen the late Chadwick Boseman in Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, but after witnessing Hopkins's incredible work here, I can't imagine anyone else more deserving of the Best Actor Oscar. Mads Mikkelsen for Another Round, maybe, but he somehow wasn't even nominated.

reviews.review_title: Great film and an iconic performance
reviews.content: When I think about all time great performances, I think about Marlon Brando's Vitto Corleone, Robert De Niro's Jake LaMotta, Tom Hank's Forest Gump, Daniel Day Lewis's Daniel Plainview, Jack Nicholson's R. P. McMurphy, Dustin Hoffman's Rain Man and, of course, Anthony Hopkins's Hanibal Lecter in Silence of the Lambs. And with no fear to make an overstatement, I can easily say that an 83 years old Anthony Hopkins did it again.Hopkins's performance is technically perfect, very emotional and powerfull. The result is a character with diferent layers, that is not just a man with a disease, but a man who once was charismatic, intelligent and proud. His struggle to not be able to be that anymore can be noticed on his lost look, his pain and in the solitude that his condition holds him. The intensity of all this fellings is brought to us in a raw way that just a great actor can do.And although Hopkin's performance is the main factor of the movie, it isn't just that what makes The Father a great movie. The editing is a crucial factor to creat confusion and imerse the audience in the main character's perspective. The screenplay is able to make the family drama comprensible as well the fellings of the diferent characters, besides all the confusion we are all imerse. And last, but not least, Olivia's Colman's great performance just makes the movie a more powerfull experience and reminds that this dificult situation can be lived by anyone who has an aged parent.All these makeThe Father a necessary, unconfortable and powerfull experience.

reviews.review_title: Another tour de force from Sir Hopkins
reviews.content: Films that revolve around a protagonist whose life is in flux usually make for compelling stories. When that individual is portrayed by someone of the caliber of Sir Anthony Hopkins, it makes things that much more interesting.In 'The Father,' we're treated to an acting battle royale between Hopkins and the queen herself, Olivia Colman, the latter of whom is a middle-aged daughter who must cope with taking care of her father who is in the midst of a long, slow decline due to Alzheimer's disease. This is a scenario that is playing out with too many families across the world, which makes it that much more relatable to the masses.The film is pretty stationery from a set perspective, so the emphasis is instead on the dialogue between the cast. Fortunately, it's solid. The editing in 'Father' also mirrors the confusion that Hopkins' "Anthony" experiences, which brings to life his struggles in a way that is hard for many of us to understand.'The Father' may not seem like an example of riveting film, but it's certainly a standout in Hopkins' long storied career.
A true masterpiece. This movie will stay in my heart forever. "I feel as if I'm losing my all leaves"

reviews.review_title: The best, most thought provoking movie I have watched in a long while
reviews.content: I had such a mix of emotion watching this movie. In parts it's strange and almost horror movie like. Other parts are very emotional. The fantastic acting of Anthony Hopkins makes the portrayal of a elderly man suffering with mental illness so very real.I'd recommend this movie to everyone.

reviews.review_title: This movie will leave you completely stunned!
reviews.content: I watched it with my wife, and we are both in our mid thirties. My wife was in tears for the last 20 mins of the movie, and did I find my eyes wet, too? We were never so moved after watching anything. I'm glad I can still take care of my parents, and will keep doing so to the best of my abilities, until the last leaf!

reviews.review_title: A big hit in the feels
reviews.content: This was...just...damn.Some might say it's repetitive, has no real plot, or that the characters aren't very developed. I can't really disagree with any of that, but what this film also is is absolute bloody genius.Because rarely, if ever, will I see a film with a non-linear and intentionally confusing narrative and love it immediately without thinking about it more or watching it again, but this one managed it. For reasons I won't go into, however, because if you don't know what this is about, please keep it that way and just watch it.All you need to know is that the direction is flawless, the cinematography is great, especially for the limited setting, the structure is certainly unusual, but you'll understand why really quickly, the dialogue is amazing, Anthony bloody Hopkins, Olivia bloody Colman, and that it brought me to actual tears.The only thing I'll gripe about a little is the music, but aside from that, if everything I just said isn't enough to convince you to watch this, then...well, I don't know what to say other than you're just...wrong.

It now seems incredible to me that never before a film had approached this illness from the perspective of the one suffering. It is a wonderful and harrowing view into losing your mind.You imagine how it might be for someone to lose their memory and be confused about reality, but this movie really manages to convey the real complexity of it. It gives you a perspective you never thought you needed and that you will never forget.Amazing movie, incredible acting, wonderful music and perfect pase. Truly a masterpiece.

After experiencing the downfall of my father myself at close hand to this hideous condition ....I'm so glad someone has realistically portrayed if only by a fraction the hurt and horror .i applaud you for observations ,a true horror film which is sometimes the life we live . A new benchmark in film on this subject imho.

It's like someone filmed my life right now. A few days ago I had to place my father in a nursing home, which was very difficult for me.I hope he will enjoy the new ambience as much as possible.In any case, my heart breaks because of his mental state - dementia.For all parents, but also for all children who love their parents. Even if they are patients with dementia.Thanks to Mr. Hopkins for his acting in this film is too perfect.
No words for this unbelievably incredible performance . Just hand him all the awards academy!!!!

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: Uncomfortable truth about the future that awaits us all. Brilliantly shown perspective from a person with dementia. Marvelous acting.Sad but good and true, we need more movies this good.

Just saw "The Father". Wow! Movie of the year. Excellent performances by all, especially Sir Anthony. A very sensitive, emotional journey through the mind of age. Expertly written and directed. In every aspect has it succeeded as an extremely moving and revelatory portrayal.

I am almost eighty, and, though I found the film riveting, I also found it confusing. Like Anthony, I couldn't work out who those strange men were. reviews.review_title: One of the best depictions of Dementia out there
reviews.content: I'm a Geriatric nurse and as such, I see a lot of Alzheimer's and Dementia patients. This film is by far one of the best depections of Dementia that I've ever seen. The plot feels disoriented but it's a purposeful disorientation as you realize that's what these patients feel. Names, faces, and memories all become jumbled. Alzheimer's patients do not experience time in the same linear concept that we do, and this movie captures that so perfectly. Sir Anthony Hopkins does a masterful job of bringing us into the mind of Anthony, an elderly gentleman suffering from Dementia, and Olivia Coleman captures the emotions and trials that her character, Anne, must endure as Anthony's daughter and caregiver. I hope that every medical professional sees this in order to help us provide better care for our patients, and I hope this brings a greater understanding to the public about those suffering from this illness, leading to more acceptance and a kinder world for us all. This movie is a must watch as it will keep you in your seat, and keep you guessing every step of the way. I'd also like to take a moment to explain that while not every person with Dementia may be this way, a large part are. There are different versions of Dementia, with some patients not gaining lucidity the way Anthony does, and some patients being completely pleasant in manner and mood. However, all the characteristics of the illness portrayed in this film are accurate, are not dramatized, and unfortunately are very real for millions across the globe. If you or someone you know is suffering from, or caring for, someone with Dementia, please call 1-800-272-3900 for support and services in your area.

reviews.review_title: A Classic modern take on Old-age solitude issue. The realistic Father of Delusional Mind-shakers like Persona, Fight Club and Shutter Island.
reviews.content:
The Father (2020) :
Brief Review -A Classic modern take on Old-age solitude issue. The realistic Father of Delusional Mind-shakers like Persona, Fight Club and Shutter Island. The Father is not that emotional soaking experience as we assume from the title and genre, rather it is damn confusing at the beginning and extremely delusional based on the realistic term called Memory Loss or Old-age solitude issues. Don't know why but somehow it reminded of Classic films made on delusional effects like Bergman's Persona (1966), Fincher's Fight Club (1998) and Scorsese's Shutter Island (2010) etc. But The Father is far more realistic than those fictional thrillers. The film is about a man who refuses all assistance from his daughter as he ages. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, he begins to doubt his loved ones, his own mind and even the fabric of his reality. By the end it gets over-confusing but fortunately provides all the answers in classy and artistic cinematic sequences. With the small runtime of 97 minutes it never bores you, it feels less actually. I was like, show me some more this is too short. Anyways, whatever they put on screen is simply brilliant and connectable despite the intricate theories used to explore a normal issue. I doubt, some people may not even understand it in the first watch and they shall have to watch again to understand it better. Anthony Hopkins gives a performance to remember and i would like to see him winning couple of honorary awards this year. The supporting cast is fine too. The Father is all about Zeller's outstanding vision to look at an ordinary routine and then showing it in extraordinary manners. How smartly he shuffles his characters, the sequences, linear equation and timeline of events is just splendid. Overall, The Father is A Must Watch and perhaps the Best Film of 2020.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest.

reviews.review_title: One of the most heartbreaking depictions of a debilitating illness I have ever seen on screen
reviews.content: "The Father" is a drama film directed and co-written by Florian Zeller, based on his stage play of the same name. Starring Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, it is one of the most heartbreaking depictions of a debilitating illness I have ever seen on screen.In London, the elderly Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) lives alone in his flat as he struggles to cope with his crippling dementia affecting both his short and long term memory. Anthony's daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) offers to help him through various means, from sending him live-in nurses to placing him in a retirement home, but he stubbornly refuses all assistance. As his condition worsens, Anthony starts to realise he is now unable to distinguish between events that happened minutes ago with ones that happened days, months, and even years ago. This causes him to become distrustful of his family and puts a huge strain on his relationship with everyone around him.It is a sad reality that the older we get, the more vulnerable we are to the degradation of our mental wellbeing. From personal experience, I have watched as my 98-year-old grandma deals with frequent memory loss and severe hearing difficulties whenever it is my family's time to look after her. What a film like "The Father" does so brilliantly is invite the audience to adopt the perspective of similar elderly individuals, showing us that their problems are way more serious than we may have been initially aware. We see as poor Anthony tries to make sense of simple tasks like remembering what location he placed his wristwatch in his flat, even though it is established by his daughter that he always places it underneath the bathtub. Something like that may seem trivial to us, but to him it is a key factor in identifying the rate at which his mind is deteriorating. Another thing worth mentioning is that he is also unable to recall what people look like, mentally superimposing other's faces onto the bodies of his loved ones. Scenes like this particularly stuck out to me as it reminded me of how annoyed my grandma must feel as she is beginning to forget things like which of her great-grandchildren was given an award at school. These are just some of the many difficulties that senior citizens around the world must face that this film shows in such a heart-wrenching manner.Being based on a play, the film makes use of a minimalistic setting, with the action taking place primarily inside either Anthony's flat or Anne's house. Director Florian Zeller uses some inventive cinematography here to depict how closed in and empty Anthony's world is as his dementia gets worse over time. Zeller also utilises subtle visual metaphors such as the brooding muted colours of wall tiles and choices in clothing to convey how Anthony's declining mental state is taking its toll on not only himself, but his own family. It is made very clear that Anne is suffering greatly as well, caring for her father through his ever-growing outbursts of frustration, which is a true test of her patience. Again, I must compare something like this to how my grandma is handling her own issues in her advanced age. It makes me reflect on all the situations where I may have been tempted to dismiss her complaints as typical old people's problems that I don't have to worry about, however, this film opened my eyes to the fact that this is something that can and will affect us all one day and that we should all try to exercise a little empathy from time to time.As one should expect by now, Anthony Hopkins gives an outstanding performance as the main character who shares his first name (so named by the director as he was the only actor he envisioned for this role). Even well into his eighties, Hopkins shows no sign that he is losing his ability to blow us away with his realistic approach to acting, giving his character a tragic sense of pathos we can immediately sympathise with. It is worth noting that Hopkins is apparently known for his uncanny ability to memorise entire scripts back to front, so this makes it even more impressive that he is able to play someone whose memory is in such a terrible state so perfectly. Olivia Colman was also great as Anne, who tries hard to deal with her father as his condition continues to diminish. Anybody who has dealt with the pain of an elderly loved one going through such problematic illnesses will find much to identify with in her character, as she wants his constant suffering to end just as much as he does.Although it is easy for films nowadays to touch on topics like dementia/Alzheimer's for the sake of cheap entertainment, this one truly feels like they've done a respectable job at doing so, especially since it doesn't sugarcoat its themes the way most others would. There's so much to appreciate in the sense of realism it presents in the long lasting emotional impact these illnesses can leave on families. Very few films have moved me to the brink of tears but I believe this one deservedly holds such a rare distinction. If you are still in contact with any elderly relatives, I implore you to reach out to them before they are gone forever and take the time to ensure they feel loved.I rate it a solid 9/10.
