A gut punch of a movie about an elderly widower and his increasingly tenuous grip on reality. People come, people go--his former helper, his new helper, his daughter, his son-in-law--but we are never quite sure who is real and who is not, because some of them exist only in his imagination. It is precisely this confusion, on his part and ours, that is at the core of this heartbreaking film. As the title character, Anthony Hopkins is better than ever, losing little bits of himself (and large chunks of his memory) as he withers away before our eyes, turning in a performance that is as fully realized and richly detailed as any you will see this year. (If by the end of the film you still aren't weeping, you'd better have your tear ducts checked.) The splendid Olivia Colman is every bit as moving as his daughter, who desperately wants to do what's best for her dad but is not at all sure how to go about it. The lighting--generally subdued, and often downright dim--serves as a perfect metaphor for the darkness in his mind, and the long, long night that lies ahead. Flawlessly directed by Florian Zeller, who co-wrote the screenplay with Christopher Hampton. A Tony-winner in 2016 for Frank Langella, who starred in the stage version, also written by Zeller. Hopkins may be taking home a trophy or two of his own, and deservedly so.

reviews.review_title: The acting is superb, outstanding and mesmerising
reviews.content: The whole film is a masterpiece. But without giving anything away, the last ten minutes of this incredible film, is the best single piece of acting I have ever seen. As a man suffering desperately from dementia, Anthony Hopkins gives a mesmerising performance.

reviews.review_title: Life through the eyes of an aging man
reviews.content: A realistic, touching yet terrifying, mind bending and absorbing film with great dialogues, amazing performances, settings and story.And Anthony rules!

I was getting confused and bored before I realised that was a small part of the necessary experience and at that realisation was drawn into the journey of dementia and the revelation of the importance of a simple watch. (You'll understand when you hear 'Anthony' explain in a throw away line of great importance.Anthony Hopkins' performance is incredible as he draws you into a distorted but honest reality.Not for the feint hearted or those without compassion but a must see for those seeking to understand dementia.

My Review- The Father
My Rating 10/10The Father is nominated for 6 Oscars this year and deserving every one of them . If there exists a true unbiased and fair award for acting excellence this year Sir Anthony Hopkins should win his 2nd Best Actor Oscar. His performance as Anthony an elderly man and the father of Anne who in another perfect role is played by Olivia Coleman is beyond superb. This is a Masterclass in cinema acting by both Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman. Some might say Anthony Hopkins who is 83 years old is just playing a man his own age . To the contrary it takes incredibly fine acting and precise timing to play a man with rapidly advancing dementia convincingly. It could only be played by an Actor of experience and deep sensitivity. This is the finest portrait of dementia as far as I'm concerned since Dame Judi Dench played Iris Murdoch in 2001 . Dame Judi who was also nominated as Best Actress in
2002 lost to Halle Berry for Monsters Ball. I feel a similar result will occur this year judging by predictions this so far . The far superior performance of Anthony Hopkins will probably lose out to a sentimental vote for a far lesser performance by Chadwick Boseman who tragically died last year. Sir Anthony Hopkins was the only choice for Director and author of the play Florian Zeller . He wanted Anthony Hopkins specifically for the part. He sent Hopkins the script in 2017 and waited for a reply. In the meantime, he did not pursue production with any other actors in the lead role. He said if Hopkins had not agreed to the film, then it likely would have been made in French instead. Christopher Hampton who wrote the screenplays for Atonement ( 2007) and Dangerous Liaisons 1998 (which he won an Oscar for his screenplay) and The Quiet American 2002 co wrote the Screenplay for The Father with Florian Zeller and both have deservedly been recognised by their nomination for Best Adapted Screenplay for 2021. I don't rate films on feel good value or entertainment enjoyment alone in fact as an elderly man over 70 years of age this movie is more than a little disturbing and confronting but it's cinematic excellence and performances make it one f the great films of 2021 and if you love the craft of acting it's a must see. In all Academy Award nominated performances I look for the moment you say yes! That's an Oscar moment in The Father I counted at least 3 Oscar winning moments for the brilliance of Sir Anthony Hopkins this may be his last Oscar nominated role of his long life I hope not but I'm also hoping that he wins this year's Academy Award for Best Actor.

reviews.review_title: Incredibly touching. Hopkins deserves that oscar.
reviews.content: A very sad, very realistic, touching story that gives you a look to a troubled aging mind. If you ever had a person with dimentia in your family this film is definitely gonna touch you and stick with you. Anthony Hopkins is amazing and there is no way you don't feel sympathetic to his character. At the end of the film you just want to give the old boy a hug. Since we can't give him a hug, please give him the oscar.
Anthony Hopkins's one man show. Belongs on the stage. As a movie rather boring.

And that's how you make a film. Great acting by Sir Anthony Hopkins and no wonder he got an Oscar for his fabulous performance as Anthony, rest of the cast, moved along with the flow. What a fantabulous film.

It doesn't take more than 5 minutes to realize you will be watching a television theatre. Like that crap with Ewan McGregor I can't even remember the name of. This is exactly the same, pretentious, quasi-philosophical type of play. And a mundane, annoying one. One even sir Anthony would not save. As a matter of fact, this movie's only value hides in his participation. If you can even talk about value here. The rest is literally just a bland, ordinary story, the outcome of which you can easily guess. I mean, at first one may even think there will be some sort of mystery involved. Some sort of suspense. And to its credit, the first 15 minutes feel like there will be some mystery, some suspense. But then you realize there won't be anything like that and actually there won't be much at all. Just cheap thrills for the masses. Yes, you got that right. This movie is a cleverly disguised cheap thrill. And judging by the ratings, in that it actually succeeded.

Really liked this movie. Made me think of 2012's "amour". But when push comes to shove, there is only so much you can do with the subject. So it does kinda feel like a simple story, and relies more on the human emotion of the film. So I can respect the movie, and it's certainly one of the best in what it's trying to be. But for what it is, it will never really blow my socks off.7/10: very good, held back but by it's identity.

reviews.review_title: Extraordinary perfromance by Sir Anthony Hopkins
reviews.content: One of the highlights of his remarkable career, likely one of his best ever perfomances. Bravo. Film is great, but it's all about acting. Olivia is decent as always.

I'm not really sure where to start! I've just finished stopping myself from ugly crying.I'm not going to give away any spoilers so here is 5 reasons to watch this movie.1. Outstanding acting by the entire cast
2. Keeps you engrossed as to what's actually happening
3. Anthony Hopkins!4. Olivia Coleman
5. It will make you reflect on something usually hidden to most of the general public and that's absolutely devastatingAnthony Hopkins deserves every award for his performance in this movie. I can't say that enough!Just watch it!

reviews.review_title: Great Screen Adaptation Of A Great Play
reviews.content: Directed by Florian Zeller and based on his own play (with Christopher Hampton), The Father is, quite simply, a brilliant movie that deals with one man's descent into the world of dementia. Anthony Hopkins gives what is quite simply his greatest screen performance of his long career, and Olivia Coleman provides excellent support as his caring daughter. This is one movie that will stay with you long after the credits roll. The Father contains some of the best film editing seen on screen in a very long time. It's heartbreaking yet empathetic. A very strong contender for this year's best actor and best supporting actress awards. You must see this movie. Anthony Hopkins delivers a masterclass in acting.

As a viewer, you become emotionally attached to Anthony Hopkins character and feel at one with him. You feel what it's like for people with Dementia and on their life coming to a slow end. Absolutely brilliantly portrayed.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of 2020
reviews.content: This movie perfectly shows the perspective of a person who has alzheimer disease. Brilliant acting by Anthony Hopkins and perfectly directed by Florian Zeller. Definitely one of the best movies of 2020.

reviews.review_title: Sad End to an Over-Hyped Career
reviews.content: I can't believe I just awarded one star to a film with substantial roles for Olivia Colman and Rufus Sewell, two of my favourite actors.Hopkins just drags it down ... and down ... to the point where it become totally predictable and utterly unwatchable.Hopkins is, in my opinion, an insanely overrated actor. He had his best moment 30 years ago in "The Silence of the Lambs" and never quite showed anything new since then. In fact, it seems as if he has regressed to his pre-Lechter mediocrity. His last turn, in "The Two Popes," was another totally forgettable appearance.The writing for his character offers him no chance to break-out of an endless loop of confusing daughters, chickens, husbands, and that damned, perpetually-missing wristwatch.Would he have received an Oscar nomination in a non-pandemic year when the release of fresh films had not been so drastically truncated?There is some solace that Academy Award for Best Actor will most certainly go to the well-deserving Chadwick Boseman, a great talent taken from us all too soon.Hopefully this will be the last we see of 83-year-old Hopkins. Even Laurence Olivier, an actor with a far, far greater range, had the good sense to retire, returning to the screen for a final three-minute cameo appearance in the year of his death at age 82 in the non-speaking role of a wheelchair-bound World War I soldier (his voice, reciting a poem, is overdubbed).The director is to be faulted as well. Just as with "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," "Father" began its life as a stage-play set mostly in one room, to be performed for live audiences of about 1.000. In both cases, nothing was done to open up the story, and they do not meet the criteria of film: they are but documents of stage dramas, complete with five-minute monologues which would work well onstage, but not in film. But if I need to hear someone rant for five minutes, I'd much rather it be Viola Davis.

I saw this at the Woodstock film festival and it stayed with me long after. The conceit of experiencing dementia and confusion through the eyes of the person suffering from it it very effective, and coupled with great performances, this is a great little piece of cinema.

Both of the actor's acting was incredible!! I loved watching this. They treated the subject of the movie very softly that it made this movie so easy to watch even though the whole topic is sad and heart breaking. I loved the scenario and cinematography. And i also loved seeing Sir Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman together. Superb acting and a quality movie!! Must watch.By the way, during the movie i cried several times but when the movie was over, i got out of the mall and went to the car and cried my eyes out like i could not even believe that was just yesterday. I remembered every single pain i've been through since i've lost my grandparents 3 years in a row. I felt connected to that money. Definitely will watch later again to witness this beautiful acting for one more time.

reviews.review_title: Difficult to watch while simultaneously being difficult to look away from
reviews.content: For anyone who has ever had a loved one who suffered from dementia this could be a painful film to watch but worth it never the less, for anyone who has never had to go through that I think it will be eye opening. The cast all give excellent performances especially Anthony Hopkins, the film both compelling and deeply upsetting.

This film is a masterpiece. Acting, cinematography, direction, production, story... All first class.An absolute, full-blown, outstanding, wonderful, haunting, beautiful, devastating, mind-bending masterpiece.Congratulations to all involved.Highly recommended.

"Meu pai" Eu amo o Anthony Hopkins em todos os seu papéis. Mas acho que de fato esse foi o papel mais difícil, porque é difícil de assistir. Angustiante. Aterrador. A velhice é assustadora, e através dos olhos dele e de sua incomparável performance não há como não se envolver com esse drama. No Google Play. I love Anthony Hopkins in all of his roles. But I think that was in fact the most difficult role, because it is difficult even to watch. Distressing. Terrifying. Old age is scary, and through his eyes and his incomparable performance there is no way not to get involved in this drama. On Google Play. #movieslover #googleplay #anthonyhopkins.

Watching someone deteriorate this much from dementia is devastating and i wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy. This film highlights just how difficult it must be for everyone involved with this awful affliction.

reviews.review_title: Be kind with the old fellows
reviews.content: After watching this film, I cannot understand how Nomadland got the Oscar. Some things are just wrong. Hopkins delivers a haunting performance.

reviews.review_title: If you've lost a loved in with dementia this will be hard to watch
reviews.content: Possibly the most heart wrenching movie I've ever seen. My mother had 5 strokes and became senile, confused and forgetful. Anthony Hopkins performance was spellbinding and the way it was shot from his perspective brought back vivid memories for me and also an understanding of why people with it behave the way they do.It's one you have to watch and not half watch whilst doing other things, but it's worth it.

2 great actors, great directing, masterful movie as the rendition of last chapter of human journey slowly end. It's like sitting on calm yet poignant Dusk, beautiful yet sad because we know the Night will finally come.
Holy s**t! Everything and everyone was superb, but Anthony Hopkins' acting was... mind-blowing is an understatement!

First of all, Anthony Hopkins gives one of his best performances as a man struggling with dementia, only topped by his role in Silence of the Lambs.Secondly, The Father shows how powerful storytelling can be. It shows incredibly well what it is like for a person with dementia to realise his slowly loosing his mind and there is nothing to be done about it.It isn't confusing or complex. It is just storytelling at its best and a short set of actores giving some of the best performances of their carrers.One of the best movies of the year.

Having just watched this knowing as little as possible about it, other than it was based on a play about a dementia sufferer and Hopkins won an Oscar, I expected the usual drama on how difficult the patients are to manage & the pain the family go through.What I did not expect was the brilliant playwrighting, the set pieces that fantastically illustrate the sinister tricks decaying memory plays on the afflicted, the way the film drops you almost into the mind of the man via those illustrations and of course the overall well above average acting; helmed by Hopkins himself in probably the best acting he has done in his entire career.I'm trying to emphasise just how brilliantly crafted the whole thing is without giving any spoilers and you really should go in to it with a similar mindset outlined in the first paragraph of this review.This goes straight to the top of my "plays turned into movies" top 3 - followed by Glengarry Glen Ross and The Sunset Limited.Ironically, this film about dementia or Alzheimer's will stay with you forever.

reviews.review_title: The POV thing proves less effective on the movie than it had to be on stage...
reviews.content: I had a bad feeling about it when it started with Opera...You know these kinds of jokes that rely on redundancy: "Dental plan" "Lisa needs braces" or the long introduction of the vessel in "Spaceballs", it's funny because it challenges our patience, then it stops being funny when it gets on our nerves and then it takes that extra level of length that gets it back to funny... I'm not sure this work for drama.Take a premise that could work for a 30-minute TV theatre film, but multiply the scenes that say exactly the same thing and cast an acclaimed aging actor like Sir Anthony Hopkins, and apparently, you get a masterpiece.Now, I just saw "The Father", the highly-acclaimed and universally praised film about a man estranged to his daughter, in fact the whole world around him and hopelessly battling the inexorable descent into dementia. It so happens that I saw it with my own father, we thought this was going to be one of these poignant family dramas with two persons coming to terms at the end, for the obligatory deathbed scene, not the peak of originality but with an actor of Hopkins' caliber, watching him waiting to catch a stout for two hours can be a sight to watch.I wish the film was about fishing.I like a film to subvert my expectations, to come with something new, and Anthony Hopkins gives a great performance, a magnificent one, an Oscar-worthy one and what do you know, he won it. Haing said that, the choice of portraying a dementia form the POV of the patient is interesting and revolutionary but for a play. I admire the daringness and guts of Florian Zeller to challenge and disorient spectators by putting on stage scenes that are the figments of a man's imagination.Now, every review raves about that challenging idea and the way it allow us to feel the confusion of the poor man and being as disoriented and dizzy as he is... I agree that it's a great way to build empathy but I don't think this is the ultimate way to put ourselves in an old person's shoes or feel the ordeal of senility or Alzheimer, let alone, feel the emotional burden of the children. Since we never know who is real and who is not, it kind of defeats the purpose of empathy.For me that's how the film lost me, when it played hard to get for the third time, it was one to me and I guess my mind was so unwilling to pursue the effort that I told my effort there was no need to go on, I know his tastes, he needs linear and straight narratives. A film can be original if there's something entertaining to sustain it but I can't see how wrapping confusion with pathos can make for a pleasant experience. If you're going to hit the sensitive chords, maybe you shouldn't make it too cerebral. A good thing there are occasional burst of humor and lightheartedness, this film at times is literally the Anthony Hopkins' show.Now, don't get the wrong idea about my Dad, the day before, we were watching "The Hunt", one film made us talk and comment and anticipate actions. With "The Father", after the first scene, we remained silent and I know what that silence meant, we hoped that something better would come up after. It didn't. After the first scene with Anne (Olivia Colman) the daughter, comes the one with the man played by Mark Gatiss who's supposedly married with a woman played by Olivia Williams who also plays the nurse at the end. Then you have Anne's husband played by Rufus Sewell and Imogen Poots who plays the new carer but by the time we got to the slapping scene, I could feel my Dad's agony and told me that I had just read about the film, and it wouldn't get any better.I finished the film. I tried to appreciate the performance of Hopkins and his poignant interactions with Colman (who was nominated too). I consider the scene with Poots as one of Hopkin's career's highlights especially the mood swing that terminate the smile that kept illuminating her face. But for one moments like this, we have to endure these long walk over dark corridors, these moments of sheer melancholy, this Opera music and these damn violins. Watching them and even knowing that Zeller is a respectable playwright, I was wondering why he had to exploit that stylistic choice till the end. I know it didn't prevent the film from garnering 98% of approval on Rotten Tomatoes and get on IMDb Top 250, some Youtube videos from people who've seen it more than once provide explanations.Well, I saw the film twice and I listened to the explanation. And for me it all comes down to one question: why the mystery since we already know the answer? Why not get to the heart of the matter, which is a matter of the heart? And that's what the final scene is about, a breakdown, something deep and sincere, without any trick or artistic license. I'm at least grateful for Zeller to have made the scene that way.As for the rest, I think people were so blinded by Anthony Hopkins' performance, that they praised the performance rather than the whole film or they were so admirative of the change of perspective that they felt like rewarding its "courage". I have an idea, next time I will shoot a movie entirely in black and black, total darkness and I will say it's a way to make you feel empathetic to the ordeal of blind people. Maybe it would work.Speaking for myself, and I know I'm in a minority, "The Father" made it for a depressing, bleak and confusing experience. It was a drag. And even the musical choices were atrocious. I stop here, I don't want to get redundant, myself.

reviews.review_title: Features not one, but two, breathtaking performances
reviews.content: "The Father" blew me away! Anthony Hopkins is getting all manner of accolades for his performance and deservedly so, but Olivia Colman is brilliant too.The film plays out from the point of view of the man with Alzheimer's. Consequently, the storyline is hallucinatory, disjointed, confusing, filled with internal contradictions, and makes dizzying leaps in time. All that works to the movie's advantage as it shows us how that loathsome disease will turn a once-vital man into a desiccated husk of his former self.Having witnessed the ravages of Alzheimer's as it destroyed two people I loved, I found a lot to relate to in "The Father." One example is the fantasy segment in which Ann imagines herself choking the life out of the old man. She has these thoughts not out of malice or resentment, but because she wishes to end her father's suffering, as well as her own.One issue the film does not address is finances. The characters are well off enough that when Ann makes the heartbreaking decision to put her father in a nursing home, he gets a private room in a comfortable-looking facility with a nurse who gives him one-on-one attention.Having once held a driving job for a pharmacy, I delivered to a lot of nursing homes. Many of them stank of urine and feces, crammed several patients into a room, and were severely understaffed so that one-on-one care was impossible. I would be interested in someday seeing a film about Alzheimer's in which the victim and his loved ones are working-class or poor.Having seen only a handful of movies from the Year of Covid, I can't say for sure that "The Father" is the best film of 2020. It is, however, the best one I've seen. This is nothing to watch if you're looking for escapist entertainment; but if you want a film for the ages, you've found it.
This move is a great guide to those who do not understand dementia.At times it's a little scary that one may relate this to themselves. Anthony the powerhouse of the most realistic acting.

reviews.review_title: The Father is a STUNNING Masterpiece!
reviews.content: Wow, wow, wow, this was STUNNING!! 'The Father' is an absolute masterpiece!Seeing out parents grow older is very difficult, especially when it becomes difficult for them to look after themselves. And, yeah, we only know too well they won't admit it.'The Father' takes a look at a man suffering from dementia, and slowly but surely losing grip on reality - and time itself. Interestingly, the film is told from the victim's perspective, how he perceives his own reality - or lack of. It also illustrates how difficult - and sometimes frustrating - it is for the loved ones, and their loved ones. In this case, his daughter, Anne, who looks after him.Time becomes irrelevant to someone suffering from dementia, and this is illustrated so incredibly well in 'The Father'. There are so many shock twists and turns, and its heartbreaking to see. The subtle score was so effective - almost haunting. Anthony Hopkins delivers one of the best performances I have ever seen! He is absolutely FANTASTIC! Olivia Colman is equally incredible as Anne.The film has a simple setting and would work just as well as a stage play, which I think would be a great idea.If you've ever known someone with Alzheimer's or dementia, you will relate, and it will be heart wrenching - as it was for me. 'The Father' is a film everyone should see.

If you do or if you don't know anyone who has had dementia this film will leave you chilled to the bone. I have always been a HUGE Hopkins fan and this is why.This film will make you think twice before you put off that phone call you should of made or that visit you didn't make to someone who needs you.We can all hope and pray that our minds don't go like in this film.An absolute film to watch...!!!!

reviews.review_title: I'd Give It 12 Stars If I could
reviews.content: This film is genius at work! The filmmakers have complete control over the viewer in ways that is almost impossible to do. Hopkins nailed the role of a deteriorating man with Dementia who is rightfully paranoid of what's happening around him, and we as an audience are right along with him questioning what the hell is going on. The cast and crew should be very proud of this film that will last through the ages. If I could give it 12 stars I would.

The last time I cried so hard for a movie was Lion and that was based on a true story. Everything about this movie designed to make you understand something that is so hard to explain, it is a more poignant version of Still Alice. The magical quality of the scenes fading in and out of one another takes you all the way to the end.

reviews.review_title: A view of dementia seldom seen
reviews.content: Well done to all. Antony Hopkins never fails to deliver. He shows dementia from the side of the sufferer. At times it's almost like a psychological thriller.

reviews.review_title: Might make you live in fear!
reviews.content: This is how brilliant it was done that it will scare you by the fact that this is reality. Its been two weeks and I can't stop thinking about this movie. Its flawless in each act. I'm so thankful Sir Anthony said yes to this. I always had the understanding pf the disease but I could never grasp it intil I've watchdd this. Truly brilliant and a must watch.

Moving from non-diegetic sound to diegetic sound of classical music the dementia-afflicted titular father is listening to while relaxing, we right away found ourselves slipping into his mind and, subsequently, descending into his deteriorating mental state. Thus, we're instantly warned that what we're going to witness of events are, by and large, untrustworthy. Adopting such narrative technique isn't the easiest to pull off, never mind when applied to a character-driven story about a man doubting "the fabric of his reality." For in case it failed, the story would be in total shambles (Capone is a case in point, assuming that was its intent in the first place); and if it paid off, the story would offer us a sympathetic look at its main character. Florian Zeller managed to do the near-impossible, generating empathy towards a character we're not suffering from what it suffers by tapping on the truth we relentlessly evade each time we see our grandparents, for instance, fail to recall words, our names or even to recognise who we are while they're doing their utmost to convince us otherwise. This film embraces this fear to a disturbingly horrifying degree. We found ourselves pondering over what we see as an impending condition so much so we're simultaneously letting the uneasiness dominates our thoughts while we're sitting watching the movie.Zeller also managed here to give The Father a clinical quality reminiscent of psychological horror films to keep us always on the verge of being painfully unsettled at any time. High pitched sharp sounds and disquietingly cozy furniture(s) are here to accentuate this feeling so that a little boundary-pushing moment would send a shiver down the spine along with some suppressed tears begging to be shed. And then we have Hopkins delivering a tour de force performance that will soon or later be regarded as one of his best. Through his character, we see him in an utter bewilderment, incessantly trying to figure out what's happening around him and make sense of all that "nonsense" in such manner that force you to do so along with him. That's the definition of an engaging performance. Another thing I noticed through his facial expressions is the that he seems to be constantly processing his surroundings as well as every words he hears. A truly brilliant performance that dictates how similar characters should be played. I'm really hoping Riz Ahmed wins since it would be his first Oscar but, truth be told, Sir Hopkins is more worthy of it. Olivia Colman is absolutely amazing as always, but it's Imogen Poots as the nurse (Laura) that caught me off guard with the scenes she shares with Anthony. The spontaneity of elderly people that can be inadvertently offensive and their fear of being mocked at or at least of being treated rather as children collide here in way that made me continuously switch back and forth between sympathising towards each of them. This is a unique, unprecedented cinematic achievement, and definitely my favourite movie of 2020.(10/10)~Spoiler Alert~A spoiler warning here as I'm talking about a certain motif in this movie, that is the "watch". Besides the "apples" in Pieces of a Woman, this is yet another deft use of motifs in movies from the last year. The watch here indicates Anthony's grasp of the sense of time and age. His watch is first mentioned as being snatched by Laura. Later on, we see Anthony suspects Paul to be wearing his watch. In both occasions, it was the first time for him to be introduced to these characters, and the fact he failed to recognise them made them sources of intimidation that threaten his supposed control over his memory. In the soul-crushing ending scene where he's with his nurse, Catherine, he says that he wants his mom but his nurse corrects him, saying he means his daughter. However, he insists that it's his mom, then he mentions that he wants her and that he's losing his leaves. Then, in a last desperate attempt to convince himself of his sanity, he says that he knows that his watch is on his wrist. From all this we may gather that his last monologue seems to sum up all his life, and his aging to be precise. His life went in full circle and now he's a child again in a pressing need of his mom.
The Father is practically a psychological horror movie, depicting the decaying psyche of an old man, battered by dementia. As for movies, The Father is one to never forget.

Heartbreaking and haunting, a perfect portrait of dementia as the mind slips away memories fade and are replaced with hallucinations and paranoia and once a perfect gentleman is reduced to the state of infancy , his only remaining daughter is no longer able to care for him and he is sent to a nursing home . But that is not all to it , with proper care and in hands of professional and kind medical staff he too is able to find comfort and peace of mind in hands and embrace of them , so that his remaining days are peaceful. Having dealt with a granny who suffered from dementia this movie's portrayal of sickness as accurate and informative, kindness and patience are the most important thing to keep in mind when dealing with people with dementia and maybe perhaps professional help is required.

reviews.review_title: The Father is each one of us
reviews.content: "The father" does not talk only about dementia, it talks about life and about growing old. In the final scenes of the movie the door opens completely and human fragility rushes inside your soul and mind. This movie starts quietly and it slowly takes your whole heart as the story makes clearer and as you put the pieces of the puzzle together.Other movies simply described dementia and old age, from an external point of view. This movie instead is seen within the eyes of an old man who is losing touch with reality and who feels more and more dazed and scared and this is an extremely original prospective.The acting is powerful and Anthony Hopkins is simply great.

reviews.review_title: Striking narrative driven by the Father's point of view
reviews.content: The Father doesn't really have a story. There's no place and time. Not really. "Real" being the key word. What is real? When, where? Who? Anthony, played by Anthony Hopkins, who rightfully won an Oscar for it, is real. He's the titular Father - a retired engineer suffering from dementia. His daughter Anne (wonderful Olivia Coleman) is also real. His son-in-law (Rufus Sewell)? Probably. But when? And what about the home care aide named Laura (Imogen Poots), who reminded Anthony of his other daughter Lucy?The most striking thing about The Father is that the narrative is driven by Anthony's point of view. To him it's all real. But familiar people and places morph into unfamiliar, reality blurs with dreams, and he is desperately trying tether himself to at least the time with his trusty watch, but he keeps misplacing it. Or rather mis-hiding. Because the only way this nonsense can be explained is that everyone is out to get him and his stuff. He's suspicious, angry, and abusive towards his loving, heartbroken daughter. And the moments of clarity are even more devastating as fear of abandonment sets in - unavoidable, blameless, and real.

reviews.review_title: What a great acting by Hopkins!
reviews.content: A very simple storyline, scenario, not even with an interesting enough plot, but this movie is just so good to watch from the very beginning to the end. The script was absolutely great and the movie itself was simply made alive and real by Hopkins alone. He indeed is a great treasure to visual performing art. One more Oscar for him, please!

While there are movies like My Neighbor Totoro which beautifully portray the world from the eyes of a child, The Father portrays the world from the eyes of a senile human in the most emotionally and mentally twisting way possible. Anthony Hopkins' impeccable performance just elevated this flawless masterpiece to next level, behind which a strong message is hidden for every youngster with parents out there.

With Coleman and Hopkins, two great actors, I had high expectations.But perhaps it was because they are too good, too realistic and the story is too close to 'the knuckle'.We go to the cinema to escape reality not be bewildered.Didn't enjoy the film 6/10 and that is for acting ability.

reviews.review_title: A very saddening but brilliant film
reviews.content: Incredible performances from Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman!'The Father' makes for a rather heart-breaking watch, it's very clear from the get-go where the film is heading but that doesn't stop it hitting directly in the feels. I've fortunately never been around someone with what this film depicts, yet it still came across as very realistic - based on what I have heard about the condition.Hopkins is utterly superb in the lead role, which is what I expected given I had heard about this 2020 flick back when it won the big gongs. Something I hadn't heard about, though, was Colman's performance - which is absolutely fantastic, particularly in one emotional scene alongside Hopkins and Imogen Poots.A very saddening but brilliant film, cleverly portrayed too.
8/10 - affecting and innovative film leaves a mark in large part due to the performances of its talented cast.

reviews.review_title: Tragic disease exploited for good reviews
reviews.content: Let's be honest, Anthony Hopkins is a brilliant actor and he is certainty not letting us down in The Father. Unfortunately that alone doesn't save this movie. The storyline looks very promising at the surface but unfortunately it is nothing but a bad excuse for attention. Drama and mystery are here misused to distort the image of a tragic disease, which basically is exploiting the disease to get creds and good reviews.

reviews.review_title: Repeating a common reality, with no solution nor hope.
reviews.content: Due to the closing of the cinemas, it has been a long wait for me to see this movie, and I'm, well... Not impressed. It's about an old man who's developing dementia, and a daughter who's struggling with the decision of whether or not she should send him to a nursing home. As a nurse who had worked in nursing home for sometime in the past, I can confirm it's quite a popular case in Europe, and it has also been going on for quite a long time. So since this drama wanted to be many things else, with sci-fi and mystery are among those, it forgot to actually present anything special to the situation, and became not so much worth paying attention to. It looks more like a backstory episode in a TV series than a movie, and the fact that it also leads to the inevitable, to the norm, it makes itself quite unimportant. I have to say I can hardly understand all the praise for this movie. Anthony Hopskins is amazing in it but as the story repeats a common reality, his performance gets old quickly. The only saving grace for it is probably the vibrant and excellent choices of opera soundtrack, but even with that, I was struggling quite much to finish this movie.

About halfway into the movie, I suddenly realized I felt drunk or stoned even though I was actually sober. The script, the acting, the direction, the filmography - everything about this film created an immersive story that dragged me into Hopkins' character's mind. I vicerally FELT his character's confusion and disorientation. I literally FELT like I was drunk and stoned even though I was sober. I FELT like I'd lost track of what was happening in the film even though I KNEW I hadn't. Masterful!
Heartbreaking, and doesn't feel like a movie. Terrifying, really.

Just back from seeing this film & well... it's pretty haunting yet very realistic to life.The film follows Anthony, an elderly man slowly deteriorating from the devastating effects of dementia.I found the film to be quite moving, it has some moments of humour laced in with the more serious sad scenes, the end scene was especially was pretty sad & moving.It's pretty good, so good that's it's quite depressing & gives a realistic insight/depiction of what suffers of the disease go through & how it effects them & those around them.I noticed that the film is edited in such a way that you as the viewer are put ion the shoes of Anthony.Overall, it's a pretty good film, but it is also pretty sad & heart wrenching, not to mention haunting. The film will stay with you after the credits roll it's that deep. 8/10.

A dying man gets mental issues as aging. The only one he knows is his daughter. The shot of movie is quite confusing. It is hard for audiences to know which scene is real and which one is not. It is so confusing.
This will hunt me for a while... Devastating thing that already took so many great people...

reviews.review_title: Sir Anthony Hopkins is a Treasure!
reviews.content: Adapted from a play named Le Père, written by Mr. Zeller himself; "The Father" with its shrewd narrative makes an attempt to captivate our conscience! A fitting illustration of a cruel disease that tears apart one's happy & healthy life. A frightful state of mind where the whole caboodle seems to be breaking down!"Memories and thoughts age, just as people do. But certain thoughts can never age, and certain memories can never fade" - Haruki Murakami'Dementia' is a group of conditions that deteriorate your memory, behavior and the typical way you perceive regular activities. The patients suffering from this not so uncommon malady fail to distinguish between what is reality and what is not! We couldn't possibly imagine what difficulties they and their loved ones go through every single day!Perhaps for that reason, the makers thought; 'Why not we do the honors?'Delving deeper into the psyche of such a patient and his gradual descent into nothingness. The storyline puts us through an intriguing pathway, where we get to descry an old man who's slowly losing his ability to function in an appropriate manner!In parallel, a Daughter's helplessness to deal with her father's newly found disorder. In spite of crumbling affection, she just wants the best for her 'Little Daddy'. A heart-wrenching portrayal, that makes us emotionally attached and sympathetic toward this father-daughter duo!Further strengthened by staggering performances from both Sir Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. I don't have enough words for the amount of conviction & credibility they offer in their respective acts. It got them the nominations in the 93rd Academy Awards and deservedly so!Once in a while, some films do leave a mark. By transcending our intuitive understanding; they simply make us spellbound. They compel us to change our perspective of seeing the world! It is clearly one of those special creations.

reviews.review_title: I never weeped in my life like this before. Such a very authentic heavy drama. Like seeing the absolutele difficult day to day life from an Alzheimer's patient. Best drama.
reviews.content: I never weeped in my life like this before. Such a very authentic heavy drama. Like seeing the absolutele difficult day to day life from an Alzheimer's patient. Best drama.

The only flaw I can find to this movie is that is too sad and poignant, to the point that by the end it had me sobbing like a little girl. It's the kind of movie I wouldn't be willing to watch a second time. In a fair world, I can't see how any other movie would stand a chance at winning the Academy Awards or any actor other than Anthony Hopkins (at 83!) at winning Best Leading Actor, but sadly, we all know how things operate this days...
This film is truly a masterpiece and has one of the best Sir Anthony Hopkins role. He should get an Oscar for this acting.Must be watched.

The FatherThe foundation of this movie lay with one simple idea, how can we, the director, script writer and cast, show the viewer what it must be like, in a very visceral way, to have dementia. They chose several clever and comprehensive ways to make us feel, confused, unsettled, uncomfortable, upset and mostly all at the same time. It was an emotional rollercoaster for anyone who has had a loved one in this predicament.Just when we thought the "watch" was an anchor, then the "chicken" was an anchor, or even a blue top, it was ripped away by cutting time, changing furniture or even changing characters faces.The bigger question must be did these theatrical tricks achieve their goal and work their magic. I think on reflection the answer must be a solid yes, by proxy we felt totally befuddled throughout.With regard to the acting, it was a tour-de-force performance from Anthony Hopkins, totally stellar in its micro-gestures, the plastic bag in the pocket, or the furtive glance at a watch. This was an obvious Oscar winner in a year when there was nothing else to challenge, however that observation does not diminish this achievement.Olivia Colman really turned it out and I would say her performance here was much better than the blank expression of Francis McDormand in Nomadland, but what do I know!This was a miserable, tedious and worthy movie that I endured and experienced, I admired its scope and delivery but I never want to see it again, never ever, and I do not suggest anyone else sees it for the first time, as it would just not be possible to enjoy this movie on any level.I give this a solid 8 out of 10 meaning its good and you should watch it, but if something is showing in the next screen go and see that instead.

This film has a simple story just following a man with dementia and how the people around him are affected by it. The acting and screenplay is what makes this film and this showed with the Oscar wins. Hopkins plays a simple character suffering with dementia and captures the struggle he has when people don't believe what he sees with his illness. Production was great as well. I was able to stay engaged even with the film being in one setting (mostly). Do watch this film, some may be able to relate to the story as well.
The Father is entrancing. It will keep you bewildered throughout, as Anthony Hopkins flashes his acting prowess. He keeps getting better with age. This movie is eerie and too real.

Really great movie, unfortunately in the family we have already had a loved one who has suffered from dementia, and this movie has just reminded me how she had acted, and can help to understand people who has dementia.Everyone should see.

Have your handkerchefs at the ready for a harrowing depiction of the decline of the mind and the realities of dementia.More like a play than a film (7 characters have lines and there are 2 settings), the film follows Anthonys gradual aging decline.The abiguity of this film and the time frame in which it is set leaves you confused and in awe of how clever it is simultaineously. You are led to believe the plot is going one way and it take regular left turns, without defining the ending for the audience. The beauty of this film is that nothing really happens, but we care so much for Anthony and despair seeing him so hurt. The director has complete faith in Hopkins ability to carry the film with pure emotion.If you're sick of mind numbing action for the sake of action (which is becoming more common place in this tik tok low attention span era) and want a film by which you can get lost in such a simplistic plot and be in awe of some sublime acting then this is the film for you.Well deserved oscar for Hopkins.

reviews.review_title: I watched "The Father" 3x in a 48-hour period -- NOT in order to...
reviews.content: ..."figure it out"; that's only SEMI-possible -- if at all: even the ending, for instance, can be taken at least 2 different ways, in terms of what's real & what isn't, given the condition of the point-of-view character (played to perfection by Sir Hopkins). No, I watched the film 3x in 2 days because it's so compelling. And yes, each time I perhaps "got it" a bit more, but more to the point, I got more OUT OF IT. This isn't "Memento" (another fine film); it's not a puzzle-ox to "solve." I suggest simply experiencing it, again & again, as your experience OF it deepens and broadens and thickens. MASTERPIECE.

reviews.review_title: The Father gives us a story that's both brilliant and heartbreaking, but also an unforgettable performance by Anthony Hopkins
reviews.content: I didn't expect to write this review but after hearing so many good things about it and then watching it, The Father blew my expectations and moved me with all kinds of emotions. From Anthony Hopkins' acting (which he won an Oscar for) to the person behind the film and play it's based on. Florian Zeller co-wrote The Father alongside fellow playwright Christopher Hampton and based it on Zeller's 2012 play. It was also his directorial debut. Florian Zeller created a film so moving, so brilliant, he created a masterpiece in the drama genre. Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman in the leads. Whilst the supporting cast has Rufus Sewell, Imogen Poots, Olivia Williams and Mark Gatiss.A man refuses all assistance from his daughter as he ages. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, he begins to doubt his loved ones, his own mind and even the fabric of his reality.I would call The Father a psychological drama because of how we're seeing Anthony Hopkins' character's condition worsening for each scene. Normally, films based on plays that are dialogue heavy is something I wouldn't normally recommend, The Father is dialogue heavy but it's Hopkins' performance and the important story Zeller is telling that makes it so interesting, that you can't stop watching. Though a brilliant film, with me having a fear of getting dementia and someone close to me who had dementia, I wouldn't say it was an easy watch. But it's a film everyone should see before they die, if not for the story, for Anthony Hopkins acting performance as it might possibly be his best. Many critics call it his best performance, I don't agree with it being his best, but certainly one of his best. Olivia Colman brings a terrific performance as the Daughter, a character many will be familiar with, I was. Zeller and Hampton won Best Adapted Screenplay at the Academy Awards and the film received six nominations in total, including Best Picture and Best Supporting Actress (Olivia Colman).Will I ever watch The Father again? The hard truth is, I don't know, probably not. But I'm so grateful for having the opportunity to watch it, to experience Florian Zelle's work. Zelle wrote the part especially for Anthony Hopkins and I'm glad he accepted the role, it won him many awards but most importantly the importance of the performance regarding dementia in general.

It's set in the late 2010s in London, England, and captures part of an 80-year-old man's journey with increasing dementia.Anne (Olivia Colman) has come to the end of the line with her father, Anthony (Anthony Hopkins), who has just caused his last caretaker to quit because he accused her of stealing his watch. Anne, who is divorced, tells Anthony she has met a man and will be moving to Paris. However, she will try once more with another caregiver before putting him in a nursing home.The bulk of the film is primarily flashes of Anthony's changing memories and moods. It is not clear what is reality and what is not. It's not clear where he is living until the end of the film. Did Anne actually have a husband, Paul (Rufus Sewell)? If so, which man is the husband? Sometimes even Anne is a stranger.This is an unsettling film to watch, especially if you're 75 years old! Anthony Hopkins won an Academy Award for his performance, and it was outstanding. Olivia Colman is also excellent. The other characters are a bit slippery since we don't really know what reality they emerge from.My biggest problem with the film is that most characters do not respond appropriately to dementia. But does that matter, since Anthony denies dementia's reality, and it's his film.
This movie is so touching I can't control my tears. I miss my father so much I even wish I never miss a single day away from him.

reviews.review_title: 1st half is GREAT...2nd half? Not so much
reviews.content: THE FATHER is one of those types of films that, generally, I would not seek out - except at Oscar time. A small, "drawing room" type of drama, based on a stage play and starring a couple of Oscar winning performers at it's core.And that is enough to make this film very entertaining and interesting...but, unfortunately...this piece of entertainment falls flat at the end, so one will have to be contented to watching a decent drawing room drama (based on a Stage play) starring 2 strong Oscar winning actors at it's core.Written and Directed by Florian Zeller, THE FATHER tells the tale of a...well...FATHER, who is aging and mentally deteriorating. His daughter is trying to aide him and bring him comfort, but his befuddled mind begins to see things (conspiracies) that are not there...or are they?Zeller wrote the lead role, specifically for Anthony Hopkins and it is a very good thing that Hopkins agree to this role for he is in EVERY scene and commands this picture as only a performer of Hopkins stature and abilities can. Hopkins is, rightfully, nominated for this performance and could pull the upset (but I highly doubt it).Strongly supporting him - in an Oscar nominated turn herself - as Olivia Colman as his daughter. She has the much less flashy - but no less important - role in this drama and Hopkins would not be as good as he is without her to play against.Zeller (who was nominated for an Oscar for his Screenplay adaptation of his Stage Play) was smart to cast a strong ensemble of British Stage Actors for this film - Mark Gattis, Olivia Williams, Rufus Sewell and Imogen Poots are all strong, interesting people to watch on screen and they help bring an air of seriousness and gravitas to the proceedings.The first half of this film is extremely fascinating to watch and I was intrigued by the premise, the direction, the script and the direction it seemed to be headed. But...unfortunately (at least for me) the 2nd half of the film (and I would imagine, the Stage Play) never, really capitalizes on the promise of the first half and THE FATHER just sorts of peters out in the end.Which, I guess, you could say for the poor souls who suffer from dementia, but I don't think that was the point that Zeller was trying to make.Letter Grade: A- (did I mention that I really, really liked the first half)8 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

reviews.review_title: A tearjerker of a very special kind
reviews.content: An award-winning play is being made for the big screen - and by its director, who had no previous film experience. Can that work? Florian Zeller proves that it can. Dementia-stricken and proud Anthony learns from his daughter Anne that she will soon be moving to Paris. From then on, Zeller narrates the successive decline of Anthony's mind in complex but highly emotional and, above all, human ways.Anthony Hopkins is ideally cast for the lead role of Anthony. On the one hand, he is an empathetic father who means well for his daughter, but on the other, his pride and one-dimensionality make him sullen and critical of her decisions. Hopkins has never been seen in this simplicity. His character does not want to accept that his illness is getting the upper hand and is sure that he can manage without the help of care. At the same time, the increasing memory loss is told exclusively from his point of view, which automatically leads you to sympathise with the protagonist despite his often impossible deeds. This sympathy factor that Hopkins permanently carries with him makes it much easier to relate to him. It is arguably his best performance since his legendary one as Dr Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs, albeit much more nuanced and realistic. While the strong female role at his side then was Jodie Foster, this time it is Olivia Colman as Anthony's daughter Anne. She logically disagrees with her father and does everything possible to organise the help he needs before she leaves for Paris. Colman is the heart of the film. She is heartbreaking in this role and often cannot emotionally withstand the pain that the sight of her suffering father causes her. Her chemistry with Hopkins is also very deep and often one would think that the two actually share this kind of father-daughter relationship. Colman is fragile in her individual scenes, but also forcefully strong and always torn about her father's treatment. Rounding out the great cast are Imogen Poots, Rufus Sewell and Olivia Williams, all constantly taking on different roles due to the confusion in Anthony's head. Williams in particular adds an enormous amount of vulnerability to her few moments, especially the final scene.Zeller has succeeded in a very particular kind of filmmaking with The Father. In its simplicity, the film is nevertheless very complexly constructed, especially in the first hour, and one cannot believe that dementia can apparently really trigger this process in a person's head. Because Hopkins does such a fantastic job of translating this and the editing also relies very effectively on surprise and suddenness, it never becomes too much to bear. Zeller also manages not to make the film seem exclusively sad, but also enriches the plot with thoroughly funny interludes. Basically, however, The Father is a sentimental drama that continuously makes hearts beat faster and that you can hardly get through without shedding a tear. An instructive, authentic and fascinating piece of filmmaking that is an absolute hit for a directorial debut and should be seen by everyone despite the vehemence of its subject matter.

If you have hoped to find a movie that makes you feel like you are trapped in a terrible nightmare, hoping, praying and inexplicably waiting for some sort of twist... look no further because this is that movie.With all the talent in this movie, I really wanted to love it, sadly I am mad at myself for not turning it off because I can never unsee this abomination.Surely the sheep will droll on about how real and deep this is but rest assured it's only "real" and "deep" in the sense that you will really want to jump in the deep end of a hard drink after watching this never ending horror film.

It's not hard to see why this film has resonated so much with people who have direct experience of Alzheimer's in people close to them. The box of film-making and writing tricks that director Florian Zeller (adapting, with Christopher Hampton, his own play) employs is subtle but not so subtle you can't see it. I realised early on that the colour blue would be significant, but the gradual reveal of how and why was harder to predict and expertly unveiled. It's no news that Olivia Colman is brilliant; Anthony Hopkins has been widely praised for this performance, and whilst he didn't blow me away, it's certainly less awards-baiting than I expected. I've heard doctors say that Alzheimer's isn't, after the earlier stages, too distressing for the person suffering; I've always wondered about that, and the film seems a little sceptical too, with the way it puts us in the shoes of the sufferer giving a distressing insight into a disease which is cruel and heart-breaking for all concerned. I hope that people haven't found the film too bleak; that its resonance didn't simply disturb but also offers a measure of healing. That's harder to tell, but it's hard to doubt the film's skill and power.

This is dementia from the sufferer's point of view.Anyone who has spent time around a person slowly losing touch with reality has seen the paranoia, the misplaced confidence, and the fear - each displayed by Anthony Hopkins with unparalleled realism.If you have lost someone or are currently caring for someone with this condition and you know that experiencing it will only cause pain, this movie is certainly capable of bringing pain. But if you want to let the magic of movies show you what others experience - what it is like when you cannot trust your own mind - then go see THE FATHER.

Based on comments (and awards) most people were mostly taken by Hopkins performance in this film. It was apt, i think, he does well. But really what's fine about this film lies elsewhere.Telling a story is, i suppose, a matter of framing a subject. The "what" are you looking at matters not as much as the "who" is looking and, specially "from where". Literature used to explore these paths, but eventually gave way for cinema. Books evolved to a stance of essay and pure thought, but have been abandoning its narrative drive. Cinema picked up on it, and for the moment is still the medium where narratives are experimented (series are, for the moment, mere illustrations of story facts, in the Griffith tradition).So here we have a story of a man in his late moments. He tells the story, apart from a few establishing shots, no action happens outside Hopkins' scope. He is the one we follow, he is our narrator. But he is senil, and what he sees, or remembers, or says, cannot be trusted, not by us, and even less by him. What is true (if anything) and what is not? Here we enter a fantastic, well plowed field of cinematic narrative (and detective fiction) that has to do with the unreliability of what is being told: Rashomon, Roger Ackroyd, Memento... this is not the "look at the drama of the old person in pain", but "how can i live in this world if i can't trust anything".The cinematic tricks here are extremely simple (never abandon Hopkins' stance) and incredibly powerful. What takes away from this are two things:-most of the production seems to have been made around the intent to make Hopkins shine (i imagine that may have been one of his conditions to get on board), so much is focused on his character's suffering, and not on the ambiguity of the narrative-closed spaces (flats, prisions, boats) are a cinematic mine. See what Polansky or Hitchcock did with it in terms of making space into a character, making space tell the story. None of that is here... the sets are lush and fine, i suppose, but they never loose the smell of a set. Filming architecture meaningfully remains one of the most challenging subjects in film.

Anthony Hopkins extraordinary acting notwithstanding, this is the darkest, harshest and most insensitive portrayal of dementia I've ever encountered. While I appreciate the unusual viewpoint and the attempt to convey the experience of the person with dementia, it is a very partial view at best.Having lived with dementia in my own family as well as working with dementia patients professionally, this view is incredibly distorted. Most people who have actually cared for someone with dementia would not characterize it so darkly. There are beautiful, loving, and yes, many funny moments. Dementia is always changing with varying degrees of lucidity--which was not shown in the film. And while there may be despairing moments, dementia patients often feel quite jolly. In other words, they have a full range of feelings just like anyone.But what really stung about this movie was the insensitivity and selfishness of everyone around him. Neither the daughter nor her boy friend had the slightest clue how to respond to someone with memory loss. Their insensitivity was painful. The carer was more on target, and the nurse at the end finally came through in a loving manner.If the intent was an empathic portrayal of dementia, the result falls far short. The scenes where he was a bit jolly fell kind of flat against all the despair and darkness.Dementia, which is a progressive malady, is increasingly and incredibly difficult. And yet, everyone I know, myself included, who has stuck it out with a loved one considers it one of the most rewarding experiences of their lives. Even if it does become necessary to put someone in a facility, it is so important for the loving family caregiver role to continue.This movie could have been so much better if it had been better researched and consulted on by people with actual experience.

It occurred to me to watch this film after hearing a review of it on Nightlife (ABC Local radio, Australia, 06/04/2021). The regular film reviewer, Alexandra Heller-Nicholas, mentioned how it put you into the circumstances of the main character, an elderly man who is losing his mental proficiency. That aspect intrigued me, so I thought that I would see it and this cinematic technique prompts my headline of it being an 'old person simulator'.Anthony Hopkins heads a strong cast as the elderly father of the title, Antony (that's how the cast pronounce the name). He is fiercely independent and resists the attempts of his daughter, Anne (played by Olivia Colman), to have someone look after him at his flat. Hopkins is so believable in his portrayal of a man in those circumstances that it would be quite easy to believe that one was watching a documentary on this topic. For that reason, he deserves to be in contention for Best Actor awards this year.Despite its subject matter, The Father can be funny at times, either because of the occasional boyish charm of Antony or because of the dramatic irony of the things that he says. There was one striking moment for me though, when I caught a glimpse of Hopkins' Hannibal Lecter, near the end of a sequence with Laura, a carer Anne had arranged to meet Antony for the first time that day. Antony was an engineer but up until that moment, amuses her with accounts of what he used to do. These seem like banter to me, rather than symptomatic of anything.If it wasn't for the review on Nightlife, I might not have thought to wonder if the film was playing tricks with me, with regard to a sequence with Antony and a woman telling him that she is his daughter. Later in the film you do get noticeable instances of characters unexpectedly appearing and reappearing again in different form. This is all part of the 'old person simulator' that I speak of. It's engaging as a cinematic device, as I like how it afforded me the opportunity to reinterpret what I had seen before and to try and grasp reality with this knowledge. One way to characterise this cinematic device would be to say that it messes with your head. That is in no way is a negative for the film. Some things remain mysterious without being annoying, like the 'other' daughter that Antony constantly speaks about but whom we never see.Despite the narrative device of an 'old person simulator' being used, I did find some moments more marked for perhaps inexplicable reasons. For example, there is one sequence where Antony overhears a conversation between Anne and her partner. This moment serves as bookends for a sequence. For some reason I found that bookended sequence more incongruous than anything else in the film.In the same way that I enjoyed reinterpreting what I had seen earlier in the film and feeling that I could touch reality with it, I wonder whether Antony could too, at the end. There is dramatic irony in the closing sequence and if Antony does gain the insight that the viewer can, you might feel sure that it is only momentary.Notes to self:* Listening to the music at the start of the film, I felt that it would be a Michael Nyman composition (a frequent collaborator with director Peter Greenaway) but the opening credits proved me wrong. Later on there is some, I assume, classical music which predates Nyman's compositions, which makes me think that the influence is going the other way, as far as Nyman is concerned. In any case, it might be worth buying the soundtrack to this album, as it seems to include both original compositions and classical music repertoire.* An initial query on my part as to the plausibility of the events of this film concerned the woman at the end of the film. I did wonder whether her patience with Antony was believable. Not long after that, I did wonder whether Anne's approach was believable too. In other words, it occurred to me that maybe this story of a daughter and her elderly father might be more believable in another context, for example, if set in France (the film is co-written as well as directed by Frenchman Florian Zeller, based on his earlier play). I'm not familiar with these scenarios in any case, so it might be easily plausible on both counts.* There was one concerning scene between Antony and Anne's partner, where Antony ended up crying. I did wonder whether the incident actually occurred or not.* Lastly, with regard to where the film ended up finishing, I am left to wonder whether what we saw from the start of the film actually occurs before then, as in the film being a sequence of temporal slices which actually happen and are witnessed by the viewer as they happen. If not, then that seems to me to make less incongruous that bookend scene where Antony overhears a conversation between Anne and her partner. However, it now does occur to me that maybe I am put in the position of Antony and one of his 'tests' for whether carers are thieves or not.

reviews.review_title: A Front Row Seat For Falling Apart
reviews.content: An old man and his daughter struggle with his dementia.This is a near-flawless film, and Anthony Hopkins is pitch perfect in every heartbreaking moment as the title character experiencing the pieces of his mind continually slipping through his fingers. After Silence of The Lambs, it's probably his best ever performance.The story is structured and edited in innovative ways to make us, the audience, feel as disorientated and confused as Hopkins, making us experience what he experiences in ways I don't think I've ever quite seen on film before (with the possible exception of Memento). It often feels closer to a horror film than anything else, but in a very quiet, sad, tender way that scares us by hitting so close to mundane, real world fears for ourselves and our loved ones, rather than through jump-scares, gore and violence.It's a very small story, impeccably played out by a very small cast, and perhaps some might find there's not enough surprises or a big enough payoff by the end. But it tells the story it has to tell perfectly well, and is by far the most powerful and compelling depiction of dementia ever put onscreen. I wouldn't be surprised if it turns out to be the best film I see this year, as well.

reviews.review_title: Cleverly crafted and perceptive. Shame about a few factual errors
reviews.content: My sister-in-law and I chose this for our first post-lockdown cinema visit. Both of us have experience of having cared for parents with dementia, although that is not why we chose to see it: indeed, we struggled for a while making up our minds whether it would be wise to watch a movie that had great potential to be triggering. Given the option, we'd probably have chosen something more cheerful! In the end, our decision to watch it came down to the fact that we knew it was a well-regarded piece, and nothing else on our local picture house bill held any appeal at all.I'm glad we saw it. Florian Zeller is to be congratulated for his brilliant trick of playing with the audience's perceptions of who is who, where is where and even when is when, in order to offer some insight into what the world must feel like for someone descending into dementia. He should also be congratulated for the unflinchingly unsentimental treatment of the story. We are presented with the pain, sorrow, conflicted emotions and occasional flashes of humour that make up the "loved one with dementia" experience - sadly, one with which all too many people are familiar - without any overt attempts to manipulate our emotions or tell us how to think. "The Father" is a totally absorbing drama, and Anthony Hopkins (cast - almost disturbingly so - as a man called Anthony) inhabits the role with absolute conviction and believability, supported by a superb ensemble of top-notch talent.Without wishing to rain on its parade, though, I would raise a couple of points of detail re. The care of patients with dementia:1) In the final scene of the film, which takes place in a (clearly very expensive) care home, none of the staff is wearing a name-badge. They should be. It helps the patients keep some kind of grip on who is who in their lives.2) In the same scene, Anthony tries to describe how he is feeling. "I feel as if I'm losing all my leaves," he says - to which the nurse replies "What do you mean?" WRONG: no trained dementia nurse would ever say such a thing to a patient. If the patient were able to assemble the words to express themself more clearly, they would do so, and requiring them to explain what they mean only heightens their distress and anxiety. I'm surprised that this slip-up was not spotted and removed from what is an otherwise excellent script.

I won't elaborate here on Anthony Hopkins's superlative performance. It was superlative, but I've got nothing more to say about it that wasn't said already. Same is true of the rest of the cast - they were all amazing, but that's not my point. What I want to speak about is the cinematic brilliance of this entire experience (as it was much more than just a movie).Let us begin with the fact that the whole story is seen through the eyes of the father - which means that we the viewers are as lost as he is. We can't tell what's going on and it shakes us to the core.Now, let's speak about camera angles, in this movie the camera angles talks. They tell us things that Florian Zeller wants to tell us without saying them aloud. Think about the number of times you saw a horizontal picture of a wall with a door cracked open in the middle, but the camera didn't get any closer it was kept were we could see the wall at both sides of the door. Because Florian Zeller wants us to know there's a wider picture here - we simply don't get to see it since he, the director, doesn't want us to see it. And now let's try and count the number of long corridors with closed doors on both sides, usually dark corridors this is an old visual hint that our hero is moving on an unescapable rout to his destiny. No matter what he does - this story will end the same waySo you see, I love this movie because on top of a great performance and a great story - it speaks cinema. And now think of the fact that this is Florian Zeller's first movie. All he did so far is write brilliant plays the very first time he does cinema, he speaks its language as fluently as the very best. If that's not genius I don't know what is.It's dark and depressing but it's a masterpiece you simply have to see.

Reality crumbles out of your hands and you feel absolutely helpless in front of what is happening. That's life with dementia. You become a hostage of your worn-out brain, which serves no longer as before. Happy moments of the past are intertwined with sad ones and manifest themselves again. You can't trust your friends, family, especially yourself. The world is collapsing, and you're trying to hold it.We see all this from the face of the hero Anthony Hopkins. Despite the subject matter, this is not only a drama, but rather a puzzle film, where we collect the real picture of what is happening in disparate parts.After watching it, I talked for a long time with my grandmother, who took care of a relative with dementia. After this, you start to look at life a little differently. The film is worth watching for everyone. The best picture of 2020 after the Land of Kachevnikov.

I had to take multiple breaks because it felt so long. There's a lot of repetition, which is what the director and screenwriters wanted, but it does get boring since the audience has already seen this exact scene already.All in all, The Father brings a sad and realistic story that can and will get boring depending on who's viewing it. POSITIVES:1) Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman both deliver the best performances of their career in my opinion. Breathtakingly amazing. Hopkins deserved the Oscar
2) The way the film makes the setting, mainly the flat, seem like its own character was extremely well done. I found the film becomes claustrophobic because of how much the flat becomes like a prison. Anthony is always looking at the window but never once do we see him go outside
3) The way the film plays with time and narrative is genius. As an audience member we feel like we are the ones slowly losing our minds, just like Anthony. The way scenes loop back round on each other and get seen from slightly different perspectives really kept me engaged
4) The emotion of the film was incredibly impactful to me, partly because I have experienced this to a certain extent in my family, but also because the film and the performances are masterfulNEGATIVES:1) Anthony became difficult to sympathise with at times when he was being rude, belittling or even hostile towards his daughter and his carer. I understand that this probably adds to the realism of the film, but as a character it made me find Anthony too frustrating at times
2) I wish there was just 10 minutes at the end where we went back and saw the film objectively / through Anne's eyes. I left the film still confused about which events actually happened and which didn't, in what order things were meant to have happened, was Paul really rude and aggressive towards Anthony or was all that made up?

There have been very few movies that make me want to pause the movie halfway to fully look at my partners face to tell them how amazing this movie is. A wonderfully and beautifully told story of such a sad and depressing topic. It leaves you questioning what's going on in the same tone that the main character, Antoine, is questioning his episodes. Amazing story telling with beautiful music interwoven throughout. A magnificent performance from Anthony Hopkins. Bravo.
