reviews.content: After watching this movie I really have a great understanding not only with dementia but with old age. How can you keep up with the present if your reality keeps messing up in a matter of minutes with different details? 😢 This is very heartbreaking to watch and you'll be left there with all of the emotions of someone who has this illness. 😢 I just love how amazing Anthony Hopkins portray Anthony here. He's really a great actor. So awesome performance.

reviews.review_title: It seems as if I'm losing all my leaves!
reviews.content: What an impressive and moving movie! I really enjoyed the play and the real acting of Sir Anthony Hopkins and his caring daughter Olivia Coleman. This is a movie I reccomend everybody to watch.

This film will tug at your heart strings. Anthony Hopkins takes us on a ride that many of us will deal with someday, dementia. With every emotion he acts out you feel that emotion deep in your soul. After the movie it took awhile for myself to disengage from it.

The movie is just incredible, first, the cinematography is beautiful, and the movie looks gorgeous, the acting is just insanely great, Anthony Hopkins is at his best here, giving a truly Oscar winning performance, you can fell his confusedness, you can really enjoy the good and happy moments he has with his love ones, but also the moments of sadness and loneliness too. And that's not all, Olivia Colman is also great, and you can feel how fragile the situation is to her in every scene, how challenging it is, and how she just loves Anthony. Imogen Poots has a bit of screen time too, and she is also pretty good, Mark Gatiss as always as well. Anyways, the cast is great.But probably what makes this movie different from everything I have ever seem is the structure of the story itself, the constant changing of scenarios, and actors or even characters suddenly, with often conflicting information been given by more than one character, puts you in Anthony's shoes, and see how just helpless a person on that situation feels like, and how insanely confusing everything is.The mix of this perfect story structure, with top notch performances, makes this movie just an immersive and breathtaking experience from start to finish. I loved it.

Anthony Hopkins plays a man suffering from dementia and having to deal with his daughter Anne played brilliantly by Olivia Colman caring for him. Hopkins is equally brilliant. You feel his sense of loses his mind and not knowing what is real and what is not. The film is so beautifully written and constructed. The film is so well acted by Colman and Hopkins. At times it is hard to watch and you really feel for the characters. I think it is one of best films you can see right now. I can see why it got so many Oscar nominations. I would not be surprised if Hopkins and Colman both win. It is a deeply moving film that will stay with you for a long time.

reviews.review_title: A Truly Daunting and Devastating Ride
reviews.content: 82/100The Father is a truly mesmerizing, seamless and devastating placement into the perspective of an aging and mentally ill man. all of the twists and turns faced by Anthony in the film are just as daunting and confusing for the viewer as they are for him in the film, and it makes this film a brutal but addicting watch. The movie is a seemingly endless episode of The Twilight Zone and i could have been captivated by it for at least another 30 minutes of added runtime. Hopkins and Colman both deliver master class and award-worthy performances as one would expect, just adding on to the greatness of the film

An amazing film for a first feature. A brutal subject that has been a theme in several movies, but this one goes deeper allowing us to see from a different point of view. Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman never disappoint, both gave astonishing performances.

The heartfelt, touching cinematic portrayal of family, growing old and the meaning of life. A high-profile acting duo combine in the most moving of manners to help shape one of the finest film displays of recent years.A man refuses all assistance from his daughter as he ages. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, he begins to doubt his loved ones, his own mind and even the fabric of his reality.Anthony Hopkins continues to defy the years in a masterful performance. The 84-year-old Welsh actor received his second Academy Award since his first in 1992. Along side fellow Oscar winner, in 2019, nominated for her role in this picture, Olivia Coleman demonstrates the maturity and acting expertise to ensure Florian Zeller's watch is one of care and consideration. Seeing the pair's work in the film is entertaining enough, even if the storyline is slow and sterile. The movement is a psychological challenge for Anthony who's mental frame is deteriorating much to his reluctance. The character glistens in fragments of the spectacle, shining in his quirky actions and vibrant personality which contrasts to his cold-hearted moments of refusal in light of assistance, particularly from his daughter, Anne. Coleman is the resting shoulder offering her services and help that the former requires, she is understanding in her outlook and emotional in the turbulence of events. The two were rightly credited for their displays, and are showcase respectively that they are getting better with age.The film reminds us as an audience the importance of family. Those older than us may no longer be themselves in the future and see us in a different light. It highlights the value of love and appreciating every moment we spend in life with family members and friends. The Father is an illustration of a reality check we all ought to take, depicting serious, philosophical subjects in an honest fashion to convey its moral message.Picture perfect!

This movie is really something for a second there I really thought am I watching this movie or I'm the part of it.This is one of those movies where it plays mind games with you, confuse you, thrills you and finally shows you the harsh reality how it can be scary sometimes.Sir Anthony Hopkins did a great job, he's acting was just magnificent and he really deserved the oscar for it.

I have nothing to add to the informative and interesting assessments of this great movie. Just for clinical interest....many reviewers mention Alzheimers, but my husband, who's a psychiatrist, felt Anthony's dementia was caused by Lewy Body Disease. It's very common, but not as well known by its name and is most often characterized by hallucinations and cognitive disonance, along with the memory loss it shares with Alzheimers.

Dementia.
Spoiler, this may not end well, but that's not the point.In Florian Zeller's "The Father", a one room play turned expertly into a gripping two hours of cinema, the blubbery heartbreak or the cheerleadery miracle usually reserved for this genre are absent. Instead we are tricked into inhabiting Anthony Hopkin's wandering mind. And it is an unsettling, frightful, place, where surroundings shift, names change, events may or may not happen, bluster resides, and paranoia reigns. Perspective is thrown out the window. Yet each vignette seems real enough to believe. The hopeful ones are easy to cling to. The harsh ones are shattering.As his taxed daughter, her father's lone connection to a world that is slowly leaving him, Olivia Colman makes this a two actor tour de force. Her conflict, to live for herself or offer selfless support, is an anvil sized weight on both of their minds. Yet it is unclear which direction she favours, if in fact she favours any at all. Sprinkled with just enough amusing asides - the obsessive infatuation with and reliance on a watch for instance - there is enough levity for Hopkins to stretch like he's never stretched before. The two leads are fabulous on screen.Just as the play starts to roll, it changes gears. The flat is different. The characters too. A promised plan is no longer on the table. What is this? Who are they? Where are we? What is reality? And who's reality is it? Infuriating, but cleverly diabolical, these curve balls are subtle enough not to jar, but they do build to a powerful crescendo. It is a bit of an accomplishment to deliver a series of deliberately confusing acts without losing the audience to frustration. Oh there is frustration, but that is part of the experience. This is not an easy view, but a worthwhile one.hipCRANK

This is easily one of the best films I've seen in a very very long time. Anthony Hopkins delivers an incredible and flawless performance. I can't imagine anyone else more deserving of an Oscar this year!
I love Anthony Hopkins from the first time I saw him in The silence of the lambs.Amazing performance, very good movie , very very moving and touching.Worth to watch it.

reviews.review_title: Love Anthony Hopkins - Hated this movie.
reviews.content: I'm rating two stars only because of the splendid acting of Anthony Hopkins, otherwise this movie would only be worthy of one star. Yes, it must be terrible going through dementia, which is the only point of this movie. Otherwise there is virtually no story-line other than the poorly executed teaser about the possible accidental death of Anthony's other daughter. I felt suffocated watching this movie and constant replaying of the same events over and over. While I absolutely enjoy all movie genres, be they comedies, dramas, musicals, etc., I do want to be entertained, enlightened, or educated, and this movie fails to deliver. Simply awful.

reviews.review_title: This will happen to everyone in the fuure.
reviews.content: A few years ago, I went to the retirement home to see my grandmum."Who ... are you?"My sister and I looked at each other with bitter laughs involuntarily. My grandmum remembers my sister who comes there sometimes, but seems to forget me who go back home town only once or twice a year.This movie is depicted from the perspective of dementia patient. It's filled of a lot of sadness, but is also splendid.If it's depicted from the perspective of a person who supports dementia patient, it's probably easier to empathize to him/her. I'm sure it's tough when a person who I love is getting to forget me gradually and becoming like a kid. I can imagine it a little.Through the perspective of protagonist, he didn't realise that he got demented. He just feels that everyone says disconnected words. Something which he can't understand happanes. But he believes he saw someone for sure and listened to something even if anyone says that it's not true. But that's surely true for him. When he talked about things that he heard the day before, her daughter told him that she didn't say that on that day. Also, the next day, she fed up with that because she told that before. That's why it's so confusing. Everyone 's confused. Nobady's fault.It is he, not anyone else, who suffers from dementia the most. I hope we can find the way to a cure for such a sad illnesses which suffers them and people who they love soon in the future.

reviews.review_title: Watch if you want to be depressed and not be entertained.
reviews.content: I appreciate that Anthony Hopkins is a skilled actor and so forth, but I gave the movie The Father a 1/10, a fat ONE. - I am not a member of the 1% who needs a movie to experience how depressed life can be. For me movies are an escape pod to a few joyful, entertaining moments. I don't understand why movies are made to depress us. Who are the people that actually like to watch how old people embarrass themselves? This is so extremely sad. Go for love and enjoy life. - Well, okay a 3/10 because it wasn't ALL bad.

I never write reviews, but this movie shook me to the core! Anthony Hopkins is brilliant in his role, his performance left me breathless at times, especially towards the end. You can feel his pain. Olivia Coleman is also fantastic, there is so much emotion in her acting. This is by far the best movie I have seen in the last years and can only recommend it.
Devastating. A masterpiece. It must have had a great research team to display the struggles so accurately. Anthony Hopkins never disappoints.

I'm at a loss for words, I just can't describe the mix of emotions I felt watching this movie. The editing of the film is wonderful, in the beginning everything seems very confusing, in fact, until the end of the film many of the things are still confused. However, I believe that this is what the film wants to go through when we watch it, this is how it goes in the head of a person with Alzheimer's, this is really how he feels ... Confused, confused with everything, confused with his feelings and confused why people don't understand what happens to them.It is certainly one of the best films I have ever seen in my life, it is about a daughter's true love towards her father, it is about the obstacles that she has to face in relation to her illness and the extent to which she could take it this ... After all, we are all human, nobody is made of iron and to what extent can we endure situations like these by someone we love?I really hope this movie wins some Oscars, I will advise everyone!

One of the best movies of this year.Both Oscars are absolutely well deserved!The screenplay is so original and the actors' performances are all stunning.This is a different way to tell a story that will leave you as disoriented and surprised as the main character himself.Sometimes I kinda felt like watching Memento by Nolan, even if we're talking about really different things.Its strength it's in details and originality.Not for everyone.
Loving the story plot and the emotional shared between the cast is so deep and I really love this movie.

Just look into the film only because Anthony Hopkins won the Best Actor award at Oscar 2021, but along with his performance the film provides something new. Already went through lot of movies dealing with the subject, 'dementia' or some sort of mental problems but this one found a different path of story telling. A new way of narrative technique were we just fell along with Anthony and the surprises on his way and the revelations that he is undergone. He was exceptional in his role and that is unquestionable because we saw the shade in the well-known Hannibal Lector. This one is completely opposite to it because the physicality is even less here than in The Silence of Lambs. Here he is an octogenarian, a man struggling with dementia. Hopkins wonderfully carried that character. Not but the least Olivia Colman's Anne was also superb. Hats off to the production designer and the Editor too.
This was extremely well acted and was very moving, but I felt it jumped around too much I know its supposed to show the confusion but it felt a little too rushed and unexplained.

I don't usually watch dramatic movies, but honestly, I don't regret watching this one, it's really heart touching and at the end I tried to resist crying but I couldn't, the acting is just sooo good and I think everyone should watch it.

reviews.review_title: Can't stop crying.... Brilliant from beginning to end.
reviews.content: I knew this was a film I wanted to see because Anthony Hopkins was in it. I wasn't able to view it before now, I had missed seeing it when released last year and I knew he had won the well deserved Oscar- and I knew it would be a phenomenal film, because he won best actor for it, but nothing could've prepared me for the gut, wrenching experience of seeing the world through the eyes of a man who no longer knows who he is ...experiencing this disintegration over time along with all the confusion and anger that goes with it -the grief that is not able to be fully consciously cognitively realized and processed and the pain of family who can't bring comfort... incredible, tender, caring of residential staff members who are there to pick up the pieces at the end. This film is both beautiful and heartbreaking a testament to the compassion of all who care for, and have experience with this painful demise that is the journey of so many who suffer from dementia.
Anthony Hopkins really delivered an incredible performance. Sad and touching movie.

What an ABSOLUTELY incredible film. Sir Anthony Hopkins is really unforgettable. He deserves ALL the awards for this film.His portrayal of someone with dementia is spot on. The toll it takes on not only the patient suffering but those around them and their loved ones will bring you to tears.Not only is it a must watch if you can handle it but for those with loved ones going through it then its some incredible insight into the devastating world of dementia. BRAVO to this incredible film, cast and creators.... all the awards I tell you. I haven't been this moved about a film in ages. #thefather #siranthonyhopkins.

reviews.review_title: A Film thats going to leave you Broken !!!
reviews.content: A devastating portrayal of Dementia told through a masterpiece of a film, where the audience is thrust into the mind of Sir Anthony Hopkins and gives you a truly unique experience of how it feels when your reality crumbles and changes every 5 minutes, you dont know what or who is real anymore, you lose your perception of time. We, the outsiders, in our ignorance, might get annoyed or angry at their hysterics but we dont know how their world is crashing down around them and they can just helplessly watch. Sir Anthony gives one of his career best performance, rivalling his Hannibal Lecter, and breaks our heart into million pieces. Olivia Colman is also superb as his daughter. The set design, editing, direction, music, cinematography all are top notch. A really important film for understanding Dementia and its Terrible Reality.

reviews.review_title: That's the great cinema when you feel what protagonist is feeling
reviews.content: More movies like this and sound of metal should come so that people can understand the lives of the people suffering from these diseases.
Anthony Hopkins is finished the acts on the big screen by his role in this movie. It is as usual performed by the lonely Anthony made me crying.He must have the Oscar this year.

First of all I really like Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman, but this has to be the most depressing film I've seen in a long time.When it actually ends your left thinking "is that it?"The acting is very good, but not my type of film.

reviews.review_title: I do not know if I will be ready to ...
reviews.content: I hope she will come and see me sometime. Do you think ? Mommy.You were saying she might come occasionally at the weekend. My mommy.(Start to cry) I want my mommy. I want get out of here. Have,have someone come and fetch me. No,no,I want my mommy. I want her to come and fetch me. I want to go home. I feel as if I am losing all my leaves. The branches and the wind and the rain. I do not know what is happening anymore. Do you know what is happening? All this business about the flat. I have nowhere to put my head down anymore. But I know my Watch is on my wrist, thatI do know. For the journey. If not,I do not know if I will be ready to ...------- The father.
This film is exceptional. Masterful performances from everyone, incredible screen play, beautifully executed.

This is a Tour De Force, Superb acting from Hopkins, Colman and such a clever film, confusing the audience as he is confused. This is a tough watch, if you know someone who is like this. But this is Acting at it's Best, Hopkins deserved the Oscar, the final scenes Hopkins blows the screen apart, WOW.

A punch in the stomach. A film that shows the struggle of people suffering from Alzheimer so realisticaly that makes you feel uncofrotable.A movie i wouldn't suggest to sensitive people with relatives who suffer from this difficult disease. A movie I would deffinetly suggest to people that want to know how it feels like.An oscaric perfomance by Anthony Hopkins, probably the best of his entire life.

Last movie I saw I liked of his was his supporting role in Meet Joe Black, he's acting just gets better with age... This time dealing with Dementia and questioning his every move, very well made and supporting actress Olivia Coleman, playing his loyal daughter... Very moving to watch... Cleverly made leaving the audience questioning what's real and feeling disoriented, a great movie!
Anything below a 10 is not acceptable for this masterpiece.

Being a Hopkins fan, I was looking forward to seeing his latest film, playing an old man entering the final chapter of his life.The film is brilliantly played by Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, but was far too violent to my heart for me to say I enjoyed it.Having fairly recently gone through a very similar experience with my own father just a few years ago, the film brought back, with shining clarity, all of the horrible memories of his final months.
Absolute masterpiece. Loved it. Anthony was brilliant.

Finally I've found a movie I can rate as a 10.Anthony Hopkins (one of my favourite actors) so deserved an Oscar for this role, a truly exceptional performance!A bit slow at times but that's necessary for the plot development.The storyline is so well written, it sympathetically gives the viewer a taste of the confusion one must feel when suffering from dementia.Olivia Coleman is also brilliant as his daughter Anna who struggles to deal with her father's declining condition before accepting the inevitable.This is a truly exceptional film, thought provoking not entertaining per say, but it's humanity is undoubted!

reviews.review_title: I Gave Up After 59 Minutes, 45 Seconds
reviews.content: My title says it. I watched his film for an hour until I said, enough. I wasn't going to be one who said I wasted the full 1:37. I had already wasted an hour and I quit. It was going nowhere and I had no anticipation that the other 37 minutes would be any better. I'd say if you go 30 minutes and don't get it, then you probably will not at all.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant Depiction of A Terrible Disease
reviews.content: If you've ever had a loved one live with Alzheimer's or dementia, you'll see this is about as honest an depiction of the disease. I felt like some of the scenes were taken from conversations I've had with my gran.The story is well delivered and Hopkins delivers a superb performance.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: The performance is so damn enjoyable
reviews.content: The Father is a movie that starts with subtle elements to soothe our mind. The film goes on keeping a steady pace from start to finish which will be suited for many people but not for everyone. Anthony Hopkins, Olivia Williams literally put their soul into this film and delivered their one of the best, especially Anthony Hopkins who's character is so damn enjoyable in the whole 90 minutes run. Screenplay is put together so well. With all it's elements combined this movie has its own thing to bind the audience in it's own thrill and questions. Overall The Father is a movie which everyone will recommend others to watch. For some people it may fall in one time watch club and for others it will take position in multiple time watches.
Compelling and wonderfully acted film, which evokes questions and emotions you won't be able to shake of. Anthony Hopkins is completely outstanding.

Anthony Hopkins performance in this film is so unbelievably, amazingly heartbreaking.Florian Zeller tells a story focused around dementia that is super well edited and will take you on a wild, jarring, ride that's complimented beautifully with a very serene and emotional score.I did feel like for an hour and a half runtime it was a bit slow, but I was in for the ride and the pacing never bothered me at all. This film really messes around with time, reality, and perception in such a fascinating, confusing and heartbreaking way that seemed really special and unique.It's definitely worth the watch especially for Hopkins breathtaking performance alone.

The perspective from which the story is told is incredibly innovative and illuminating. Decades of life disintegrating while the body goes on. Makes you question what life really means when all is said and done.

I am astonished at this film's impact and the effusive praise for it and the performances. I had to keep ff-ing rather than abandon it, but it didn't improve. My problem is that I have worked in neuropsychology, and especially with dementia, over many years, and this rendition is lacking lacking lacking. Hopkins didn't impress me nor did the script or anything else. Utterly boring and not, to me, authentic, however, when so many of the general public seem to draw something from it, I can only defer to them. Dementia is a much more exciting and interesting condition than portrayed here.

Ingenious insight into dementia. Almost completely convincing and the acting of Hopkins and Colman wonderful.So why wouldn't I give it more than 8?I suppose really it is the limitations of scene and time scale. It plays like a stage play and also the there is no progression of Anthony's disease. Rather it is a gradual realisation of what stage the disease has progressed.But I'd certainly recommend it highly and pleased I watched it.

Wonderfully shot and acted. Thoughtful approach to dementia and insights into how muddled the mind can become, messing with time. This will do more for your long-term care planning than anything else.8/10.

This is the best acted, presented and directed movie I have seen in ages. All the actors involved were superb, especially Hopkins of course.When the movie finished, and still now, it had me thinking about my own life and relationships a lot.I would recommend this movie to anyone, and would happily watch it again. It made me cry, especially that heart-wrenching ending!

The Father is a good movie and depiction of dementia. It is heartwrenching to see an old man lose his sense of reality and how this effects his daugther.This movie really plays with perspective as we see the confusing life of a man with Alzheimers. Altough its done on purpose the whole movie is quite tedious, nothing big really happens and there are no real plot points except the disease and paranoia of this man.The acting is absolutely top class and this movie can really evoke emotions, but at the end of the day this is not my type of movie as I found it quite boring and annoying at times.

reviews.review_title: And the Oscars goes to this movie
reviews.content: Wow wow Anthony Hopkins and the director did incredible work , the story is very simple but the way they show you how the mind tricks the old, yes the movie is emotional but it is worth every minute .

I can't decide if its a clever movie that's about dementia or just a clever movie that uses Alzeimers as it's medium. Anyone who has experienced Alzeimers knows these movies are just popcorn representations of what's involved .

reviews.review_title: A real synonym of perfect is here
reviews.content: Oh my God!!!! I really dont have words to explain this movie. I really live the way in which we are also passing through the same disease from which Anthony is passing through. I really was so much curious to know what happens in end so that I know what was happening in this whole movie. And in last scene after watching it,I like kind of felt the numbness of my life and and saw it very closely. The way Anthony acts Oh God it was toooooo perfect. I can watch this movie again and again seriously. I do got the movie but for 100% complete satisfaction I watched the explanation of this movie and after watching it I love this movie even more.

After watching this movie, I have an idea of what dementia patients suffer and let me just say that I don't wish this fate on anyone I hate.Anthony Hopkins brought such a beautiful and realistic performance to his character. I felt like crying a couple of times, that's how moved I was.I hope many people watch this movie and when they do, I hope they learn to be more patient with Alzheimer and dementia patient. They are really suffering.

reviews.review_title: Had huge expectations but got very little
reviews.content:
Apart from great acting of the cast I didn't liked anything else from this film..
.Well it's my personal opinion
Story didn't worked out well for me
Screenplay same
At the end I was left completely disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant acting in a film about compassion and sorrow
reviews.content: Lets start this review with Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. They make this film to a masterpiece, brilliantly subtile in their acting and in the twists and turns of this drama. But all the actors in the film is making a great performance and becomes a perfect conducted reflection of the sanity and craziness that comes with the sickness of dementia.The film is based on a stage play and you feel it in the dialouge that is both poetic and emotional without being overacted or to obvious.The film has a nightmarish feel to it without losing the warmth and depth of the human relations.The sadness of getting old or see someone you love get old is in a tender way portrayed by Hopkins and Colman all the way to the very moving ending.Hopkins acting in this film should be a must to watch for every young actor or actress that want to know how to be convincing and true on screen.

Such a moving film. Anthony Hopkins is the star and is brilliant and kudos must be given to the writer and the direction. This movie portrays the confusion and frustration of all the parties involved. I loved this from start to finish. Sad, depressing but poignant.

reviews.review_title: I just hope his daughter gets the same destiny
reviews.content: When her time comes, shall his grandchildren put her in the same institution and even in the SAME ROOM of his. Quoting the movie: "It'd be better for HER". And finally, suggesting an idea for a Part 2 of the movie: he ultimately dies and reincarnates as her nurse...

I've never written a review before. I'm a big film buff but no matter how good or bad a movie is I just can't be bothered. This film has made me bother. The film as a whole is fantastic, the dialogue, staging, sets and story. Everyone in this film puts in a fantastic performance but Hopkins is captivating. I think it may be his best performance. And he's Anthony Hopkins! Within any scene, he just turns on a dime and delivers his lines more convincingly than I've ever seen an actor do. Anthony Hopkins deserves the Oscar for this movie.

This is the first time i have ever given an IMDB rating.Thought about it so many times, but no movie was so good that i just had to rate it.This was!What a movie, and what a performance by Anthony Hopkins. No doubt he deserved that oscar 100%. Maybe the best performence i've ever seen in this type of role.The movie is so authentic and sad but at the same time so good.Watch it now.

This movie broke my heart about a thousand times, and quite frankly in the beginning/first half: I thought I was losing my mind. What is scarier is that this is a real possibility for me. As I get older, I worry about it more and more. Genetically, we thought my paternal grandmother had Alzheimer's (when it was first being recognized). Then, my father "had the cardiovascular system of an 80yo" in his 40s. Blamed cigarettes. Fast forward to when I was 40yo. A neurologist told me I had a problem that is only found in 80yo people or "is there something genetic to this?" Well. I've been terrified since.Now, what these people SHOULD have done was have photos of his daughters/wife around him AND a current calendar. This helps so much (till they become really out of control and think everyone is conspiring, but not many places mass produce calendars for the future with all sorts of information on them). Even then, you can reason with them to a point. My grandmother was so much better with 100 calendars, and we kept old ones with photos of her (and grandpa) together: A calendar from 1925 accompanied by photos of her, gramps and my father as a baby. Just a tip to try to help anyone reading this. You'll do anything to spare them this if you can.Ok, the movie, I'm sorry: Excellent and devastating. The acting was wonderful, and I'm glad they didn't have a huge cast. Two Olivias playing Anns. Truly a heartbreaking movie and I cried more than once. And to add to the sadness, you have to see everyone else's point of view. The struggling daughter, the impatient husband, the young caregiver trying to be the good girl which mingled more with his mind...it was a rough ride. But I do NOT regret watching it. I'm going to suggest my children and grandchildren watch it as well.

reviews.review_title: It was something that I have never experienced before.
reviews.content: The Father was a well-done movie. There were many things that I have liked about it. First of all, Anthony Hopkin's acting was incredible. He excellently represented the inner conflicts and emotions of his character that the audience also felt. He is one of the best names in acting even when he is old. Secondly, storytelling was incredible. This kind of storytelling is something that many of us have never experienced before. Even though it got really confusing, it felt really realistic in a way that you think you are actually suffering from it. With the combination of storytelling and acting, you can easily get into the story. Finally, the length of the movie was just okay. I think it would get really out of hand if the movie was about 2.30 hours long.However, I didn't like the complexity that the movie tries to create very much. I know it is the point of it, but it starts to make everything harder for the audience, in my opinion. I believe it is not a good idea to reveal the truth after creating so much confusion. I think this way because, after a moment, you can't remember every detail about the previous scenes, and it becomes hard for you to make connections and realize the reality in the movie. I know that the last scene of the film was powerful. But it still annoyed me a bit and dropped my pleasure of watching because I couldn't grasp what was actually going on. Maybe, that is the point.

reviews.review_title: Say to love your dad if you can..!
reviews.content: The story is to portray about the old and Alzheimer dad, but it's so tender, sentimental and real honestly. It can't deny that the leading actor is a legend and totally agree with why he got an Oscar award. Beside, the way of telling story makes me feel touch, sad, and laugh sometimes. It's hard to tell people what Alzheimer people think, but this movie can show visually these concerns. Honestly, the relationship between my dad and I isn't smooth and rich, however, I need to think again about this relationship after done this movie.

reviews.review_title: Hallucinations and paranoia, resentment and despair
reviews.content: Poor Anthony. He is confused. Who's taken his watch, what's happened to his daughter, and where the hell is he? He is confused, but defiant. He refuses help. He insists he will outlive those who are plotting against him. If you know someone with dementia, or even if you don't, this film will ultimately make you feel sympathy for the one who has it yet does not realize it. It's like being in a hostage situation, while being stuck in a time warp. Such a person, like Anthony, may be irritating but is ultimately to be pitied. You wouldn't want to be in his shoes. "Nobody tells me anything," he declares. "I'm not an idiot," he insists. These are statements someone with the condition would typically make. Anthony Hopkins plays Anthony brilliantly, and he is well-supported by a competent cast. Go watch this movie, and leave with eyes opened.

This is a difficult film, difficult to experience and even more difficult to digest. And that is precisely why it is a brilliant work! Another theater play brought to the cinema, as it has been in fashion lately, but what an extraordinary way to do it. This is the film that answers the question that we all must have asked ourselves even for a brief moment: "what would it be like to live with dementia?" Through the direccional choices we are transported to Anthony's mind and, consequently, confronted with a distorted perception of reality which, no matter the effort we make to understand, ends up being incomprehensible.The film lives and dies by its interpretations (like any good play) and Oliva Colman and Anthony Hopkins are at the peak of their game. Olive with a measured, smooth, but meaningful interpretation; Hopkins in the best performance of his career (and that's saying something!) shows us everything he is capable of, starting the film full of layers that will be removed throughout until nothing is left, the confidence and charm that we know of so many psychopaths that he's portrayed until the vulnerability of a small child and with everything in between.The director only admitted to making this film with Anthony Hopkins in the main role, hence the name of the character, and we can understand why.When, at the end, you hear the rustle of leaves as the camera flies over the park, we are left with a thud in our hearts and are overwhelmed by the fear that one day we will be able to experience in ourselves what we have just experienced on the screen. Still, this is an exercise that we should all do, everyone should see this film.Deep, Touching, ... Terrifying, here is: The Father.Undoubtedly the Film of the Year and the Interpretation of a Lifetime!

Especially the load and stress for the family members, how quick the mood of people with Alzheimer can change and their panic and fear when they realize that their memories fade were so realistic (and incredible performed by Anthony Hopkins).We are really happy that other people can see how an Alzheimer disease really works and about the sensibility they discussed this, for us critical, topic. I like it very much. It belongs to high-level works at the script and performance levels. Adapted from the stage play, the scene is more concentrated and single, but it can go deeper into the character's heart and create a strong sense of narrowness. Going in to watch this, I knew this film would resonate with me. Anthony Hopkins gives an absolutely stellar performance of a man suffering from the hourly/daily kaleidoscopic twists and turns of dementia. I've never cried watching a movie..until now. Unforgettable.This movie will stay with me for years. A sad insight into growing old.

The Father; the film ends and the cinema auditorium is silent, a very sombre atmosphere. That's because it's an extremely emotional film, I didn't cry in the cinema but I did when I was alone in my car. Anthony Hopkins is incredible, as is Olivia Colman and the supporting cast including Olivia Williams and Mark Gatiss.It's a disorientating film, hard to know when one scene ends and another starts. Often there is repetition of the same dialogue, altered through slight changes in setting and major changes in character as seen through the eyes and mind of the father. I'd say it's one of the most original films I've seen, in terms of its structure, both in the way the story is told and how the audience along with the father is unsure of who's who. It very much reminded me of Michael Haneke's, Amour, in places, especially the inner city grandiose setting of the flat. Florian Zeller is the director, who also wrote the screenplay from the play the film is based on, which Zeller also wrote.

My mom died last year, in 2020, six years after being diagnosed with Alzheimer's. She had lived with us for 15 years helping to raise my kids, and it was nice having her be a part of our family until the very end.There are many things in this movie that just don't comport with the reality of how a family deals with a family member with Alzheimer's. Good families know how to de-escalate situations, and to create a safe environment for the family member with Alzheimer's. You don't question or raise doubt about something they should have remembered from yesterday. It does not help. This includes the end of the moive when Anthony gets the full attention of his nurse caregiver who is there even to go on two walks a day with him. Based on my experience with multiple memory care facilities in the USA, that level of care is simply not to be found. When I checked my mom into facilities for short respite stays, the cost is very high, the food, and quality of care is marginal at best. No one gets individualized care. One place left my mom in a wet bed all day. If it were not for my business trips I would have kept her home all the time.If you wanted to create a movie that showed how hard it can be on a family to care for someone with Alzheimer's they could have showed changing wet bedding every day, or the struggle of getting them into a bathtub to take a bath. My mom would cause ringing in my ears from screaming as I try to give her a bath. Bottom line, this movie was not very true to the reality of the situation family members face.However Anthony Hopkins did a tremendous acting job worthy of his Oscar winning performance and the cinematography of this movie was amazing. It was very inventive how the scenes worked to confuse the audience and give us a sense of what Alzheimer's is like. For these reasons alone the movies deserves a viewing, even though I found it frustratingly removed from the reality of caring for someone with this horrible disease.

Hopkins delivers a performance of a lifetime- nuanced, graceful, elegant and emotionally overwhelming. I have seldomly emphasized this much with a character on screen. Simply thinking about certain moments bring up a distressing feeling inside my body and mind. Hopkins vulnerable acting is masterfully transported onto the viewer, he is the core of the film, this is by all means his film.But lest we forget the expertly crafted direction of Florian Zeller who constantly shakes us up with the disorienting unfolding and modification of events. He doesn't deceive us by inserting distasteful pathetic music choices but rather uses music only when it is really warranted and doesn't take anything from the performances away. Thus a healthy co-existence is created and the film doesn't feel emotionally manipulative.As I said, this is a devastating film whose overall nature lingers with you long after the credits roll. A film which makes you remember why cinema is often called an "empathy machine". It is because of films like these.
I'll give it 9 because this movie almost made me cry, but I recommend it. Superlative job from Hopkins, he really makes you feel all the trama from the perspective of the main character.

reviews.review_title: An engaging and haunting film of empathy
reviews.content: Heartbreak and confusion are two ideas and themes I've encountered before in my life. But never before have I seen it so brutally abused in The Father. The Father doesn't just tell a story about the character Anthony and his scenario, rather it places us into the mind of Anthony and his mental deterioration, showing us the heartbreak that is experienced by the ones around him and the confusion and even acceptance of his own situation. At one point, Anthony' consciousness fully acknowledges that he is a burden to his family members in a dramatic, and devastating scene. It's unsettling and sad, and the films depiction of caring for a loved one with dementia is what we possibly may experience later in our lives, even now. And it's this idea of empathy through the audience and fictional characters that Florian Zeller communicates through the film with his heartfelt and unbearable narrative.I happened to catch this in theatres today, as it's my first time back since a year now. I never realized how much a luxury the theaters are and the impression it could make on an individuals connection to a film. For some reason, the fact that I was watching the movie in a theatre rather then in a living room felt more impactful to the nature of the story. Again that idea of empathy, the closeness with the characters I witnessed through gazing at the big screen. I give credit to this from the cinematography and camerawork, writing, and especially the acting from Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. What largely made an impact on me was this film's transitory depiction of home. The people we rely on to define us may suddenly seem unrecognizable, and that's just disturbing. But I think Zeller's use of empathy also provides us with an alternative effect of comfort on the viewers.

reviews.review_title: Difficult to discuss immediately after seeing it.
reviews.content: I just finished watching The Father. Its ending made me cry a little. I'm only saying this to signify how uneasy it can be.It's difficult to write about this film immediately after seeing it therefore I'll keep this post short and casual.Firstly, it's a play adaptation and it is visible that the film is kept in the spirit of the stage performance. Setting is fairly static, performances strong and the film language limited to the realist-impressionist style.Secondly, this film really does a great job showing how the dementia might feel for the ones affected with it the most directly (the ones who actually suffer it, inside their heads). Mixing times, faces, events, places while still trying to keep the bits of own identity as well as to make sense of the happenings progressively lacking in the immediate coherence is painful to watch from a perspective of an informed spectator, knowing what is going on - contrary to the main protagonist of the film - and having had witnessed similar illness in the past.Finally, my purely subjective view on this film is that this the film and the performances that should be talked about. After Quo Vadis, Aida? The Father is another 10/10 film and together they highlight the mediocrity of relatively popular, recent films such as Sound of Metal and Promising Young Woman which for some strange reason seem to get the most of critical as well as public attention this award season.

Anthony Hopkins - a veteran of his trade - alone is an impressive cast. But add Olivia Coleman/? Williams and Mark/? Rufus Sewell/? Gatiss, and the story - that itself is a tour de force - elevates itself to a deeply touching human drama. The acting in this movie is a rare achievement in film. Of course, the script is an adaptation of a play; that probably helps.The movie takes us through a never-ending ever-more-confusing maze of constant shifts and changes in Anthony's? Day-to-day life. Whenever the audience thinks it might know the? Construction of the plot, it is thrown out of its assumptions when Zeller adds yet another? Fragment of confusion. We start doubting everything along with the main character; is his daughter married? - and to whom? - is? She going to Paris? - it is? His apartment, right? - what is happening?!Everything - the changing casting, decor and script - makes us lose our bearings. Is it morning? Is it evening? And what? About the chicken? What chicken?The Father is hard to watch and recognizable? To the extreme. It prevented me from going to sleep for more than an hour? After watching it; it's that disturbing. At the same time, it's also heartbreaking. It's a brilliant concept, exquisitely constructed, and it lingers. It's one of the best films of the decade.

Highly recommend you see this touching movie.Sir Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are superb in their respective roles brilliantly written and directed by Florian Zeller.It's a sad, insightful and moving story giving us a glimpse of what ilife is like battling dementia.

reviews.review_title: This is one film that has to be watched to be appreciated
reviews.content: "The Father" is adapted from director Florian Zeller's stage play by the same name. It is lead by Sir Anthony Hopkins, who delivers a mindblowing Oscar-worthy performance. He acts as an aging man, who slowly loses the sense of reality due to dementia.The audience doesn't know what is reality and is as confused as Anthony. Director disorients us by having different actors play the same characters and even the set keeps changing. We hear different versions of Anthony's life, and we even seem to experience events out of order.This movie is a tear-jerker and a unique piece of art because it focuses on the feeling and not the truth of the experience.

If you liked:
Nebraska
Amour
Relic"The Father" is one of the 2021 Oscar frontrunners, a heartbreaking drama about aging. An old man named Anthony is refusing help from his daughter as he ages. They are at a point when the child is worried enough about their parent to try to get them a professional carer; and the parent, fighting for the last bits of their independence, is proud enough to insistently believe that they can perfectly manage on their own. A terribly awkward situation for both to find themselves in and although we sort of side with Anthony in the beginning; we eventually do see that his mind starts to slowly disintegrate and fragment, starting with simple forgetfulness, and ending up with a nasty habit of believing that everyone is out there to steal from him.What makes this movie so unique and borderline genius is that we see the whole story from Anthony's perspective only. He is clearly showing early signs of dementia; and we only get the side of the picture that he himself recognizes and sees through his confused memory and eyes; to the point where we ourselves become paranoid and confused. The faces are confusing, the time of the day is confusing, the surroundings are confusing. Because of that, the film isn't constructed like a dull drama, but rather as a some twisted kind of mystery thriller bordering on horror. Probably most of us have at least once contemplated on our own mortality and the paralyzing fear of losing one's memory as we become older. This film is not scary-horror, but it should scare the stuffing out of anyone, since this problem is universal for all of us humans. The prospect of getting lost in your own head is far scarier and far more real than anything some Boogeyman from a generic horror film can throw at us. It's what I have been afraid of ever since I could think hard enough. It's also one of the reasons why I became a biologist, I am planning to delve into Biology of Aging research so that we can live healthier lives as we get older, and avoid this kind of horror in our lives and the lives of our loved ones.All of this was brought to life by the never-changing excellency of my favorite actor Anthony Hopkins, rightly earning Hopkins his 6th nomination; and the superb directing of Florian Zeller, for which he confusingly wasn't nominated, but his film did get the "mysterious" Film Editing nomination for all those cuts that made the confusion of a fading mind tangible.This brutally real film won't provide you with any answers, but it will give you a ton of questions to ponder on. Comparatively very short, running for 90 minutes only, it is definitely one of the best films of 2020 that nobody should miss. Available in some theaters.

It's an Prospective View

It's messed up.

reviews.review_title: A first rate movie - excellence all around.
reviews.content: The script was a beautifully written skillful work. The composition of the shots was breath-taking. It all came together well. I like how there was a sense of mystery about the whole show, as to what was really going on. I think that by the end of it, you can piece together what really happened. Most of it could have actually just been a dream. I'm not sure how long Anthony, the name of the character played by Anthony Hopkins, has been affected by dementia. Is it recent, is it many years? That part is hard to tell.The acting was a tour de force by Anthony Hopkins - only possible when an enormous talent meets a lifetime of experience. He was perfect in the whole thing, and his mercurial switches in mood were all genuine and earned. Olivia Coleman was very amazing in her part as well, as her entire emotional life was available to her character. This is one of the more successful adaptations from a play to a movie that I've seen.
Anthony Hopkins at his best! The perspective of the movie is extraordinary, an exceptionally original approach to the subject. Recommending it wholeheartedly.

reviews.review_title: Don't watch if you are scared to look into the void
reviews.content: So we have tons of movies that show us how is the live of a family member or nurse that take care of people with dementia, I don't recall a movie that portraits the person himself with the disease.Worst than a horror movie, you imagine yourself in that prison and abyss of which you can't just run or get out by yourself, either you have someone that has the courage to help you or you are in it forever..My grandma had dementia and was somewhat like this, my mother has Alzheimer and seems softer than the dementia, but still o can see she is not there anymore and we can't do nothing, they are there to stay and go into the void day by day.What a cruel end of live this is, and the movie showed me a side I haver never thought of, or I chose not to think on... this movie stays with you, specially if you have someone in your family but also stays with you if maybe one day we can suffer of this what then?Brilliant acting of Lord Anthony Hopkins (he actually uses his own name), the cry he does in the last scenes makes me feel like I have a baby in front of me and it is exactly what they are defenseless babies.Watch it if you are ok to look into the abyss of you are to sensitive don't watch it.

reviews.review_title: The movie is able to make you not only watch, but feel what is happening.

reviews.review_title: A MASTERPIECE from two acting heavyweights: Coleman and Hopkins
reviews.content: Absolutely brilliant performance from both Academy Award winners - Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman; two actors who never fail to deliver. A fascinating and emotional insight into what it is like for a person slowly descending into dementia, a cruel and vicious illness that steals little bits of a person on a daily basis until nothing is left.

I rarely take my time to write reviews on IMDb and this is a clear exception. One of my biggest fears is slowly losing my memory and not being able to recognize the people I love wholeheartedly, and this movie made sure I cried a river of tears throughout the beautiful journey of watching it. Anthony Hopkins is, without a doubt in my mind, a fantastic actor who helps this movie shine. The story is phenomenal and, at one point, I legitimately thought I was watching someone suffering from Alzheimer's.If the movie didn't throw the word "Anthony" at me every now and then, I can be certain that I wouldn't even remind myself that that man is Anthony Hopkins.I always see actors and actresses but I also allow myself to establish an emotional connection with their characters.There are very few movies that I have watched where I completely forgot I was watching a movie, and this is one of those movies. I got lost in the movie as Anthony got lost in his mind. In the very end, I didn't see Anthony Hopkins, I saw an old man suffering from a horrible disease. I sincerely hope Hopkins gets an Oscar for the genuine tears he spawned on my eyes.It's a beautiful film and you won't regret watching it!
It's safe to say that Sir Anthony Hopkins is a national treasure and he is just breathtaking in this role.My god, what a performance!

A gripping movie and sad movie that brings you on an emotional rollercoaster. Anthony Hopkins steals the show, an absolutely fantastic performance.I have to say I was a little disappointed with the ending. I get why they did it, but still thought it could have ended differently.

As a young 19-year-old, I have never been as scared of getting old and getting sick with dementia as I was after watching this movie. It's a beautiful and horrifying portrayal of how dementia affects the family and the patient.

This movie was phenomenal. It's a drama played out like a mystery thriller due to you being in the mind of Anthony Hopkins's namesake character.You can tell this was a play due to the minimal locations throughout but it suits it, the flat almost becomes like a metaphor for his mind, more and more like a labyrinth as the movie goes on.Hopkins and Colman were both incredible, both of them should have won Oscars but Hopkins could have won it ten times over. This film was one of the most raw and most real movies I have watched. It tells the story of one of the worst diseases humanity faces in such a gut-wrenching way, staying away from the sometimes unnecessary and drawn out melodrama that film tends to produce. What makes this film so beautiful is the fact that we experience the film through Anthony's perspective (save a scene or two). Though Anthony is the being that suffers from the illness, we are there with him. We feel the confusion and the desperation for fulfillment. We crave answers to the questions that are posed to us through Anthony's eyes. He wants to know who he is, what he's doing, and what's going on around him, and we want the same. In this way, Anthony's experiences become ours. We see what he sees, and we feel what he feels.Something I want to make note of is the film's setting, which takes place mainly in a few flats. The sets are all complicated - there are numerous doorways, a clutter of furniture, and several different rooms. The disorganized set is so carefully designed to mimic Anthony's mental space. Just like parts of his brain are hard for him to access, it is hard for us to assuredly recognize the characteristics of the flats and to easily notice the switching between them. This is all excluding one single part of each flat: the doorway at the end of the hall. The way that the camera always steadily follows Anthony in and out of that room highlights the inevitable truth of the situation... As Anthony continues to rely on the solitude that the room at the end of the hall offers him, the eery shots of it force us into reckoning with the uncomfortable truth that Anthony won't be able to escape to it forever. Though the film chose not to display Anthony's eventual death, we all know that it's soon to come. Instead, the film shows one last heartbreaking moment where Anthony cries for his mother, stripping his mind and being into the likes of a child's.
Reminded me of my grandmother a lot, and my moms struggle to help her, it hit me right in the heart.

reviews.review_title: If you have any experience with dementia in your life, please skip this. It will break you.
reviews.content: If you have any experience or personal history with dementia in your life, I would highly recommend skipping this one. Not because it is a bad movie, the opposite actually. The movie would probably hit so close to home that, even for me, it will be a bit too much to handle at times. This is one of the most realistic movies I have ever seen. Even tho I have never experienced anything in a form of dementia in my life, I could feel the realism and tragedy that is going on. Anthony Hopkins gives one of (if not the) greatest performance of his career. He nails every aspect of his character. From the big memory loss moment to the subtle little movements, everything has meaning and consequences. I would also highly recommend watching it twice. The first time you will experience the movie with the main character and try to puzzle everything together. The second viewing you will appreciate the story a lot more. There are a lot of little moments and sequences that make the story even more complete. Some scenes go on for a bit to long, but it all works out at the end. It didn't hit me as hard as I thought it would at the end, but it still left me with an appreciation for dementia and everyone who has been in contact with this horrible disease.

When the trailer for this movie came out, I remember thinking that it was going to be a spooky film, about an old man's daughter trying to make him feel like he was losing his mind in order to get his property. After watching the film, it's so interesting to see that that perspective is like Anthony's perspective throughout the movie, it was like the trailer made you feel what he was feeling; I don't know if that was intentional, if it was, very well done.This story is heart breaking. You basically watch as this elderly man slips further and further into dementia, until he eventually regresses into his child self. He feels as though people are constantly out to get him, and sometimes you don't know it they are or they aren't; telling this story from his perspective allows you to go through a disorienting experience that gets you to put pieces together and interpret things in different ways, which I so appreciate more than maybe showing it from the daughter's perspective, where it would end up just being a series of linear events.I'd recommend this to anyone that can watch something like this. If you've had experience with people that have dementia, it'll probably hit close to home. It definitely gets tears out of me no matter how many times I watch it.

reviews.review_title: HEARTBREAKING FILM WITH GREAT ACTING BY HOPKINS
reviews.content: Florian Zeller's heartbreaking and extremely moving realistic human drama about elderly man named Anthony, magnificently played by the great British thespian Sir Anthony Hopkins who delivers a towering piece of great acting in an astonishing Oscar and BAFTA Film Award winning performance for Best Actor, who is unable to come to terms with his oncoming dementia and his losing grip on reality. He refuses all help from his caring daughter Anne, brilliantly played by Olivia Coleman who delivers such a memorably endearing Oscar and Golden Globe Award nominated performance for Best Supporting Actress, showing the pain and the utter sorrow of watching helplessly as her beloved father slowly slips away. Anne must also deal with his forgetfulness, confusion, and mood swings. This powerful heartfelt film will reduce you into an emotional wreck as it did to me. Wonderfully impressive directorial debut by Zeller who won a richly deserved Oscar and BAFTA Film Award for his engrossing adapted screenplay. Fine supporting performances by Rufus Sewell, Mark Gatiss, Imogen Poots, and Ayesha Dharker. Nominated for 6 Academy Awards including Best Picture.
That's a rare thing sometimes. He plays the father exceptionally well. It grows upon you, it confuses you and you'll feel.

reviews.review_title: Should be on every family's Watchlist
reviews.content:
Our mum died over a year ago & she suffered only mild to moderate dementia, but it played havoc on her mind, within her final years.After any death, we often relive ideas of what we could have done better & recently, I watched this movie on an SBS WORLD MOVIE channel. It not only brought me to tears, but also helped me understand that as a family, our resolve to keep mum home at all costs, while I was able to care for her 24/7, was the VERY best option we could ever have taken, for her welfare.If you can, I URGE everyone whose parent/grandparent is in the grips of this condition to watch this movie. At times, it was harrowing, but it held an invaluable insight into thoughts & feelings we might never have understood, acted out by a world class actor. Most of the plot, though broken in parts, was easily followed, however, the ending progressed so quickly, that it was slightly lacking.....
It detailed perspective from not only a carer's perspective (in this case, his last surviving daughter) but, more importantly, from the father's own view (often through many confused states of awareness in one day), which changed so often that it would make our 'unaffected' heads spin.I wish I'd seen this movie while my own mum was still alive.Everyone, if you have a parent/grandparent who is dealing with this debilitating condition, please try your best to access it - easily done via SBS on demand, with a simple search using Anthony Hopkins's name, or the movie title. It'll take less than 2 hrs of your time, but well worth it.It helped answer questions I'd had for 4+ years of care of my own parent, but also carried the full hurt of understanding how my mum must have felt when she, on occasion, awoke in bed, asking me where she was & why, in her own home of 50+ years.Even though it can be uncomfortable to watch, any frustration I felt while caring for mum paled into insignificance after seeing this film. It holds knowledge that can help you, better help them & in my view, should be on every family's watchlist.

reviews.review_title: A dance of time and memory
reviews.content: This is truly a unique piece of art. Like other great art, it challenges you into seeing life differently.In this case, it shows how our memory is the mechanism that delineates time and our lives. Without our memory - our experiences intertwine, they loop/ repeat and come and go.This movie and the performances of the entire cast and crew, captures the disorientation of a person living with dementia and the immense challenges of their loved ones living with them.It's both heartbreaking and joyous.Anthony Hopkins is truly magnificent - with the near final scene and his memory of his mother - particularly poignant.Watching this movie reminds us all how we should cherish our memories and all the moments of our lives.
