reviews.review_title: The People's Choice Best Picture Award
reviews.content: The movie is so well written that even we get a glimpse of what it is like to live in Anthony's world. I have seen movies where they portray dementia but this one really gives you a real dose of what it feels like just by watching the movie, kind of like what memento felt.My grandmother is suffering from Alzimers and I have always wondered what must be going through her mind. We celebrated her 87th birthday few months ago and last week I visited her, I asked her how old she is, she replied 63. She would go on to tell me about her childhood for the hundredth time but I listened like it was the first because she is always so invested in the story that she literally cries and laughs when explaining her stories. As it was getting dark, she would try to get up from her seat saying that she needs to hurry and cook some meals, as her son will reach soon from work. She'd try to get up and say the same thing..She hasn't entered the kitchen in decades and hasn't seen that son in a decade, he passed away 11 years ago.Do watch this movie, it will hit you like a brick wall if you are just getting about dementia and will knock you out cold if you have a relative with the same condition.

The father is a movie that turns around Anthony, a role played brilliantly by Sir Anthony Hopkins who won the academy award for it. Anthony is an old man who is suffering from Alzheimer's. The story follows him through sometimes but it is masterfully manipulated by the script and edits making the film somehow complicated to understand at least for the first watch. It does not have many soundtracks but the few have done the job perfectly by Ludovico Einaudi. Actings are perfect other than Sir Anthony Hopkins himself others have done a great job at making the father a really powerful drama.Overall, the father is a really good movie if you are into the drama genre that with a strong script probably gonna make you cry.

reviews.review_title: Please DO NOT waste your time in watching this drag
reviews.content: Okay, he has dementia, but why are all the characters changing? Who is his daughter? Who is the husband/boyfriend? Why does he end up in a hospital magically? Its like more of magic shape shifting scenes that is a full of repeat scenes and boredom.PLEASE save your time and skip.
I've never cried so hard while watching a movie. Anthony Hopkins has always been my favourite actor, but this movie will leave a lasting impact on me. One of the best movies ever made. Hats off.

I was unfamiliar with director Florian Zeller before I saw The Father, but he won my heart with this. It was heartbreaking to watch as someone who has dementia run in my family, so do not walk into this expecting anything other than tears.It's a very realistic portrayal, with just the right visual tone told delicately through the eyes of the Olivia Coleman's character Anne. Its safe to say you can't go wrong with Olivia Coleman or Anthony Hopkins in your film, but I want to shout from the rooftops how amazing it is to see some fresh filmmaking talent break the traditional Hollywood barriers. This was fantastic all around!

Beautifully acted, written, directed and very well paced. I can't understand why it hasn't won more Oscar's. Who am I kidding? Academy Awards have become a sham now.This movie is one of those that will go down in history as one of those classics that everyone agrees to be a masterpiece.

I can clearly understand the high votes of this movie: the entire world inside this film can bring you to the deepest desperation of an old mind.And let me add this: I cried instantly as the movie ended, as I was thinking about the action of Mr. Hopkins, wonderful, tremendous and and so tender!

This film was originally written and delivered (by the same director) as a stage production. These roots show throughout the film, which relies on only 2-3 sets and uses a sparse cast of characters. This minimalist setup forces much of the film to be carried by the acting. Thankfully the film is in good hands with both Hopkins (who started his career on the stage) and Colman as leads.The story of dementia in a film is not necessarily unique, but the nature of the storytelling is, and the way it unfolds brings the audience into the stress dementia can introduce into everyone's lives. Violent or shocking moments in the film become questioned as easily as the name and face of a supposed close contact. It's thought-provoking to participate in, but also draining. Thankfully the runtime is only 90 minutes as I do not know if I could have taken much more.Thankfully the movie does not wear its point thin. There are some interesting nuggets to chew on and maybe a few unanswered questions...but that's all part of the experience I suspect.8/10.

This film makes you live everything the people who suffer from dementia are feeling. It's amazing and in the same time so heartbreaking to be so tormented by your own mind and memories. You feel confused, lost, it makes me appreciate caretakers more, how much humanity is needed for this job, it makes me sad for the families who must see their loved ones slowly fading away and becoming child again. This sad film makes me happy that these profound motion pictures still exist today. Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman deserve all the awards , they are amazing.

As someone who had to deal with his grandfather having dementia in his final stages of life, the depiction of Anthony Hopkins felt truly real and moving for me. This movie will help you understand better this disease and what people go through when their mind start to deteriorate.His winning at the Oscars was totally deserved, this was one the greatest performances in his career.
Looking at the trailer before I watched the movie, I knew it was going to be good. I just didn't expect it to be that good! Loved every single minute of the movie. Can't wait to watch it again.

The father is a great drama with a great performance by the cast. Obviously age is just a number for Anthony Hopkins the man is a true legend other cast members are great as well but Imogen Poots could have been better, really good cinematography, other than some minor plot holes I saw nothing wrong with this movie and I absolutely liked it and highly recommend watching it.
No doubt acting of each actor is good. But they movie is baseless and confusing. Monotonous and not meant for entertainment.

reviews.review_title: Didn't think it would hit me like that, but it did
reviews.content: Really powerful, it really hit me hard, seeing this family struggling with memory loss, confusion and some backstory. The acting is amazing, emotions feel real and it's even stronger when you personally know someone with Alzheimer's.Kinda disappointed with the soundtrack, which is good but was sold like a masterpiece. But like I said, it's good.

I'd had a particularly bad day visiting my Dad and wasn't really in the mood to go to the cinema let alone see this film. My defences were up before we'd got through the adverts.To start with I thought that this was OK but not brilliant. But the combination of a strong cast and equally strong script soon drew me in.By the time you realise what's going on, you are totally consumed in the nightmare.Some of the dialogue and mannerisms could have been my own dad earlier that same dayThis is a hard watch for anyone who has family with dementia. And as others have said will stay with me for a whileWas it brilliant. Yes. Would I want to see it again....have a feeling I will but not yet.

Mr Hopkins will get his award for sure after such a good acting. Second of all, the visual production was amazing! First half hour of the movie I have found myself at struggling to figure out the design of the house; the objects were constantly changing as well as the places of rooms (even it did not, they succeed to deceive me right there) and I completely felt the same as Anthony. It gives you a chance to identify with the main character, so that was really good attempt and a directorial success.

What a beautifully constructed film. The intricate film-making creates such an immersive experience, the audience real delve into the life of the characters, which in this case is quite a heart-breaking place to be, despite its striking reality. This is especially effective in such a contained setting, which is just one of the many brilliant directorial decisions made in The Father.You see this is really a very simple film. There are only a few characters, which gives more room for each to be fully fleshed out, which allows us to engage with each person and their role in the story a lot more. The narrative is told somewhat in a linear manor but fuddled up and moved around to reflect the state of mind of Anthony Hopkins' character (sort of similar to that of Memento) and that's it. Only that isn't it, although technically so little is done so much effect is made, this story benefits so much from simplicity because there we have so much. So much raw emotion and so much heart-breaking realism. You really feel like you are in this world firstly as a viewer, but then you begin to question yourself and your own perception and sense of being and when everything becomes clear at the end of the film you instead think of the people around you and not yourself. You think of those close to you, your family or anyone who is slowly losing touch with themselves and the world around them, only able to hold onto a few fragments of their memories. And that hits you like a ton of bricks.I watched this with two of my friends in the cinema a few weeks ago and all of our reactions when the film had finished was around the lines of "I want to call my Mum... I want to check up on my Grandad. ... I miss ...". That's impact for you. I think that gives you plenty of reason to watch this film if you are emotionally stable enough to be taken through the ringer quite a bit. But oh my what a beautifully tragic piece of cinema.

Reason i gave it 6 was that: Movies purpose was 10 , content. Intentions . Educational and productional side
all was 10, but the same time , movie itself very boring. Usual real life to what it is, sadly.
The film was so well done you could easily forget it was a film and get lost in the personal hell along with Anthony. Truly a Titan in the acting world and he earned that Oscar for his performance.
All the movie I was just crying!The best movie that I've ever seen, I recommend everyone watching it.
This film made me cry so much , it's one of the best films that I've seen so far , I highly recommend it .

reviews.review_title: Will continue to recommend. Very cleverly written and designed!
reviews.content: Was all done so well, will continue to recommend and will watch again in the future. Really sad watch and hard to watch at points.Shot in a beautiful apartment, the design and links between locations is so cleverly done and something I haven't seem much of before.For somebody who has a small understanding of dementia and alzheimer's, it gave a completely new prospective of how one might feel and the things they go through day to day. Perhaps a good one to pass onto somebody close who might be struggling with the repercussions of the disease.Anthony Hopkins is the perfect balance of charming, yet plays the perfect old man we can all relate to in one way or another! Whilst managing to be very humorous.Great watch, thank you.

reviews.review_title: The best film I have ever watched
reviews.content: The acting is absolutely impeccable, especially the unbelievable performance from Anthony Hopkins. The most beautiful writing, so evocative and powerful. Just quality.

A harrowing and realistic portrayal of someone going through Alzheimer's where the viewer is immersed in the confusion and loss of time and space that this disease causes. Hopkins is superb as the father and Colman too is excellent as his daughter caring for him. A difficult watch, particularly for those who have experienced this and tears will be shed.

Brilliant acting by the two protagonists, father and daughter,but tremendously boring and without climax. It's a smooth continuous narration of the world seen by a man with dementia. I don't find that interesting. Why did we need a movie like this in the first place?

This is the most confusing movie I've ever seen. It was so confusing to the point that after the entire movie was over and I came out of the cinema I had a bloody migraine. I would not recommend anyone to watch this movie.

Anthony Hopkins has beaten his best ever performance and Olivia Coleman has outdone herself. Movie direction par excellence The Father is probably one of the best movies of the past 25 years. A gargatuian performance by all involved. Excellent script that describes the realities of Alzheimer's.

reviews.review_title: Where is the entertainment in story's like this...
reviews.content: I understand that film expresses many experiences and tells many stories, some fact and some fiction.This is a story of fiction. But don't be fooled because it is very possible and very real.I wonder how films like this can be viewed with much of any pleasure or ...entertainment.Cause after all what is film of not to tell a story to amuse or intrigue. And well there can be expressions of violence and gore in some film, at least that expression is perhaps more blatant.As I found this film to be disturbing and sad.You are pulled into the main character, Anthony's life as he loses his mind to dementia. In a setting that ultimately becomes a world that has no time for such insanity. Where people get taken somewhere, and put away, to let someone else deal with them.That reality is very real. And more horrific than any gory horror film.Anthony Hopkins who plays the character of Anthony, is a great actor, but he could likely be just playing himself, as he has reached an age when losing parts of ourselves is the reality. And so I don't see it as an award worthy performance. But who am I to say and well I'm certainly not involved in all the politics that go into those ceremonies.Watch it, if you're curious. Most will probably feel some sort of complaisant agreeability with the story. Empathize. And you only have to seen the news or followed along any social media outlet to see that people revel in the discomfort of others.Makes you wonder.

reviews.review_title: Tried to explain to my wife w/o avail.
reviews.content: My wife's a huge fan of Sir AH. She's also huge on father/daughter relationship and she thought the film would make her cry. However, she has a linear timeline mentality and doesn't understand movies on time travel, Pulp Fiction and such. I had to explain several times this film is based on Anthony's POV and the director wants you to experience what it is like to suffer from dementia. Needless to say, her expectations were too high. I did like the different POV.

reviews.review_title: Look at Alzheimer's from the inside.
reviews.content: The narrative is similar to Memento. We watch the story through the eyes of the main character (Anthony Hopkins plays divinely). Having an ailment, he can only improvise in situations where fate throws him. The director shows how important it is for people to be certain in their lives.
This is the best film I've ever seen on dementia. The acting directing and cinematography are Best in class. Sir Anthony Hopkins delivers once again. Cheers mate.

reviews.review_title: Excellent performance by Sir Anthony Hopkins
reviews.content: I wasn't sure what to expect from this film thinking it would be a depressing story about an aging parent. However the story being told was done in such a unique way and it kept you guessing as to what the truth was. Also Sir Anthony's performance was mesmerizing and brilliant and I was emotionally involved in the story. See this movie, you won't be disappointed.

Anne (Olivia Colman) attempts to care for her aging father (Anthony Hopkins) that refuses to accept his need for assistance. Florian Zeller wrote the stage play, wrote the adapted screenplay (with help from Christopher Hampton), and directed the film. (Sheesh!)Immediately after watching all 8 2021 Best Picture nominees, I ranked The Father #6 out of 8. After watching for the second time, I think it probably should've been upped to 4 or 5. Even though I still think there were better films in the mix, I have yet to get over how PHENOMENAL this film's screenplay, performances, and general production were.Other than Best Picture, The Father was nominated for five other awards at this year's Oscars: Best Actor (Anthony Hopkins), Best Supporting Actress (Olivia Colman), Film Editing, Production Design, and Best Adapted Screenplay. Per usual, I completely agree with all of these nominations, but I would've liked to see Cinematography in there as well. The cinematography was simple yet so well executed. There were many times where the camera stayed in one place as the characters moved around it, and it was notably impressive.Without a doubt, the two best aspects of the film were the screenplay and Mr. Anthony Hopkins (which aligns with the Oscar wins). The screenplay is original and a brilliant way to tell the story of dementia. Hopkins' performance in this film should be studied in acting school. He flips the switch from comfortable to scared at the drop of a hat, and he does it seamlessly. His expressions, body language, and tone are perfect for the role, and his Oscar is very well deserved.The search is still on for a film adapted from a play where we don't feel stuck in one location. Thankfully, the flat we were bound to in The Father was absolutely beautiful. It was charming and warm and the Opera music we heard so often added to that warmth aptly. Despite the lack of diversity, I ended up enjoying the production design quite a bit.Now, even after all of those wonderful accolades (and minor criticisms), I still wouldn't say that I was thoroughly entertained for the entire run-time. Many aspects wowed me, yet I still found myself to be a little bored. I was happy that the run-time was a short hour and 37 minutes because it felt repetitive once I understood what was happening. There didn't seem to be a real climax, although I did think the ending was pretty remarkable. I needed a bit more ebb and flow to keep me interested.Out of all the movies nominated for Oscars this year, this is definitely one you need to see. Watch to see a master of acting, a remarkable screenplay, and dementia through a different lens.@boomroastedmoviecritic on Instagram.
Not many films get me emotionally invested these days, but this did. Beautiful cinematography and incredible performance from Hopkins. Truly incredible. Colman also was fantastic.

reviews.review_title: this film tore me to pieces..
reviews.content: .. I lost my father the day before new years eve to demensia. Anthony Hopkins - you are a genius. You acted my father and his illness and you did it so well it broke my heart again.
Incredible performances, it's just a new level of acting not seen before. Leaves you speechless and in tears. Hopkins is a true genius. The cast, music, script, shooting, ... just ... wow.

The Father will leave you feeling melancholy and hopeful at the same time. Whilst the story is heartbreaking, the love, grief and compassion Olivia Coleman's character radiates through the movie depicts perfectly the real struggles of dealing with dementia. This in combination with an outstanding performance by Anthony Hopkins gives life and depth to an otherwise simple plot line. As an audience the rug is constantly swept from under your feet, Florian Zeller constantly subverts your expectations and brings you into Anthony's world - Simply Brilliant!

reviews.review_title: Pleas kill me before i get like this- also not entertainment
reviews.content: Well, a well made film on mental illness but- hard to watch. Informative yes, entertaining, no. Good for students maybe or professionals, or some type of medical training. Not a good film to watch on a saturday night with your girlfriend.

Anyone who has looked after a relative with dementia will know that this movie wasn't just close to the mark, but hit it dead right centre. It shows not only what it's like to look after someone with this awful illness, but uses tricks so you can appreciate what it's like for the sufferer. Fortunately for me it wasn't always this hard. But this reminded me vividly of the most difficult times. This should become required viewing for anyone training to care for dementia patients. I now consider Anthony Hopkins Britain's greatest actor without doubt.

reviews.review_title: I can totally relate to it
reviews.content: I saw this film and thought about my family's experience and my grandmother. She had Alzheimer's and almost the same story. An aunt took care of her until she passed away. In the movie they didn't capture the full progression, at the end of my grandmother's days she forgot how to move and how to swallow and she was intubated so she could stay alive. I feel like I owe a great debt to my aunt, she gave up her job to stay with my grandmother full time.As for me, I am very sad and emotional after seeing this movie. I moved to another country just before she died, I had a special relationship with her, I was her first grandson and lived with her when I was little, she spoiled me and I was very dear to her. I loved her and I really miss her. The weird thing is that in my mind her funeral was the day I read about her illness, I hugged her and wept, she was so confused and kept asking what was going on my son.

reviews.review_title: It kept me thinking for many days...
reviews.content: We see the importance of the edition here because it's really another character in the movie. However, over everything, the end broke my mind, because to think about the role interpreted by Anthony Hopkins on How he wakes up every morning thinking that he is at home with his daughter, that who doesn't love as much as the other one who died by an accident, he wakes up confused and with an attitude similar like a child one... It's very scary to think about getting older in this way, so raw and real.

reviews.review_title: Between emotions and mind games, curiosity is evolved in our minds
reviews.content: Between emotions and mind games, curiosity is evolved in our minds, many probabilities kept us thrilled till the end to know what is exactly going on there.It's a trip through dementia and obstinacy, clarifying the bad influences of them on the other people around you, who are concerned about and trying really hard to help you and put you into your comfort zone.The method of actions and post-actions that is applied by the great actor Anthony Hopkins (the father), and the genius Olivia Coleman (the daughter) to show the Emotions, the Obstacles, and the Disturbances that they are having between themselves and between each other, all of these themes are shown through repeated dialogues and repeated scenes.The movie represents how Anthony is lost in memories, and the what's the perfect explanation of dementia, the director - or maybe the writer - chose to show us the story through an image that contains themes of dementia and insanity, and this scenes of memories also show the struggle of Anne (Olivia Coleman) throughout her life wasting years attached to her father, afraid of leaving him alone, he was arrogant that he was not convinced that he is complaining and also a little bit selfish. Which brings us to the dilemma of love is sometimes devastating.
To walk through what they experience is a eye opener.

My mother has lived through this same thing with my grandmother. At the beginning of the film I thought this ought be good, I have to recommend this to my mother. I believed I will be in tears. But really film just repeats itself over and over again and the thing gets old really fast. Would not recommend.

I watched this on the eve of my 60th birthday. Dementia is something that has an increasing presence in day to day life and particularly when you are approaching my age!It was so interesting to see the view from the "other side" which really made this film amazing to watch. I shall watch it again because that will increase my understanding of the whole situation.
Just so powerful and gives a real insight into what it must be like to be suffering from dementia. Really clever and probably the best film I have seen in a long time.
For Best Movie and the Actor..along with the screenplay! A masterpiece.

Holy smokes they are only in a flat and from start to finish was absolutely brilliant no doubt the acting was extremely good amd convincing. I recommend to anyone sit and watch this film and you will be impressed.

It's one of the best of 2020-21.It's a brilliantly made, wonderfully scripted and awesomely acted piece of cinema.It leaves you as confused as Anthony Hopkins character. The perspective from which the movie is shot is as good as real life.You have to work your way to understand the emotion of being lost and forgotten.Anthony Hopkins is marvellous. He shifts his emotions so subtly that you will be in awe.And a special mention for the screenplay.Go for it. It will stay with for long.

We were confused the whole time and I think that's how we're supposed to be feeling because that's how people with dementia feel. It's like the movie and the performance put us into character. Incredible performance by Anthony Hopkins. He does it again with a performance that we know no one else can outdo but him.
An amazing performance,they touch my heart so deep.

Trigger warning for anyone who cant handle seeing old men break down.. like me. I really needed that warning. Sobbing, this really broke me. Dementia through the lens of the sufferer. This movie nailed what it must feel like on both ends of the spectrum. Anyway I'm going to call my dad now.

reviews.review_title: An absolute masterpiece. Just watch. JUST WATCH.
reviews.content: I'm out of words. What can I say. If this isn't a masterpiece then nothing is. This is the best movie in Oscars 2021.
This movie gives us a message that we never abandon our elder ones. I literally cried at the ending.And acting is totally lit. Great work.
Very sad, but vey beutiful and interesting movie.I recommend it to everyone.

Different movie from the classics. Incredibly it tells of a situation that no one hopes will happen to their father. Sometimes you get lost and don't know if what you are seeing is reality or Anthony's imagination, great idea!

I watched many movies in my life, part of them was with amazing spaciel effect part of tham was realy epic but few of them really make me feeling emotions From the depths of my soul, this is movie like that. I think there is a lot of movies with special effect that hard to explain how they make this shot but it is even herder to make the viewer the identity themselves in the movie, Sometimes we watch movie from the heart not from the head.The power of the movie is the Characters of Anthony who played by Anthony Hopkins and Anne who played by Olivia Colman their Relationships of father and daughter is the heart of the movie. Anthony is Dementia sufferer and Anne is the one who take care of him but when she meet a guy and movie with him to Paris she must to find someone who will help to Anthony. Everyone who know person with Dementia will understand that, for me is close issue and sometimes it felt like i know Anne i can understand her motive and her action it is like the the director Florian Zeller placed a mirror in front of me and when you met yourself the movie is not just a movie it is kind of experience. I must say it was heartbreaking to watch how the Character of Anne it is hard to watch how she absorbing the mood of her father and didn't respondThis movie is Adaptation to a play by Florian Zeller ( the director of the movie) Full Disclosure I didn't watch the play but I think this movie did something that play never can do and this is to watch the point of view of Dementia sufferer we don't know what is the time or place Although the movie set in one location and this is thanks to the change of the apartment, this is the power of Cinematography.The thing the negative thing I can say about the is that i didn't like the Character of Paul who played by Rufus Sewell for me this Character is just there to be antagonist all he does is to complain and behave wickedly for me it make me to "exit from the illusion" . It is hard to for me to explain but for me it is the type of Character who is there just for the need of antagonist and not because it is necessary to the story .I think if you familiar with Dementia or you want drama movie go and watch this this movie otherwise I don't know if you love but you can try and consolidate your own opinion.

reviews.review_title: This is what great acting looks like
reviews.content: Anyone with elderly parents, regardless of their mental state, will instantly recognize and empathize with many of the characters. It's the main reason the story is so compelling.The second reason is the magnificent performances by all the actors especially Olivia Coleman who shows the full gamut of emotions she goes through in an understated way. In the age of overacting, this was refreshing indeed.We all know about Anthony Hopkins so I will say no more but he becomes everyone's elderly father the the duration of the movie.

reviews.review_title: Confusing, harrowing and at times horrifying
reviews.content: To put The Father into words is hard, because it is confusing, hard to follow and even understand at times. We see a man who is uncomfortable with aging, wants to retain his independence and at the same time is blissfully unaware that his issues can't be fixed.But that is only the top of the surface of Florian Zeller's film which is based on his play, and a screenplay he co-wrote with Christopher Hampton and a film Zeller also directed. Anthony(played by Anthony Hopkins) is 80 years old and has run off an aide his daughter Anne played by Olivia Colman hired to help him. Much like my Grandpa and I'm sure others all over the world have experienced with seniors, Anthony refuses aid saying he can manage on his own, and Anne shouldn't worry about him.Hopkins gives Anthony humor in this scene like his sarcasm when Anne tells him she's leaving for Paris as she's found someone and can't take of him 24/7, but then comes the first brutal line of the film when he realizes she's serious and says so you're abandoning me.Then we observe Anthony wandering around the apartment and he encounters another man sitting in the living room. He is befuddled, who is he? The man states he is Anne's husband and she is not leaving for Paris. Hopkins becomes defiant, saying he will not be forced to leave his flat to which the man states that this isn't his flat, Anthony has been living with Anne and her husband in their flat.Anne comes back, but to the horror of Anthony it's another woman, not Anne. Zeller's screenplay is labrynth-like, where every scene takes the audience down a path we aren't expecting. The film is at times very hard to follow, and truthfully for most of the film me and my Mom were confused.. Is Anthony losing it, are others trying to make him crazy, or what?Scenes repeat, things aren't what they seem and Anthony at one point asks why his other daughter never comes to see him. (In one of the key scenes, later on we learn why.) Hopkins performance is jaw-dropping particularly the scene where he meets the new aide his daughter brings in, he charms her and we see Anthony's charisma, humor and wit, but then he says she reminds him of Lucy in that she laughs inanely like her.Hopkins immediately reestablishes dominance by saying Anne is after his money, he's not crazy, he liked his other daughter more, Anne is cruel and manipulative and goes from charm to humiliating both the aide and Anne in the course of 1 scene.Also Hopkins with his eyes shows so much of Anthony's thoughts his anger, fear and confusion over what is happening to him, am I ok? He tries to maintain control telling the doctor his daughter takes him too that yes he knows his birthday, who he's staying with and so forth.Finally, we begin to understand that we are watching a man who is losing his sense of reality due to the illness that is controlling his mind. The aide tells him she heard from Anne about his other daughter and what happened to her and we see a photograph of Anthony, Anne and Lucy. We observe the other woman appear when the aide Anthony likes is supposed to come, and then we observe Anthony no longer at home.Anthony has most likely not been home either in his flat or daughter's flat for a while, and has clearly has lost sense of time, faces and what he knows. Finally, at the end Hopkins shows a man who finally realizes he has lost all control and in his final scene which I will not divulge BUT INSIST ANYONE WHO DOES TO BRING TISSUES... is horrifying, heartbreaking and absolutely gut-wrenching.Zeller's film which he takes major risks on by taking us on a journey of dementia is frightening and disturbing. But it is a powerful and important film that deals with an issue many of us sadly will encounter with loved ones, and features the genius of Olivia Colman and the brilliance of Anthony Hopkins.Hopkins nearly 30 years after his brilliance as Hannibal Lecter, once again demonstrates his brilliance with a performance that is almost operatic from humor, to drama, to pain, to horror and finally to tears. I'm so glad the Academy recognized this and for once got it right.

Let me start saying that Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are absolutely brilliant in this movie and both deserve the Oscar praise they got, it's quite heartbreaking to see Anthony suffering like that, things already happened for him, others he doesn't even remember and everyone just doesn't get it, it's a great movie with great actors and a great story.10/10.

...and this gives an insightful, worrying glimpse of what may yet come. My mother had mild dementia (is there such a thing?) but died before it could become full-blown. My mother-in-law was much further immersed in it, and it was so hard to watch. This movie hit so very close to home, and also was heartbreaking, coming from Anthony's perspective.
For Anthony Hopkins performance I can watch this movie 100 times..
This movie hurts like a mother*ucker. Amazing performance from Anthony Hopkins. Truly amazed, one of the best movies I have seen in a while...

I thought I had seen it all in terms of con movies, but this one might take the crown.Watching the daughter and husband carefully and maliciously create more and more situations to make it seem like the father is losing his mind, is a work of art.All is meticulously planned to make him lose face in front of a nurse every time one is present. Telling him that stuff he believes, isn't true, even though she told him exactly that it was the day before... I'm pretty sure I would have thought I was going crazy myself if I was in the father's place.In the end she gets the apartment, and I think she even got his expensive watch (we see at one moment that she has a watch in a box), while he rots in a home for people who can't take care of themselves.Final shot, the leaves of a tree, but are they yellow, are they almost ready to fall? No, they're bright green, full of life, for we know that he in fact still has all his head.Brilliant.

reviews.review_title: People who gave this a 10 must have dementia
reviews.content: Yes, I get the subject matter hits home for some but the truth us thus could be a 15 minute short film. Standard Hopkins acting which us good but not Oscar worthy. The story is non-existent. I'm baffled that anyone would actually like this movie. As entertainment it is totally boring.

This film provides a compelling and moving portrayal of the onset of dementia (or potentially Alzheimer's) by its lead character, masterfully played by the legend Anthony Hopkins. What I really appreciated was that the story is told from his perspective, and you can feel his sense of confusion, loss and fear of having to let go. What was also depicted in an honest and nuanced way was the relationship between the parent and the child-caregiver. Olivia Colman did a fantastic job of conveying a sense of moral ambivalence between having to constantly take care of her father or to move on with her own life. While she does eventually take the decision, motivated in part by her partner, her lack of resolution is clear and her sense of guilt is relatable to anyone who is or has been in a similar situation. Really enjoyed the film.

This is one of the greatest roles of Anthony Hopkins career, but even as great as he was along with his fantastic costar, Olivia Coleman it's Director Florian Zeller who is the real star. reviews.review_title: A chilling ride into Anthony's volatile world
reviews.content: Zellman's 'The Father' is a lot more than a film that merely exists to tell you a story. This is an experience and a journey into an unstable world that is just as real, as it is make-believe.At once stupendously effective and profoundly upsetting, "The Father" might be the first movie about dementia to give me actual chills.Combining mystery and psychodrama, "The Father" is a majestic depiction of things falling away: People, surroundings and time itself are becoming ever more slippery.It's a brutal, terrifyingly simple technique, backed by a production design that manipulates the details of his surroundings just enough to make us question where - and when - we are.Father belongs to the veteran actor Anthony Hopkins who won Oscars for the Best Actor for The Fatherand the debutant director who has moved beyond cliche and sentimentality to reveal the true nature of dementia.

reviews.review_title: something we all see every day

reviews.review_title: Snippets of imagination + Fragments of reality
reviews.content:
Chrisblogger8g
3.5/4
The Father (2021)The Father is undoubtedly well-acted, well-crafted and densely packed with raw emotions, with the amazing performances from the two lead actors, Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, and seems to work without a proper narrative. I myself got very confused watching Hopkins' character realize he was in somebody else's flat and then it is revealed he is in his flat after all, or how each scene transcends into eternal madness, ending up in a hospital, with characters that change names and appearances as if they were in a spinning lottery wheel. I would have appreciated if the movie was also presented out of Anthony's point of view, but, I guess, this is the brutal and realistic depiction of someone suffering from dementia.Other than Hopkins and Colman the other characters just revolve and are here to confuse Anthony (that's the name of his character) and the viewer more. This confusion was made on purpose, like I said, to depict a person suffering from dementia and how his surroundings and his 'fabric of reality' start to fade around him. We watch as the most sophisticated phrases like 'manage on my own' is repeated countless times, and how the plot sequences start to repeat later on in the movie, and mostly feel straight up from a Quentin Tarantino non-linear narrative.Here's one example: Anthony meets a caretaker that reminds him of his daughter, Lucy, whom he has no idea has passed, and the next day the caretaker takes care of him. A painting he has had for a very long time has gone. The following day, it is revealed that he had the meeting with the caretaker a day ago and the caretaker looks like the daughter he couldn't recognize about an hour ago when I first started watching it.Plot aside, I like how Anthony and Anne are characters that feel like actual human beings, one with emotion, feelings like grief, one that we can at least sympathize with and they make their intentions clear, through their actions. Anthony is just an 80-plus year old man who insists he can manage on his own. His daughter, on the other hand, thinks otherwise as he keeps on forgetting things and mixing imagination with reality, and suggests a caretaker.A side villain who is almost as convincing pops up and is in disapproval for Anne to take care of her father as he is a 'nuisance' and demands her to send him to an institution, which actually happens at the end of the movie. Is this man her husband? Has she met someone else? Or is she already divorced?By the end of the movie, Anthony is already unable to bear his everchanging circumstances and cries for his mommy, which provokes pity, sadness and sympathy to the viewer. It's agonizing and haunting.Tag it for a re-watch.

My grandmother lost her battler against Alzheimer a year ago. As someone who has helped to take care of a patient with dementia, I certainly recommend this film. It is done from the patient's perspective and it shows really well what they suffer every day.The most important thing is that the film will help you understand and empathize with people suffering dementia but, I'm not leaving aside that the acting of Anthony Hopkins, as usual, is superb.

reviews.review_title: What does memory make of us?
reviews.content: After the film ends, you will be willing to complete the series of questions posed by these beautiful scenes, on top of which is the permanent question (What is the point of life?).For a moment, Anthony will make you feel that he has a memory disease in fact and that all of this can be real scenes from his private life. The character that the movie leaves behind is not easily eliminated.As I watched, he mentioned him, he reminded him, the memory of the thing twice." Memory is what constitutes one's true self. We notice how Anthony can do no other than name (Anne and Lucy) his daughters. How he's stuck in one day and doesn't want to get out of it. reviews.review_title: "I feel as if I'm losing all my leaves"
reviews.content: A film that ensures its audience feels present in every moment of a man who himself is about to disappear, Florian Zeller's story of dementia is vicariously felt through the unexpected infliction of a disquieting psychological thriller, assuring The Father soundly succeeds at manifesting an experience we'll either come to live, or never forget.(Peformance highlight: Anthony Hopkins, Olivia Colman)

A year ago if I have to recommend a movie about Dementia and Alzheimer, Still Alice would have been a very easy choice. Somehow, that movie stuck with me since I was a kid and it broke me in a very good way.The Father though... it left me so devastated. You don't just 'watch' this movie, you 'EXPERIENCE' it. The Father will make you know how it feels to have dementia. How confusing and frustrating it would be. Anthony's fear of abandonment is the most heartbreaking part of the movie. On top of that, every little joy that he had, it lasted very short and we all know that it will be gone. At least the movie gave us a chance to hug him at the end but left us wondering which is reality or which is Anthony's scattered memories or was he in the hospital all this time?Just only Anthony Hopkins's acting is already made this movie worth watching. A masterclass without a doubt. On top of that, it's amazing how well this movie tell its story. The camera angles, costumes and the script are so refined. The flat designs are also worth mentioning. 10/10 for sure and probably one the best 2021 movie so far.

reviews.review_title: An Engrossing Experience, And A Stellar Performance From Hopkins
reviews.content: This film a brilliant depiction of the effects of dementia, not just from the point of view of loved ones, but from that of the sufferer.Olivia Coleman is fantatsic, as always, but it is Hopkins that steals the show here. He's always been one of the best, but this is one of his finest performance to date.A viewing that's as captivating as it is thought-provoking and heartbreaking, The Father us a must-watch.

The acting is a masterpiece of chambre play magic. The cinematic engine put to work with what it does best, to image the cognitive process, to allow us to experience rather than watch from the outside the disintegration of the self, until its constituents left like rubble on the floor, early childhood, melancholic or show man, characters alternatingly appearing out of thin air in the spiralling mental rewind. And the saddened realization of all the missing time, all the gaps, the five years obviously lost between anne being martied and going to paris without a minute passing, the years of not seeing lucy felt as months and eventually the time gap from being an infant with a mother to being an old man with a daughter perceived as simultaneous. The film medium is strikingly well suited to depict this breakdown of time, chronology and causality, because it is the editing language by which we read film, hence his lack of mental grip over these becomes our frustration and our lack of comprehension, and yet still we can cinematically also read what he is left with - an association montage, scenes linked by resemblance only.

reviews.review_title: As far as my eyes can see, there are shadows approaching me .
reviews.content: Superb. As a health professional and academic, I have worked on and off for many years with people who have cognitive impairment (CI) and have written much on this topic. This movie should be mandatory viewing for policy writers, researchers and practitioners working with older people afflicted with CI. This year, we bid farewell to my partners father in circumstances very similar to those depicted in this movie and in watching it, relived every painful, at times, comical moment right down to the obsessing over his watch!!! What the film and performers capture so well, is the pixelation of thought, the irreversible downward trajectory of functioning, the frustration, the chaos and despair that ensues, all of which are captured in equal measure from the perspectives of the 'afflicted' and the observers/carers.In Australia, which is a realatively wealthy country, the care of older people, many if whom experience CI, has turned into a major industry, a cold inhumane monster in which the 'care' provided has often been found wanting. Films like this help raise awareness of the personal toll of this condition. It's visual eloquence serves as a suitable contra to the vulgarity of pseudo caring corporates and their insatiable greed.
It's a slow and awful movie also so confusing but not in a good way, if you wanna bore yourself to death watch this master pee.
Truly a masterpiece, acting, concept, everything. After it was over I was literally left staring at the screen in deep contemplation and awe.

reviews.review_title: One of the greats of the 21st Century
reviews.content: Reasons why I love this film:Extremely rewatchable. Usually, a second watch decreases my appreciation for good films. Yet, every aspect of this film worked just as well on the second watch as the first. Having seen the film, every scene suddenly has a greater gravity and importance. In fact, the second viewing nearly brought me to tears and has made me look forward to a third viewing.Realism in uncertainty. Despite the screenplay being completely unpredictable, and given the nature of the story telling (more on that later), every performance is wonderfully acted and every scene allows the characters to truly come to life.Power in the way of storytelling. The way that the story is told has absolutely given me a greater appreciation and sadness for Anthony, the main character. No spoilers, but it allows us to understand him so much more then a conventional narrative would have.It's weighty. It's emotional. It's powerful. In what way? How about you watch The Father and find out for yourself!

reviews.review_title: Time, memory and self are all broken.
reviews.content: Narrating under a diseased perspective of a father in his old age, the film comes to be the visualization of this old man's distorted inner world. As a result, the normal life and memory originally believed in turns into suspense films in which he is scared of the whole world and suspects everything he has gone through. Time is a cruel malefactor, bullying the weak and sensitive old man. Every time when he chatters without stop or expresses emotionally is actually his inner heart's yelling and questioning. The vast flat, the ornate furniture and the particularly passionate classical music showed In the scenery shots are not able to drive away the old man's loneliness. He is engulfed by time and his family and love that he used to defend tenaciously all become shattered and indiscernible memories, which alarm him day an d night. He is successful to find back his watch that represents his sense of control of time and memory. But in fact, he fails. And what's more sad is he finally loses himself out of control. So, time, memory and self are all broken. Not only Anthony Hopkins highly overlaps with the character, but also he perfectly performs the one at death's door, makes the film seem like a true record. Every plot and every frame comes to be foil.

I was drawn to see this film having memory issues of my own, and with an octogenarian parent living with us. It was for me a most uncomfortable experience requiring a stiff drink afterwards to quell a strong sense of foreboding. There were only 4 or 5 couples in the cinema but all were silent through the final credits, remaining sitting as if not knowing what to do next. Highly recommended but not if you are over 80.

When the Doctor ask Antony when was his birthday? Antony says its 31 December 1937, the exact date which Anthony Hopkins was born.No wonder because the script and line was written for anthony himself.

Knowing family like this you suddenly see it from a different perspective
Very cleverly you are in their position
A film you will never forget.

A movie that makes you think of yourself, your parents and your kids at the same time,
And if you were lucky you will remember your grand father...A movie that am afraid to recommend to my parents, as much as i want them to watch the miracle of Anthony Hopkins performance yet am afraid of its affect on their emotions...Its just one of the best movies i ever watched.
Very emotional, moving, and well made as directed movie played by the Phenomenal actress Anthony Hopkins.No dry eye left in the cinema hall, Wonderful!!!

Working in aged care, I have seen this story play out in front of my eyes. It's heartbreaking.This moving has you questioning from the get go. What is actually happening here? Is it his mind? His dementia? Or... his family?A true mind blowing movie.

OK we all know the actors here are fantastic. That said, what the hell was the point? Dementia is bad? Thanks for that news flash. We get no sense of the arc of the character's lives. No real sense of connection to what is going on beyond a heightened sense of terror that we all might find ourselves in this condition. Also the $20 fee to watch this interminable cinematic root canal feels like a complete scam. Why is this the one movie I had to buy versus rent? What a waste of my life.

I have never cried this much over a film. Sir Anthony's acting was so so good that I want to cry whenever I think of the scenes. I am so glad that he won an Oscar for this film. This reminds me of the sufferings and the confusions of the elderly who have dementia. One of my favourite movies now...

I have never felt so touched by a movie in my life.The cast abasolutly amazing, Olivia playing daughter - Anne and, Anthony playing Anthony- father.Mr Hopinks is the most incredible actor in this world, this movie remind me of my loved one and I cried throughout the film.Thank you for being the best.

Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) lives most of his adult life in his large London apartment. He shows signs of dementia as he falsely accuses others of stealing his favorite watch. His daughter Ann (Olivia Colman) tells him she is moving to Paris to live with her new boyfriend. His world becomes fragmented and confusing when unfamiliar faces burst into his life.This is a breathtaking artistic vision of what dementia feels like. When Olivia Williams came along, I thought the film could go in two interesting ways. New people can fool the old man, which would be very bold in terms of the script. It can also be psychological Kafkaesque horror with constantly changing faces. The film tries to do just that, but lacks a sense of Kafka. This is an interesting film with very interesting actors. Maybe I was expecting too much at the beginning of the movie. Ultimately, I consider what is not on the screen, not what is on it.

reviews.review_title: Not an easy sight, if you think about old age
reviews.content: It seems that the film was specially written for Anthony Hopkins, who has long deserved it. It can be depressing if you follow the plot of this film about predictable fatherhood, old age and the problems associated with it, but knowing Anthony Hopkins at least on Twitter, nothing like that is in my thoughts. The image turned out to be very convincing, but how good it is if at 82 you can successfully play an old man.The film did not seem to me something unnecessarily simple, weighed down by classical music and operatic singing. On the contrary, the film is extremely serious and oversaturated with symbols.I recommend this difficult film to everyone, Anthony Hopkins is beautiful, 82 years old is some kind of magic. The film resembles a performance and, as I was told on the net, it really is.

It arose many question marks but I imagine that was the very purpose of the film. Great acting, a lot of emotions, a lot of tears. Reminded me of my grandpa, who was clearheaded until the end but weakened by his body. How fragile we can get. Age can truly be destructive.

Did you know that Anthony Hopkins is a British actor and Oscar winner? He received his last Oscar for his performance in "The Father".Set in West London, " The Father" tells a story of an old man with dementia and his worried daughter and shows the audience the representation through Anthony's eyes. It leads to disorientation and even as an audience member you can't tell which scene is real and which is imaginary.The main characters are wonderfully played by the actors because you can put yourself into their shoes. You can really sense the desperation and helplessness of the daughter and I am convinced that anyone in real life would react the same way.On the one hand, the plot really leads to confusion. Scenes are repeated, yet presented in a different way. On the other hand, the plot really catches your attention and you want to solve the mystery behind the film. I was always struggling between turning the TV off and continuing to watch. It's a real nail-biter.If your are a fan of dramatic movies, I completely recommend that you watch this film. I am sure it will be an unforgettable movie.

This movie is a masterpiece from every angle. The fantastic acting performances from both Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman helped to create a one of the best combined performances of all time. The fear, sadness, frustration, and confusion that they were able to display was so important for the plot of the movie and they did so very well. Florian Zeller did an amazing job in bring such a tragic disease from peoples minds onto the screen. The way that he was able to mimic the feeling of suffering from such a thing was immaculate. There was no way to tell what exactly was going on which so brilliantly represents the way that dementia can have an effect on peoples lives. The constant replaying of old memories was an excellent way to represent how someone in Anthony's position would feel, with each memory revealing just a little bit more to the story. It was useful in showing the ways in which dementia can affect not only the one suffering from it but everybody in that persons life. All in all this was one of the best movies to come out of the decade.

This film depicts dementia incredibly well for the diagnosed person and people involved in their lives.It's sad, educational and soul searching.If you've ever experienced dementia in your family you will totally relate to it with empathy and emotions.An absolute must for professionals and others to watch working in EMI units.Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman plus cast cracked it. Absolute perfection.

Incredibly poignant and heartbreaking, terrifying, beautiful, ingenious, this is a masterpiece. Never have I watched a movie where you can relate so much to the character: a true revelation, you experience what it is like to be them. Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman give a wonderful performance. One of the lines at the end (you will know which) brought abundant tears.This is a traumatic movie and you need ready yourself to watch it, but you will not regret it.
My heart is literally hurting. The acting was just... perfect. It felt so real.. Must see movie, just be sure to have a pack of tissues on stand by. Trust me you'll need it.

This film couldn't have been done better. In a very short period of time, you connect with the characters in a very familiar way. It pulls on the heartstrings in all the right ways. The feeling it evokes at times can be nothing less than grief.Both main actors were incredible for their roles in this film. It was true in the truest sense, as the main character slowly loses his ability to understand what is happening to him.It is heart rending to think of the people we know and love who experience this desease both from the inside and the outside perspective.The music for the film is unobtrusive and unmanipulitive, it is the story that really touches down so heavily, there are several long pauses that give the watcher plenty of time to think extensively about what they just witnessed. It is often these pauses where the greif really hits home.The end scene of the film absolutely had my husband and I sobbing, which is not very common for my husband. It is a film that causes a lot of self reflection as well as stirring up compassion for those we know are currently suffering through this.

Altheimers has always been a big fear for me, as I've seen it happen to People close to me. This is actually kind of an important film as much as it is a horror movie for People knowing about this disease. It handles it so well in many ways. The way they illustrator every day as a New nightmare just perfectly captures the horror of this sickness.. I highly recommend anyone to watch this movie, prepare yourself for a confusing, scary and emotionel ride.Anthony hopkins is exceptionel in this movie, and everyone around him fits their characters perfectly. I bet he made the job easy for his co-actors in this one. Imbarresing that he did not get an award for this. He imerges to this character, like it was himself experiencing this.

Such a powerful story, Anthony Hopkins at his absolute best, I found it confusing at times, you need to stick with it and you will be rewarded with a very powerful message at the end. I absolutely bawled my eyes out at the end, an award winning performance without a shadow of a doubt!

In my opinion, this is a : real, sad, living, honest film. From the side of the person affected with the problem of dementia. It made me cry and feel such empathy for the family.Anthony Hopkins was just wonderful and so genuine- sorry to all actors I know you are good but Anthony Hopkins acting was just first class.Olivia Coleman, as his daughter played the role with genuine sadness, loss of her childhood, and of a person exhausted by it all and was fantastic.Have to say, I was confused myself with the actor Paul slapping the Dad as in the last few minutes of the film the actor Paul appears as the nurse in the home/hospice. I would love to know if there was more to that or not.

A closely observed and compelling journey into dementia which manipulates time and place in order to express the anxiety of the sufferer(s).The closing scene's beauty is matched by its tragedy, and it left me stunned. Unmissable.

reviews.review_title: We hope it doesn't happen to us...
reviews.content: I was on my flight to Burbank Airport while watching this. I usually don't watch films like this and did not know what I was getting into.But I was pleasantly surprised I really liked to see the inside of this terrible disease Alzheimers. In a way I think it can prepare you for what might come to some or prepare you to research as much as possible to prevent it.Anthony really played his part so well. The look of confusion on his face and his beats he took, stumbles on words was so true! And the last few minutes really had me in tears.I recommend this highly.Oh I also loved the fact it was just shot at their home and then a small bit at another location for the end.
Inception but not si-fi. Great acting. Looking forward to more Florian Zeller directing.

This has everything except car chases, zombies and the other ridiculous special effects of modern cinema. This film feels Shakespearean and epic in its profound emotional appeal and comment on the human condition. I was scared, hopeful and sad and very, very confused - in one word, my emotions were running the gamut and I was hooked. At the end I cried like a baby :). And - I love you, Sir Anthony!

Amazing depiction of living with dementia and what it does to the individual and their loved ones. While Anthony Hopkins is amazing, the direction is extremely powerful as well. If you have relatives with dementia, you won't regret watching this movie.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful, albeit depressingly sad masterpiece.
reviews.content: A beautiful, albeit depressingly sad masterpiece. There's no other way to describe it. This is a must watch, but don't forget to bring tissue, you'll certainly need them.
Anthony Hopkins's performance was stunning. This movie shows you some facts about life and it does it in very touching way.
Story seen from the confusing view of a dementia patient.It plots the patients life from being capable but with severe memory problems which mean it is difficult for him to safely look after himself.
Stupid Paul is the worst.I've never been so afraid to get old in my life and wind up never leaving my flat but then find out I've never been there.

I'm totally lost for words! There's no words in the world can describe this masterpiece, Anthony Hopkins acting skills in this movie is beyond human capabilities, something never ever seen before.But beware, this movie is an emotional bomb that will leave you devastated and some scenes in this movie will hunt you till the last day of your life, so better don't watch it, and I mean it!

reviews.content: Apart from that it was pretty much spot on 9/10.Says my review is too short so I would like to add Anthony Hopkins is very good and should be this years recipient of the oscar for lead actor.
Great film, well written, perfect acting. One of the best movie experience that I had in my whole lifetime. It is not for everyone, but I can totally recommend it!

This film remind me a lot of Providence by Alain Reisnais, with John Gielgud, as an old and lonely writer, and all his fantasms about his family.I would say, and, believe me, it is great compliment, this film could have been directed by Alain Reisnais.A great film !

The Silence of The Lambs, Fracture, Hitchcock, and The Elephant Man were all amazing performances by Hopkins but The Father is the only film of these that truly makes you forget your watching a movie. The fear, confusion, frustration, depression, anger, and brief lucidity experienced by dementia sufferers is something many of have seen, but even for those who haven't, his performance is so convincing it throws you into the middle of what a child experiences when their parent is battling the disease. There is nothing like this film. Watch it now.
On the point ! Crispy but a slow poison !It takes us into a emotional roller coaster !Laughter ! Confusion ! Bored ! Saddened !Tearfull ! Anger ! Peace.

Having both grandfather and grandmother struggle with this horrible thing I found it incredibly insightful and compelling. I found it humours, serious and at times saddening, I would recommend this to anyone.
